Recommandé
23.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 7 janvier 2023
It's kinda janky, it stutters sometimes but it basically perfectly sets out what it intends to do: Make a creative photography game in a cool setting. All you do is take pictures at the end of the world and collect stuff. If that sounds cool, you'll like it.

What I didn't expect with this game was that by the end of it I would be an actual photographer. Obviously photography is a complex thing. I'm not claiming to be an expert after playing, but I had never done it before outside of phone cameras.

When you break it down I think this game is actually the perfect tutorial for photography. If you were starting from zero you could watch hours of videos on youtube, but I honestly think you would get more out of spending the same amount of time playing this game.

Through playing you learn in a steady and easy to digest stream:

◇The function of ISO, Aperture and shutter speed
◇The effect of different lenses on perspective and their implication on composition
◇The effect of flash on a scene
◇The functions of different settings in post processing
◇Composition
◇Having rocket skates would make certain shots way easier

When I finished this game I was inspired to buy a camera for myself and was shocked at how pretty much everything in the game translated 1:1 into the real life experience of photography.

I actually cannot think of another game that does this…

You won't be able to do a kickflip straight after playing skate.

You won’t be able to drive rally straight after playing DIRT.

If you’re new to it, you can definitely get a camera and apply the things you’ve learned in Umurangi Generation immediately.

I dunno if steam reviews is the right place to put this kinda stuff. Sorry if it comes off as a bit pretentious or maybe even a bit naive, but where else am I gonna put it?

I love this game.
 
ClockTower

Recommandé
2.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 19 mai 2020
Only game I've played that scratches the same itch as Pokemon Snap. The levels are very well designed and offer a ton of replay value. Even if you complete the main objectives of the photo bounties (mandatory photos you need to take to pass the level), there's very little chance you're going to meet all the objectives your first time playing through a level. It's also worth mentioning that some of the photo bounties are tricky as hell. You might spend two or three minutes trying to get a shot thinking 'how the hell am I expected to do this?' Then all it takes is finding some unexplored distant ledge or a weird corner to pull it off. Provides a lot of great 'aha' moments. Boppin' soundtrack, very colorful level design that offers unique opportunities to go back and explore each one, intuitive controls, a good sense of humor...

I've run into one or two glitches on day-one release, but nothing major. My biggest gripe (that is intentional game design) is there doesn't seem to be a way to adjust the aliasing on the levels. Changing resolution seems to only affect the UI, and I haven't been able to reproduce the graphics in the preview screenshots or what's available to play in the demo.

I talked to the developer about this and he said he was going for a PS2 aesthetic with the rendering. I can respect that, I just wish it was an optional feature as I don't have any nostalgia for those types of games. Considering the focus in Umurangi Generation is on art design and photography, it was disappointing to see the shift in style from the demo, where I feel like I was seeing a lot more of what the game had to show. I'd much rather get as clear of a picture as possible--I genuinely loved some of the shots I pulled off in the demo.

Otherwise, fantastic game, would absolutely recommend it to anyone.
 
ECHtoplasm

41 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation amusante
2
Recommandé
9.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 30 juin 2020
カメラマン(写真家)体験シミュレーターです
所謂雰囲気ゲーの一種で全8面をプレイヤーはカメラだけを携えて旅します。
ストアページのムービーや画像ではサイケデリックな雰囲気が目立ちますが実際のゲーム内では明るさよりも退廃的な雰囲気が目立ち、プレイしている内に方々から穏やかではない「何か」が起きていることを感じとっていきます。

各ステージクリアには30分程度、だらだらやってもゲームクリアまで5時間程度でした。
コントローラーだけでのプレイも可能。
ゲームのクリアに必要なゲーム的な難易度は特に高くもなく、どちらかというとレンズ交換などを駆使して写真撮影や現像する楽しさに主軸が置かれている感じです。
撮影した写真はpngファイルでローカルに保存もされます(オフにすることも可能)。

ゲームのメニューやチュートリアルは日本語化されています。
がステージ上に落ちている新聞の文章や壁の落書きの文字は英語なのでフレーバーテキストが気になる方は調べながら遊ぶ必要があるかもしれません。
ゲーム中にはストーリーの説明シーン等は一切ないですがローマ字表記で日本語のとある単語も出てくるので注意深く見ている方は途中で何かに気づくかもしれません。


ゲームシステム
プレイヤーは各ステージ毎に設定されてる10個の目標(撮影依頼)をマップ上から探しだし写真に収め、ゴール地点に向かいクリア(配達)するのが大まかなルールです。
指定されたオブジェクトをマップ上から探しだす必要があるためプレイ感覚としては「物探し(Hidden Object)ゲー」に似た雰囲気もあります。

制限時間はボーナス達成目標としてカウントされていますがクリアするだけならば気にする必要はなくいつまでも撮影を続けていられます。
また死亡したりゲームオーバー要素もなさそうです。
カメラは24枚撮りのフィルムカメラで撮影回数は有限ですがマップ上にフィルムケースがいたるところに落ちている為、残り回数で困ることもありませんでした。
やり込み要素としてボーナス目標まで全て達成してステージクリアをすると特別な機能がアンロックされるようです(操作方法画面にあるフラッシュもアンロック要素でした)。


ゲームでは使えるレンズは
・標準レンズ
・望遠
・広角
・魚眼
の4本でゲームの進行具合と共に解放されていきます。
シャッターを切った後には現像メニューが開き画像修正が可能です。
・露出
・カラーバランス
・カラーティント
・彩度
・コントラスト
・色相
・ブルームエフェクト
・色収差
が調節可能ですが設定メニューから現像をオフにして撮って出しだけで済ませることも可能です。
現像作業はあくまでプレイヤーが写真を撮影する楽しみのもので、ゲームの攻略の上では気にしなくていいのは不快要素にならなくていい調整だと思います。
ステージクリア時には写真の買取が行われ撮影内容によってトータル収益が表示されますが、これもあくまで雰囲気作りのエッセンスにとどまっています。


このゲームの製作者はよくある80年代風モチーフに囚われているサイバーパンク世界ではない、今現代の世界をテーマにしたサイバーパンク世界を目指したそうです。
またダークソウルシリーズにも影響を受けているとか。
ゲーム内から感じ取れる終末的な雰囲気はそれらや今の社会情勢も反映されているのかもしれません。
ゲームのやり込みよりも自分でゲームの楽しみ方を見つけるのがお好きな方にはおすすめのゲームです。
 
hal8KURAGE

I bought this game without reading the description or watching the trailers and thought it was just a game about taking photos of your friends. It ended up being a dystopian sci-fi narrative with heavy social commentary. Loved it. Great photography gameplay mechanics.
 
paimona

35 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
6
Recommandé
5.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 21 avril 2023
One of the odder aspects of indie games going (semi) mainstream and being sold alongside AAA games has been the increased marketing of “indie” as a brand, a shared aesthetic and idea. By and large, it’s not, and insofar as there’s a shared indie sensibility, it’s only shared by more conservative indies, which use the language and structure of traditional, publisher-made video games by iterating on established genres.

But there’s a bigger, weirder sphere of games that largely exists outside of commercial games, on Itch, or Gamejolt, or even more obscure places on the internet. 99.99% of these games will only be played by a small insider audience, and maybe a few kids exploring what’s available for free, but every once in a while one escapes. Umurangi Generation is such a game; it’s absolutely inspired by known commercial titles, most notably Jet Set Radio [7] (with whom it shares an audiovisual aesthetic and an appreciation of graffiti culture) and Pokemon Snap (because it’s a photography game and, for some bizarre reason, Pokemon Snap remains the only traditionally published photography game, at least until 2020’s Bugsnax).

But while Jet Set Radio borrowed the iconography of punk, Umurangi Generation straight-up *is* punk, albeit a 21st century sort that embraces rather than rejects national identities.

What is Umurangi Generation about? If I’m being honest, I’m not entirely sure; there’s no dialog, just artful dioramas you explore and photograph. In this case, they’re of future New Zealand, occupied by UN forces as NGE-style mechs battle alien kaiju. It’s an image-and-tone driven piece, and I’ll be the first to admit that I’m not a great visual thinker, and surely missed a lot. There’s an atmosphere of antipathy and frustration (towards globalism and foreign governments, towards a world seemingly on an irreversible course towards destruction) but also quiet resignation, and an appreciate of the beauty of life’s small joys: making art, hanging with friends.

It’s telling that I’ve taken this long to write about the actual gameplay; the photography is actually quite good, easy to use and slowly giving you more filters and lenses to keep things interesting and give you reason to return to previous levels. But for me, it was a means to end, a lens (no pun intended) to explore this strange world. There’s many bonus objectives, and to “max out” a level you have to race against time to accomplish everything in a certain window. If you try to achive this, it will greatly extend the game’s playtime, forcing you to memorize every nook and cranny, the fastest pathways through, the quickest-to-reach angles necessary for certain photographs. It’s a particuarly novel speedrunning game, and I admire it, while simultaneously having absolutely no desire to race the clock. I find timers anxiety-inducing, and thus stay far away from speedrunning.

Did I enjoy Umurangi Generation? Yes, but I probably appreciated it more than I enjoyed it, in part because it felt like a game intended for someone else: someone younger and more in tune with its ideas about the world, who found empowerment rather than disillusion in its politics, and who took a lot more pleasure from getting the perfect photograph, even if there was nobody else around to appreciate it.
 
Aerothorn
1,793 produits enregistrés
0
37 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation amusante
11
Recommandé
2.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 3 décembre 2020
У нас в Тауранге война с неизвестным противником. В новостях говорят, что мы отбиваемся, но нас, походу, уже колонизируют. Тротуары усыпаны тушками инопланетных медуз, солдаты ООН лениво постреливают из винтовок по громадным силуэтам на горизонте. Сутулые, серые, совершенно бесконечные очереди беженцев день и ночь дежурят у сторожевых пунктов – а вдруг выпустят? Мы слышали, что на Северно-западном блокпосту вчера пропускали. А еще говорят, будто бы одну зверюгу таки грохнули. Кровищи-то было!
Тебя разговоры волновать не должны. Не твой конек. Ты – фотокор конца света. У тебя своя работа: крути объектив, щелкай затвором. Задания газеты «Тауранга-Экпресс» абсурдные, но несложные: два бумбокса в одном кадре, фото чайки через телескопический объектив, снимок киви. Киви в каком смысле – птица или плод? В любом. Что попадется, то и снимай.
Ноги – в коньки, наушники – в уши, и вперед. Скользи на роликах по крышам и рампам, ныряй в толпу, ищи удачные ракурсы. Щелкай снимки. Не теряй времени – в идеале материал нужно сдать за десять минут. Впрочем, руки за опоздание не оторвут, так что работай в собственном ритме.
Главное – поймай в объектив ускользающие в бездну очертания момента. Маори называют его «Умуранги», что значит «Красное небо». Оно действительно такое – иногда непроницаемо-бордовое, иногда болезненно-пунцовое; всегда – красное, всегда – над головой; насмешка, напоминание о неизбежности конца. Сфотографируй его для газеты.
Для газеты фотографируй и улицы. Они – зал ожидания катастрофы. Круглосуточно в неоновом свете клубятся пестрые толпы. Люди отчаялись куда-то отчалить, и толкаются на перекрестках просто так. В толпе спокойнее, в толпе быстрее узнаешь все новости – в основном, перевранные или вовсе выдуманные. Да и что толку прятаться в домах, которые вот-вот рухнут вместе со всем остальным? На миру и смерть красна.
Сфотографируй трагедию юности – для себя. В граффити молодые изливают свой гнев – ООН нас продали, политики продали, копы продали. Где эти престарелые умники, когда земля и небо в огне? Потерянное поколение (все чаще говорят: последнее поколение), тусуется по углам и в переходах, прогоняет тоску безудержным танцем. Приглашены все – панки и рэперы, уличная шпана и геймеры, стритрейсеры и безусые добровольцы.
Ты понимаешь их боль, ведь в твоих венах – яд обреченной юности. Как и у всей твоей бригады. Не экономь пленку. Щелкни своих корешей пару раз – для вечности. Щелк, Щелк. Как челюсти рока у самого горла цивилизации. Щелк, щелк, щелк.
 
Major Tom

Évaluation publiée le 26 décembre 2020
update: I have changed the review from negative to positive. A recent patch states changes were made to movement to help prevent inducing motion sickness. I's been a year since I last played and between that update, and the high refresh rate update I was able to play longer than all previous attempts and past where I had been previously without a sign of becoming nauseated! Previously I had to turn it off within 15 minutes of starting, so thank you for the improvement!

Maybe don't buy this game if you can be prone to getting motion sickness at times.

It's a neat game and I would like to play more of it, the music is great and it's saying things, but something with the view controls makes me motion sick every time I play it, doesn't matter what I change the mouse sensitivity to.

That's the only reason I don't recommend it and maybe a downvote helps surface this for someone else who would appreciate the warning.
 
neuroflare

Recommandé
6.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 14 septembre 2023
Diría que es uno de los juegos mas únicos que he jugado, no por que tenga un gameplay o una historia diferente a todo lo conocido, sino por su estilo y su forma de presentar el mundo.

Realmente es simple, apareces en un nivel y tienes que tomar fotos a objetos o conjunto de estos para avanzar. Eso si, tiene sus retos, tanto en encontrar dichas cosas, usar el lente especifico, buscar la manera de encuadrarlos en una sola foto y si es posible, en menos de 10 min (igual solo es opcional). En este apartado es visualmente increíble, las opciones de filtros, de colores, todo tiene el potencial de verse fantástico ♥♥♥ la suficiente creatividad.

Lo que si me encontré ♥♥♥ muchos problemas de las colisiones, en especial ♥♥♥ las escaleras que parecen ser una sugerencia la mayoría de las veces. Atravesar paredes, pisos, flotar o salir disparado en el aire sin razon alguna puede resultar molesto en muchas ocasiones.

No hablo de la historia porque al final, creo que vale totalmente la pena experimentarla, tiene sus sorpresas y sus puntos impactantes. Totalmente recomendable para los que quieran una experiencia corta y única.
 
RockoTrex

Boon
0
51 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
3 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation amusante
12
Recommandé
5.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 16 aout 2021
The world you wished for

Umurangi Generation (Origame Digital, 2020) is a photography game about being young and punk at the end of the world. Grab your camera and skates, disregard the caution tape, and dance with the roller goths and neon hipsters. It has vibes for days and is angry as hell. It’s the end of the world, after all. The water’s rising, the sky is red, freaking kaiju are demolishing the city! Maybe we could have stopped it at one point but now we’re just buying time. The most expensive, explosive time the UN military can buy. A billion homeless and they're building EVA!. Of course they're building EVAs.

Earlier this year Congress approved a $25b increase to military funding over the $715b Biden already requested. It is a staggering amount of money, enough to drown whole continents in lead. After more than a year of death, protests, failing infrastructure, and natural disasters, our leaders have once again invested in violence. More money means more guns means more poor kids to shoot them means more bodies to blanket the scorched earth. I’m sure in a bunker somewhere we’re building mechs.

The US is a colonial project. It has no claim to anything but a history of genocide, and facing the existential threat of a dying planet it reaches for what’s familiar: guns, police, nationalism. The billionaires are fleeing to space but the normal rich have to settle for bunkers in New Zealand and whatever sociopathic impulses they feel like funding. Millions are being evicted and our government is burning ants under a magnifying glass.

Umurangi isn’t set in the US – it takes place in Tauranga Aotearoa (what colonizers have named New Zealand) – but the US has functionally seized the country. UN propaganda – which, judging by flags, is now just the US and Britain, a colonial power couple – blankets the walls and claims ownership of anything it can stamp. PROPERTY OF THE UN. POLICE WILL NOT BE HELD RESPONSIBLE. Security walls stretch past the tops of buildings, a bounty on anyone who tries to climb out. Life in a trash compactor.

The kaiju and EVAs are fighting in the distance as I slip into “Gamer’s Paradise,” letting the nightclub bass wash over me like a bad trip. Topside the sirens are wailing, but here people are dancing, drinking, dozing in VR headsets. It’s the end of the world, after all. You can die a martyr or a hedonist but you’re gonna die either way. I’m too poor to blackout, so I take my pictures, pick up my pay, and go find my friends at the homeless camp.

Umurangi hums along with an understated tension. I’m chilling with my friends on a rooftop overlooking Mauao mountain. Sometimes the jets fly too close but if you try you can almost forget the war a few stories down. We stop at a military camp, drift through the streets of Kati Kati. Everyone’s waiting for the next attack, wondering if it’ll be their city that gets hit, but right now we can breathe.

A while back I wrote about camera confidence in Dear Future[kritiqal.com] (Dear Future Production Committee, 2021). Like Umurangi, Dear Future is also about taking photos of a dying world, only in that game, life has already moved on. There are no people to observe, no neon lights or gunshots blowing out the exposure. Even the trash is mostly gone. It’s easy to loiter, to spend precious minutes waiting for the sun to set and the shadows to land where I want them. The game ends when the sun goes down but somehow this only makes me move slower. Everything that is going to happen already has. There’s no need to rush.

Umurangi, conversely, is full of happenings. Stories litter the ground and pile up in corners as I try to track down my list of shots. I’m bumping into strangers and falling off ledges but I’m not satisfied leaving with just my delivery. Life in Umurangi is dense. Graffiti and music and resistance overflows from spaces that should be too small to hold them. These people have been forgotten but they’re alive. In spite of everything they’re alive and I want to preserve that somehow, to pretend that there is a future and someone will find these pictures and that will somehow make this OK. Not OK, but…not for nothing.

Who is buying all these photos? Are they UN propaganda? Newspaper exposés? Random prints for the few people with money to spare? Most likely it’s all of the above, different parties pulling apart the film for what they need and passing me a few bucks for my troubles. Every image is worth something to someone and when you are poor and homeless and hungry your decisions stop being about politics but about survival. I’m not an embedded journalist or government photographer, I’m just some kid with a camera. Someone who will throw themselves into firefights and army bunkers if it means I’m not sleeping on a park bench. I lean into that camera confidence, that feeling of invincibility behind the lens. Nobody with the power to pay me – with the power to do ♥♥♥♥ to stop this – wants to be here themselves. They’re off on holiday or deep underground getting drunk with hologram girls. I send them postcards of rooftops on fire. They wire me $5.

As hyper aware as I am of Umurangi’s citizens, nobody seems to care that I’m there. I slip past barricades, poke my camera into the faces of strangers, and am utterly ignored. This is a game and I’m the player doing random ♥♥♥♥ like jumping on the damn robot, but also, why _should_ anyone bother with me? We are all tired and scared and just existing. These aren’t our problems but we’re the ones out here trying to fix them. Umurangi is angry as hell and its people don’t have time for cops and petty fights.

When Umurangi’s tutorial asks if I’ve played a first-person shooter it isn’t explicitly making a correlation between itself and a game like Doom. FPS is just videogame shorthand, ultimately. We know how to look and shoot and move with WASD so let’s not waste time with the basics. But the acknowledgement lingers with me. There are many trite things to be said about the mechanical similarities between guns and cameras – of triggers and flashes and the reaping of souls – but Umurangi doesn’t care about them and frankly neither do I. I’m too busy noticing that there are only guns and cameras. Kids who look like me leaning on rifles as I take their portraits; kids counting munitions in the sewers; kids bleeding out as the sky turns red and their bullets do ♥♥♥♥ all to save them. My camera is just as useless, just as much a tool, just as impassionate about who it shoots.

What were these kids’ options? They could join the army – be given a gun, authority, a momentary sense of safety – or they could run the same streets with a camera like me, making deliveries and trying not to get shot. I can’t blame them for enlisting. I save my anger for the recruiters, the arms dealers, and everyone else who told this kid they’d be taken care of. I take one last picture as the medic tries to stop the bleeding. The shot’s not on my list and I don’t know who it’s for but it’s all I can do to acknowledge they were here. That they were alive. I feel sick as my wallet grows $3 heavier.

Umurangi is the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ future we occupy, the compromises and pain and small moments of joy all combusting at once. There are no good choices left, they’ve all been stolen from us. What do you do when the world’s on fire but you’re hungry and the landlord’s demanding rent? At what point does the dark comedy of capitalism finally break? Umurangi knows we’ve passed the point of no return but have to keep living like we still have time. It acknowledges our anger but refuses to give up on the people left behind.

We hold on to each other and make what we can of the time that’s left. It’s the end of the world, after all.

This essay appeared on KRITIQAL[kritiqal.com].
 
KRITIQAL
2,110 produits enregistrés
0
28 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
2
Recommandé
14.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 26 mai 2020
I strongly recommend ignoring the countdown timer on your first play through. Just play this game at your own leisurely pace and take your time. This timer is purely for a bonus objective and is not compulsory at all in order to progress.

tl;dr: If you're the kind of person who likes the idea of wandering around interesting locations, taking pictures of various things from multiple angles while experimenting with various camera lenses and image adjustments, then Umurangi Generation is for you.

This game really shines when you spend your time just soaking in the atmosphere and taking pictures anything interesting you stumble upon. Experimenting with multiple camera angles with the various camera lenses and image adjustment sliders that you unlock along the way can be pretty addictive. I played through locations multiple times because I wanted to go back and try things differently.

The art style and characters are really vibrant and reminiscent of Jet Set Radio's graffiti inspired cyberpunk cel shaded aesthetic (with banging electronic soundtrack to match). The story, while not overly complicated, is told almost exclusively through the world environment and can be easy to miss if you aren't paying attention.

**Feedback for devs**

-Hide that countdown timer! It gives a false sense of urgency and promotes rushing through locations that have clearly been meticulously created. Maybe have a checkbox option next to the bonus objective but have it off by default?

-I think having some kind of user friendly photo submissions system where we can upvote other people's photos would really help to create a thriving community around this game. At the very least, encourage players to go onto the Steam community hub (ugh) to submit photos and rate other player's.
 
CHOIMAI

Produit reçu gratuitement

意识流末世摄影师模拟，光是这摄追赤红末世代这名儿它就够意识流。
游戏给玩家的目标是在场景内找到特定物品并拍摄照片，如果有攻略，你可以找的非常快。
但对玩家个人来说，真正的目标应该是拍出够味儿的照片。
给推荐仅是因为我既不懂摄影，又不懂艺术。
倒不是因为它好玩。
 
晴天披笠 (ver. 节能模式)
3,353 produits enregistrés

30 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
4
Recommandé
6.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 2 janvier 2022
Umurangi Generations is the angriest game I've ever played. The government has failed to protect its people and you can see resentment to said government in every aspect of the world. Every newspaper, every piece of graffiti, every person in this world depict the numerous failures that have occurred. It is explicitly political and relentless in its critique, a welcome change in this era of so called "apolitical" video games.

Cool atmosphere, cool environmental storytelling, lovely soundtrack by that boi ThorHighHeels. It's got everything I love in a video game, and I just wish it was more polished on the technical side, as there's a lot of screen tearing and the image is not very crisp.

Évaluation publiée le 6 décembre 2020
Listen, I'm bad at Umurangi Generation. I like taking photos, but I'm not really creative or imaginative enough to see a scene and think "Oh, THIS is how I want to take a photo of this!". Good news though, because despite not really knowing what I'm doing, the game gives you enough options and cool scenes that when you go through your gallery and reviewing your photos, you'll see one and think "Hey, this one's really good!". And that's a nice feeling.
 
Bear Force One
0
22 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation amusante
7
Recommandé
10.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 30 décembre 2020
Играя в Umurangi Generation ощущаешь себя не фотожуром, а другом, нежданно-негаданно завалившимся к талантливому приятелю на хату средь бела дня: свидетелем разбросанных по комнате потников с трусами и незаправленной кровати, который всё же постукивает ногой в такт гоняющему сэмплы Fruity Loops и одобрительно кивает в сторону затегованного black book'а — вот эта вот застигнутая врасплох, неряшливая самобытность сделанного на коленке первого Unity проекта вкупе с набитым годами стилем и авторским звучанием[thorhighheels.bandcamp.com].

Только на вписке в такой берлоге можно познакомиться с живущей за гранью добра и зла красоткой Джейд и её молоденькой сестрой Максин Колфилд. И только в гостях у такого товарища можно застревать в текстурках и абьюзить баги коллизий, делая распрыжку на лестнице чтобы взмыть в небо и поймать кадром кроссбридинг Flag от Bandai и Gainax'овского мультика про баку Синдзи на фоне Новозеландской культуры; Pokemon Snap отдыхает.

Но не все Покемоны такие дружелюбные. Переливающийся неоновой палитрой Umurangi Generation, словно ностальгирующий хамелеон, косит под Dreamcast графику хитового Jet Set Radio, и умело маскирует lo-fi шумом свой по-хищному геймплейный нрав — поиск предметов/ракурсов на грани воксель/пиксель хантинга с черепашьей скоростью. Вместе с игроком ползёт по швам и позерская 【ａｅｓｔｈｅｔｉｃｓ】, раскрывающая самоиронию истинно vaporwave'вовской практики осмеяния консьюмеризма: перед нами инди-игра, продающая возможность бегать и низко приседать в составе DLC, будто микротранзакционный AAA зашквар.

На лицо проблема всех молодых — UG не знает кем она хочет стать когда вырастет, и мечется между симулятором фотографа с арт-песочницей, в итоге недодавая ни тут ни там. Медитативность рушится прессингом таймера с лимитом на плёнку, прохождение стопорится надмозговыми описаниями задач, а самовыражение ужимается залоченным арсеналом примочек с насадками для камеры, открывать которые приходится насилием над собой.

И ладно бы всё это имело хоть какую-то мета-надстройку и связь с сюжетом, но нет; натужно и никчемушно. По итогу выходит что ваннаби-художникам разумнее отложить деньгу на беззеркалку или камерафон, а сторонникам диегетического[vk.com] подхода к виртуальной съёмке пошаманить хаками c Framed[framedsc.com], ну или взять любой open-world тайтл с фото-режимом и не заморачиваться.

Как ни крути HSL ползунки, Umurangi Generation остаётся расфокусированной игрой. Но она же является парадоксально чётким игровым опытом, критика которого сводится лишь к единственному, знаковому фишке-изъяну — неопытности автора, раздутой под зумом нескромных амбиций. Несмотря на очевидные огрехи, вся эта техническая безалаберность умудряется довести до слёз своим ответом на глубоко личный вопрос о том что такое фотография и что значит быть фотографом.

UG это не игра о съёмке, а игра как снимок; четырёхмерный ПЭТ-скан Земного организма, запечатлевший всю протяжённость момента разгара пандемии: с политическим абсурдизмом, апокалиптическим настроем, и невидимым монстром, в пасти которого пропадают друзья и близкие; с попытками зашториться от всего этого линзами VR шлемов в самоизоляции одиночных камер; с провалами; с бесчеловечными практиками сильных мира сего, наживающихся на панике и не желающих защищать тех за кого они взяли ответственность.

Смотря на монитор впереди я оглядываюсь назад; оборачиваясь же назад я вижу впереди проблески надежд и нависшую над ними непроглядную мглу. Фотограф — это ловец духов. Одноглазый Гинко, знаток Муси, хранящий то чего уже нет в том что ещё есть. Да и сам светописец как плёнка, тонкая мембрана между ещё/уже; эмульсия из звёздной пыли и соли земли, экспонирующая собой память небесных светил. Посредством него реальность видит себя; отражаясь же в ней мы наблюдаем всё остальное.

Umurangi Generation лучше всего описывает её же собственный персонаж — пингвин. Это не отсылка к Pen² из Евангелиона и не пришедший к протагонисту Бойцовского клуба проводник, вуалирующий плевок в сторону общества потребления. Пингвин — тотемное животное нашего поколения. Символ тотального бессилия жалких людишек перед стоящими у руля власти богоподобными кайдзю, растапливающих приютившие нас льдины геополитической Пангеи. Несопоставимости масштабов и непопадания самого важного в кадр. Неспособности улететь; возможности лишь ускользать эскапизмом по глади промозглых будней в экзистенциальную тьму, как закатное солнце на багряном небе — называемом по-маорийски "umurangi".

Charles Bukowski, "Hug the dark" a écrit :
there is no god
there are no politics
there is no peace
there is no love.

there is no control
there is no plan.

stay away from god
remain disturbed

slide.

Это последняя из увиденных мною в 2020-м игр, подводящая под ним черту. Последняя фотография, запечатлевшая в моём зрачке то как мир умирал.

it's like jet set radio but it makes you sad

34 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile

Recommandé
6.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 8 janvier 2023
kill facists
 
Dommi Pickles
0
15 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
1
Recommandé
4.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 20 mai 2021
Cento e vinte nove fotos. Pelo menos foi isso o que foi salvo em uma pasta separada que o próprio jogo cria. Não poderia ser por menos. Umurangi Generation é um jogo visual, uma narrativa que se cria com imagens e não se conta, uma jornada psicodélica por um futuro distópico que mistura elementos da cultura cyberpunk com o mais puro horror existencial. Explicar Umurangi Generation com palavras é a sina de quem ousa analísá-lo, como descrever uma música, pintar um orgasmo ou esculpir o vazio inexorável.

Ganhei o jogo de presente do camarada Caco, um aventureiro de experiências diferenciadas, um connoisseur de horizontes sombrios, depois de demonstrar interesse em sua análise[www.gamerview.com.br]. É um convite para ser uma testemunha silenciosa do fim do mundo. O rugido da guerra está por toda parte mas a última geração do planeta está disposta a ir embora com festa e estilo, dançando ao ar livre e relaxando com pinguins.

Cabem ao jogador duas tarefas hercúleas: documentar em fotos o cotidiano no limiar do abismo e reunir os fragmentos de informações espalhados pelo jogo para tentar montar um painel mental do que suas pupilas contemplam.

Strike a Pose!

Durante a faculdade de Jornalismo adquiri um gosto pela fotografia, a ponto de comprar uma câmera profissional. É importante destacar que esse gosto não se refletiu necessariamente em talento e minhas notas sempre foram medianas. Entretanto, o prazer de colocar uma interface entre minha visão e o mundo ao meu redor era por demais instigante. Através do olhar, reinterpretava e entendia o vasto mundo que me parecia tão inóspito em minha timidez.

O custo elevado da fotografia analógica, principalmente em preto e branco, sepultou esse prazer. Ainda assim, a percepção da função das imagens permaneceu. De certa forma, as paisagens eletrônicas se tornaram uma espécie de nova forma de exercer essa prática e o tema das fotografias virtuais se tornou querido por mim e presença constante no blog. Os anos de interesse continuaram não se revertendo em talento, mas estou tranquilo em relação a isso: você não precisa ser bom em um hobby para apreciá-lo.

Umurangi Generation está para a fotografia como Tony Hawk está para o skate: você não sairá um ás do mundo real após o jogo, mas terá uma compreensão melhor de como ele funciona. Além disso, suas mecânicas são bem parecidas. Em ambos os títulos, você recebe uma lista de missões para serem realizadas em um cenário aberto e precisa explorar cada detalhe para descobrir o ponto exato para completar a conquista, enquanto sutil e simultaneamente mergulha em uma cultura e em uma época.

A imersão de Tony Hawk era a cena skatista dos anos 90, suas gírias, suas músicas, seu estilo de se vestir. Aqui, vivenciamos a última geração do planeta, nos anos 30, suas gírias, sua música, seu estilo de vestir, que misturam elementos dos vibrantes e coloridos anos 80 com uma forte pitada de atmosfera niilista. Trafegar pelas ruas, prédios e vielas de Umurangi Generation é como revisitar um clipe do Duran Duran renderizado em um PlayStation 1.

A decisão estética do jogo foge do realismo e não consigo imaginar se ele funcionaria rodando em Unreal 4 com efeitos de ray-tracing ou qualquer outro modernismo. Há algo de fortemente retrô nesse futuro, o ciclo infindável das tendências que se repetem, a mesma atitude que a juventude apresenta diante da tragédia ou da sociedade que não o compreende, independente da década. Em meio ao apocalipse, celebra-se a vontade de viver, como se não houvesse o amanhã, como se as consequências do hoje não importassem.

Embarcamos então como um registrador que não participa. Somos o Vigia dessa realidade na beira do colapso.

Umurangi Generation é brilhante como declaração de amor a sua arte. Isso se percebe ao oferecer diferentes tipos de lentes para sua câmera e trazer outros recursos desbloqueáveis que modificam o retrato dessa realidade, como filtros e parâmetros configuráveis. Outro grande acerto é o breve tutorial que ensina o básico do básico da fotografia. O jogo também se destaca por trazer algoritmos capazes de analisar as fotos que você tira e classificá-las de acordo com parâmetros pré-estabelecidos. Entretanto, o grande trunfo mesmo é a liberdade que o jogo oferece. Não se trata de tirar a fotografia perfeita, mas de buscar sua expressão, de buscar a liberdade de escolha, sem julgamentos, sem preocupação com pontos.

Ainda assim, completar os objetivos pode ser trabalhoso e há um marcador de tempo que adiciona uma certa pressão ao jogo. Equilibrar a proposta com a necessidade de se "gamificar" o processo pode ter sido o único erro que Umurangi Generation comete.

Relatos do Fim do Mundo

Sem diálogos de qualquer tipo ou explicações, essa realidade se configura como um enigma para o jogador, uma camada extra de jogabilidade que precisa ser descortinada. Ou não. Apenas saia por aí e tire suas fotos, sinta o mundo, não tente compreendê-lo.

Esse sentimento de descolamento da realidade, de não entender o zeitgeist, parece ser compartilhado pelos habitantes dessa era. Sem diálogos, é realmente impossível afirmar certezas. O fato é que o mundo de Umurangi Generation está sofrendo uma invasão inexplicada e, provavelmente, inexplicável.

Forças hostis e inumanas estão vencendo batalhas sucessivas contra nossa espécie e as Nações Unidas impõem um regime de controle draconiano para murar e proteger os sobreviventes. Na medida em que o jogo progride, você vai assistindo ao fracasso desses esforços, se juntando aos refugiados de uma guerra da qual só vemos fragmentos.

Na metáfora, Umurangi Generation dialoga com tantas situações reais dos dias de hoje. Guerras que só são compreendidas pelas altas esferas impactam o cidadão comum, que se vê refém do horror e direciona sua amargura contra as forças militares.

Curiosamente, os objetivos do jogo não tem qualquer relação com o conflito, que funciona apenas como um trágico e preocupante pano de fundo. O jogador precisa escavar as pistas, ficar atento a propagandas, manchetes de jornais e até mesmo pôsteres de filmes desse futuro onírico.

Afinal, quem é o contratante? Quem é a pessoa que exige que tiremos fotos de fatos cotidianos ou objetos sem significado, quando a História está acontecendo ao nosso redor? Para quem ficarão esses registros? Não importa, porque nada importa.

A desobediência civil é uma das tônicas. Incapazes de reagir contra a ameaça externa, a frustração transborda para as tropas de ocupação e suas muralhas inúteis. Esse mundo quer dançar e relaxar até o último segundo e essa vontade indomável não condiz com a tentativa de regulação imposta.

Ao final de tudo, a profecia se cumpre. De fato, nada importava. Nem guerra. Nem dança. Nem alegria, cores ou picardias. O epílogo de Umurangi Generation é perturbador e escancara aquilo que não queríamos ver anteriormente.

Retina Desgastada

As duas camadas de Umurangi Generation se chocam ao final de tudo e se diluem. Esse mundo se esvai. Ficam cento e vinte nove fotos em uma pasta, um amontoado de palavras que apenas arranha sua superfície, oito registros em vídeo e uma retina mais desgastada do que quando começou.

Publicado originalmente em: https://blog.retinadesgastada.com.br/2021/05/jogando-umurangi-generation.html
 
retinadesgastada
1,859 produits enregistrés
0
23 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation amusante
0
Non recommandé
3.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 8 juin 2020
Produit reçu gratuitement

* 中国鉴赏家同好会[开发者邀请]评测
*开发者邀请评测由开发者邀请同好会成员免费测试游戏的方式，最终产生的玩家评测,故该评测仅作为参考，望读者理性阅读，谨慎购买。

前言

作为一个喜欢拍拍拍但是由于贫困的经济能力只能用手机拍照的人，很多时候还是对那些拿着“长枪短炮”的人十分眼馋的。既有一种文艺范，相片质量又好，谁不喜欢呢。

虽然买相机的钱是紧张的，但过相机瘾的心还是要有的，幸运的是，终于看到了一部专门服务于照相的游戏,《摄追赤红末时代》

既然是以摄影作为招牌，那这块招牌如何呢？我的看法是，它有着

极佳的专业摄影体系

这里所说的摄影体系，一方面，是指游玩时对相机，这个玩家操控的“玩具”，有很多现实相机元素的添加。

基本的，曝光，远近，左右倾斜这些拍摄元素，一应俱全。

如果想进阶的拍出更好的照片，游戏同样给了你选择，便是不同的“相机镜头”。这个需要游玩关卡后不断的解锁。而不同的镜头也如现实一样对处于同等距离和曝光度的同一物体，有着或清晰，或模糊的差别。而镜头所拍出照片的样式也会略有差别。

拍完后觉得不满意？修图功能也有！拍完一张照片后可以对照片进行曝光，颜色等的修饰，让相片有着不一样的意境。

虽然没用过单反，但根据之前傻瓜相机以及手机的体验，不同镜头和照片后修图，都是现实中拍摄设备的标配。制作方也确实是为还原做了功课。

而摄影体系的另一方面，就是对相片有着体系化的反馈。

这一点，制作组做的很棒。每次拍完照片修完图后，游戏都会为你的相片给出你这照片所使用的美学体系和艺术流派等等等，通过钱数来对你的相片进行打分。这样既可以学习自己“乱”拍的照片所代表的艺术流派和知识，还能知道如何拍出更好的照片，应用于现实，可谓一举两得。当然如果作者能把评价体系的机制单独成漫画书，作为摄影教程，那就更好了。

可是，当摄影体系转换到这个游戏本身，却是一副好牌打个稀烂

与介绍并不相称的游戏体验（目前来看）

根据介绍而言，这款游戏的背景是未来还是一个腐败的社会。确实有些诱导人，让人以为它本来应该主打在未来世界下摄影人的生活。。有着精彩深度兼备的剧情（一度以为是个摄影版大都会）

可是，游戏里的未来生活仅仅只是个背景板，你做的还是司空见惯的根据关卡里不同的要求去拍照。没有任何剧情。浪费了一个华丽且充满想象力的设定和背景。

当然，没剧情也只是较为可惜，但不至使它毫无可玩性。因为这个游戏场景十分多样，拍摄的要求也随时会变，新鲜感一直在，如果只是安于做一个拍照模拟器，也已然是现在游戏里难得一见的了。

然而，它第二步棋，却是个昏招，东西得自己寻找，这就难受

这里面每个关卡会交代不少需要找的物体，再拍照，但很多时候这些物体就是死活找不到，藏得太深太隐蔽。好好一个拍照游戏，变成了一个寻物游戏。而且，更可怕的是，找不全不给通关。

这就很打击人了，本身想做个轻轻松松的拍照达人，拍拍美景晒晒，学学技术知识装x的游戏，变成了个毫无乐趣的扫荡，有的关卡花了一个多小时就为找一两个物体，还没剧情支撑，太无聊了吧。。有这时间玩个剧情游戏，玩个欢乐游戏不好？

总结与改进建议

这款游戏游玩机制已经十分完美了，对初学者或者深度摄影爱好者都很有吸引力。然而较差的游戏设计拖累了这样的机制，使得它除了发烧友和特别耐心的人以外，并不适合所有人去玩，趣味不足。因而提出两个方向的改进建议，以供参考

1. 可以增添剧情，使得找东西的过程不是只是为了找而找，而是为了某一个具体的行为背书，起码完成了也会有着一定的成就感或者期待之后剧情的期待感。

2 或者是可以单独出一个不限时间，也不用找东西，随便拍随便游览的观赏模式。这样可以为更多玩家提供一个拍照的平台又不会因为找东西的复杂而羁绊烦恼。，一举两得。创意工坊也可以搞起来，方便大家设计不同的场景来让别人拍照，甚至官方还可以搞个摄影竞赛之类的，挺好的。

虽然这次给的是差评，但这个机制确实合我胃口，希望作者在改进已有游戏的同时，也能继续用这套摄影体系做更多优秀的游戏，加油，奥力给。（如果更新了视情况会改评测）
 
HYMON ROTH
0
14 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
17.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 28 juillet 2023
Umurangi Generation

The game's premise is all about becoming a photographer. You've got specific pictures to capture and deliver within a tight time limit, and that's just the beginning. The real magic happens when you start exploring the environment, finding the perfect angles and subjects to frame up. It's a mix of platforming and exploration, and it's oh-so-satisfying.

Beauty is in the eye of the beholder, and you'll discover that some shots may not be objectively stunning, but they hold the most truth about the world you're exploring. As you experiment with different lenses and editing options, you'll find yourself drawn deeper into the game's powerful narrative.

Now, I won't lie, the movement can be a bit janky, but that somehow adds to the overall impact of the game. It's like life itself, with its imperfections and challenges. And speaking of challenges, the tasks you're given push you to find both the strikingly beautiful shots and the ones that reveal the less-than-pretty truths of the world.

As you get lost in the stunning world of "Umurangi Generation," you'll realize that the game's limitations are a reflection of the developer's own experiences and outlook on life. It's a game by the marginalized, for the marginalized, and it's deeply impactful.

I had the pleasure of playing it on the Switch, and let me tell you, it's a whole new level of experience. The handheld mode makes you feel like a real photographer, capturing the world through a lens. The gyro controls complete the package, making it the definitive edition and with me having my eyes on the steamdeck... I wonder if I can relive that, I did love that level of immersion.

Sure, it may not be a big AAA title, but "Umurangi Generation" defies conventions and delivers a joyful yet painful experience. It's vibrant and empowering, yet also bleak and confining. This game has left a permanent mark on me, changing the way I see video games, the real world, and myself. Its imperfections are what make it so perfect. Give this game the attention it deserves, and you'll be in for a wild ride.
 
Kenstagator

Recommandé
14.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 13 février 2021
Umurangi Generation is a photography-simulator-game by ORIGAME DIGITAL, i.e. Naphtali Faulkner, a lone Maori game developer.

The game's premise is easily explained: You're an amateur photographer and courier in Tauranga. You have a checklist of motives you have to photograph, but as long as you don't run out of film, you can also photograph whatever you want and still earn some money.

Despite the fact that no game I've heard of before has dealt with the concept of photography so intensively, the fact that it's a decent photography-sim isn't even the coolest thing about the game, because it has a really impressive artstyle, reminiscent of Jet Set Radio, so you actually want to take photographs, and it has subtle but effective storytelling too! As the levels progress, you'll inevitably notice that Tauranga is facing several crises, but by the time you really start questioning what's going on, it's already too late. But I won't spoil anything here, most of the social commentary is something a person in 2021 should be able to pick up on, with some Neon Genesis Evangelion- and SciFi-vibes sprinkled on top. However, this is all conveyed via environmental storytelling, so don't expect a blockbuster here.

The game is fairly short at some ~4 hours of playtime. I'm cool about the price tag though, the game has some replayability since you keep unlocking new lenses and ways to edit your photos. Actually, I'm fairly convinced you have to play the game twice to unlock all the tools anyway, but as of writing this review I just finished the game the first time around. Also, the game actually saves all of your photos on your PC, which is really cool but can add up to quite a bit of storage space, so keep an eye out and maybe clean up your gallery folder after each playthrough.

There's also DLC for the game, but I can't say anything about it yet since I haven't played it.

All in all, this is a pretty stylish, conscious indie-game that I can recommend to anyone that's into artsy stuff and wants to have a fun evening!

8/10 - Cops are dirty!
 
AL1

Then you should absolutely check out Umurangi Generation.

It sits among the best games of 2020, and I absolutely adore it.
It's a little short for the price, but hey, quality over quantity.

Cyberpunk photography game set in dystopian New Zealand

This game low-key taught me about photography.
Also, the aesthetics and visual/environmental storytelling are sick.

I recommend playing the game this way:
Step 1: When you arrive at a new stage, ♥♥♥♥ around taking pics of what seems cool, when you're done and it seems there's nothing else to photograph, proceed to Step 2
Step 2: Complete all objectives, even the bonus objectives. Feel free to try out new equipment in previous stages. When you're done proceed to the next stage and back to Step 1

Waimarie pai!

Évaluation publiée le 8 janvier 2022
In a low-income neighborhood stacked full of shipping containers branded as "UN Temporary Emergency Shelters", you find candle-lit memorials and graffiti murals in memory of a local girl who died defending her hometown from the first wave of Kaiju attacks. One of the memorials has a picture of her with a bird on her head. She has an annoyed look on her face, like her friend just told her to hold still for the picture. Another picture shows her fishing. She's wearing the same baseball cap in a lot of her pictures. There's a picture of her as a baby, and a picture of her in a UN pilot uniform.

After squeezing through a narrow alley and around some fences, you find a memorial installed by the city, commemorating "those lost in the first wave", no specific names given.

6.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 8 mai 2021
This unique game is set in futuristic New Zealand. I thought it was an odd setting for a game when my mum first told me about it. I soon realised how well this idea works for a game like this. The aim of the game is to take photos of different objects, angles, and people that are shown on your bounty list.

You traverse through different scenes and settings that vary drastically between levels, looking for specific things to take pictures of, all while taking in the amazing views, and getting an up-close insight into all the little details of each level. The levels aren't all innocent and pretty either, so you get to explore the nightlife, subways and other aspects that would usually be excluded when creating a game. It portrays some problems that New Zealand is facing at the moment, as well as some crazy futuristic catastrophes.

Not to mention the amazing sound track that the game uses. Some very alternate, interesting music that made the levels feel more real and immersive.

I enjoyed this game a lot more than I thought I would and it is definitely an experience that you wouldn't get from many other games.

1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation amusante
0
Recommandé
3.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 27 mai 2020
真·老法师

Umurangi Generation 摄追赤红末世代

👉前言👈

本作是由ORIGAME DIGITAL制作，ORIGAME DIGITAL, PLAYISM发行的一款第一人称的摄影游戏。玩家将扮演来自新西兰陶朗加运输公司的一名送货员，在抽象而又不失美感的世界中尽情拍摄，用摄影的魅力充实生活、感染世界。游戏的场景以及人物建模略显粗糙，但又有几分复古的意味，并且含有不少隐藏内容，休闲独特的游戏风格也可以让初学者体验一把摄影师的生活，推荐给喜欢摄影的玩家。

👉游戏体验👈

游戏的主要内容就是完成关卡规定的拍摄任务，包括拍摄特定的图片、收集胶卷、制作明信片等等内容。在关卡的地图中，玩家可以随意地拍摄，想拍什么东西都可以，不过要注意的一点就是不要拍到“蓝色的瓶子”（教程中讲到过，代表了葡萄牙战舰水母，拍到会扣钱+扣分...）玩家在进行拍摄的过程中难免也会遇到角度不对或是拍不到特定物品等诸多问题，这时候就需要利用主角的跑酷技能，在固定的场景中跳跃穿梭，在屋顶狂奔，直到找到满意的角度。

除此以外，游戏还为玩家提供了特写、中距离、远景、普通、长焦镜头、广角镜头、鱼眼镜头这几种镜头，同时还可以通过变焦、旋转镜头等操作完成拍摄，而在拍摄完成之后，玩家还可以对相片进行后期处理，利用对比度或曝光来做后期调整，让照片展现出让自己满意的风格。玩家所拍摄的每张图片都会有系统经过Colour颜色、Content内容、Composition构图的3C法进行判别打分，而系统内的打分也并不代表人们的主观感受，从拍摄中获取乐趣，提升拍摄技艺才是游戏真正的目的。

❤️优点❤️

👍 新颖的游戏模式

👍 抽象而又细节丰富的场景

👍 足够休闲的游戏氛围

💔缺点💔

👎 关卡内的提示系统欠缺

欢迎参观我的： 奸商评测 喜欢这篇评论，可顺手点个赞，让更多人方便看到。
 
结力老狗比

koeslter
8
16 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
11.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 1 décembre 2020
There's something relaxing about photography modes in video games. "Photo mode" is still a relatively new concept in games, but when done right it can absolutely shine, offering the player an opportunity to take a break from the game's larger world to focus squarely upon a small portion of it. I've spent hours in different games just taking photos, listening to the ambiance of the world and music around me as I tweaked the lighting and angling to get it just how I wanted it, before going off to find another spot to take a picture of.

Umurangi Generation might not be the pinnacle of photo modes in video games, but it hits almost all the right notes to put it in contention. The camera feels both approachable and capable even for those unfamiliar with photography, taking all time and scoring pressure off and giving the player room to experiment as they see fit. Aiding this is environmental design which maintains a great balance between intrigue and cohesion, finding new ways to keep each level fresh and engaging while maintaining a clear identity. As well, specific points of interest big and small are spread out incredibly well, never leading spaces to feel overburdened or artificial.

The specific photography objectives in each level don't fare quite as well, unfortunately, seemingly existing for the purpose of guiding the player but often becoming obstacles themselves. When a level's objectives work well, they form an interesting mix between photography and navigation puzzle, but later levels can make them so demanding as to make an interesting or even simply clean shot impossible.

But what Umurangi Generation excels at by far is tone, atmosphere, and narrative, all while rarely spelling out direct plot points. The world of Umurangi has a constant subdued bleakness to it that's hard to compare to any other game. It's a world that can best be described as defeated, the final throes of life being upon it and no options afforded to the player besides that of simply being present. This relationship between the player and the game-world leads to a special connection, with the dire state of the world and the hopeless lives of its inhabitants feeling much more tangible when the player is forced to be among them rather than saving them.

Ultimately, I can recognize that Umurangi Generation is a game that might be hard to pitch to people, considering it's a quiet, dour photography game. That's totally fine. But, it is a game with such a finely crafted world and atmosphere that I would be lying if I said I didn't want everyone to at least give it a shot, and it is certainly one of the best games of the past few years.
 
May
549 produits enregistrés

3 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation amusante

Recommandé
8.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 20 mai 2020
Lets get the few stupid complaints out of the way. Sometimes getting temporarily stuck on geometry(never actually cared). Last complaint is no dlc for more levels cause that's going to be cheaper than the new camera and photoshop i now want to buy.

This game is by far one of the best I've played in a while. For me it just feels good to play. The camera feels like a film camera. The music is 10/10. And the world and themes are inspired by all the right things. This game threw me back to my high-school photography classes that i took and then put me in an incredible world with incredible friends(idk how they have so much character as silent people and a pengu, but they do).
Each level feels unique and lived in beyond what most AAA games do. The world and story left me honestly struck by the end. I don't want to spoil anything about the world/story/themes of this game cause it's worth learning by playing, but it is surprisingly lovely and dark in perfectly balanced measure. with a honestly very moving ending at least for me.
I've already replayed a couple levels trying to get all the extra objectives done, to get more film gear(need a canister location guide for a couple levels) and even though i was racing the clock i would still be like 'wait is that a shot, can i hop over here and crouch and yeah that's IT!' wasting a full 30 seconds just trying to get the right angle.
This game isn't for everybody, but if you actually enjoy taking photo's with your phone or u always wanted to try photography, please try this game. It's beautiful the whole way through, completely unique and absolutely fun with a jaw dropping world to boot.
This review was on the game the day released btw
 
Three Stans
0
17 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
1
Recommandé
14.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 25 novembre 2021
The fact that there are people on this earth that haven't played Umurangi Generation is a crime.
This is a phenomenal achievement in terms of storytelling and gameplay. It's an extremely relevant and powerful story told with not a single line of dialogue, all you have is your buddies and a camera. Experiencing the game is in it's own right the story, you see the story you want to see which is a direction that I love in games, no overblown cutscenes or expository audio logs even though you can tell a good story with those. The game gives a list of objects to take photos of and you can be as creative as possible and it's perfect for anyone who likes photography or just art in general. There a few glitches that I experienced that hindered my enjoyment slightly; the detection on some of the objectives was really janky sometimes I would take a photo miles away from the objective and it would mark that off the checklist and sometimes I'd be right in front of it and it wouldn't count at all, sometimes I would walk into an object and get sent flying 100 metres in the air which was cool occasionally but most of the time would send me off the map and respawn me at the beginning with a 2 second time penalty, which was less cool. I'm going to get into minor spoilers for the game even though there isn't really much to spoil so if you don't want to read the rest that's fine, please play this game it is incredible and also get the Macro DLC which adds so much to the themes and sandbox.

The red sky generation is what the title translates to and essentially the game is about the denial of accountability of older generations and what people would do when they know the world is going to end and the answer is party. None of the citizens can really do anything about the war the UN has started with the alien race trying to invade and you as the protagonist can't report on anything that's actually going on so your only option is to take pretty pictures as creatively as you can but don't take photos of blue bottles. The government takes the neo-liberalist approach of never addressing the real issue and making you pay for a temporary solution.
The Macro DLC adds to this while being a much more depressing story. It pretty much uses the iconography of Neon Genesis Evangelion to explore issues in the present, it's also set in New Zealand. The culture of New Zealand is very integral to the themes and aesthetic of the game, it feels very spiritual and in-tune with it's indigenous culture while incorporating a future aesthetic, rebelling the colonialist mindset of westernisation = better and the erasure of national identity. It also uses retro technology to add to this rebellion, you use a film camera throughout the game and the music constantly uses samples from the PS1 and PS2 era (the music is incredible btw). The music seems very much inspired by Jet Set Radio which is a game all about rebellion. This is then juxtaposed with the divide between the wealthy and the poor (called surface dwellers). The wealthy are shown to have a very different style that completely ignores the cultural heritage while at the same time advertising and commodifying the style of those surface dwellers. The DLC extends it's roots in our current events by having a level where you are taking photos of a protest against the UN occupation, the game becomes truly ominous and it shows how fast the government uses it's own weapons against the people they're supposed to protect. This is even scarier when only 2 levels before you have to take photos around the weapons they were creating to be used against you.

"Painting is not done to decorate apartments. It is an instrument of war." - Picasso

This quote perfectly sets up how this game tells it's story, it's a game about making art to preserve the lives of the umurangi generation and rebel against the modernisation of the video game medium. It's a lovingly crafted artwork that takes advantage of it's medium to let the player express themselves while also making them witness the oppression of culture and the manipulation by our governments not to protect us but to suppress us. This game deserves to be spoken in the same breath as classics like Silent Hill 2, LISA the Painful, Fallout New Vegas and Shadow of the Colossus.
10/10 play it now. Right now. DO IT.
 
FunnySnake

15.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 10 novembre 2020
Stage 1: Yo, this is chill. I love the lo-fi Y2K aesthetics.

Stage 2: The clever usage of positioning yourself to get the objectives in shot has caught me by surprise and efectively merges both free-roaming chill creative photography and subtle positioning puzzle elements resulting in... wait, am I in a war zone?

Stage 3: Getting all the upgrades and film canisters makes the player pay attention to its surroundings in ways I couldn't have imagined. I'm kinda blown away with how the game makes me fall in love with its stage and environmental design while being almost minimalistic.

Stage 5: WAIT, WHAT IS HAPPENING

Stage 6: DAMN

Stage 8: HOLY MOTHER OF

Final Stage: TUMBLING DOWN TUMBLING DOWN TUMBLING DOWN

-------------------------

This is my review. I won't say anything else because I don't want to spoil the game for you. Umurangi Generation is a landmark title in the photography videogame genre and one of the best experiences I had this year. If you see the trailer and think to yourself "yea, I would vibe with this" then get this ASAP.
 
Chato Maltés
0
13 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation amusante
0
Recommandé
4.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 5 juin 2021
Pokemon Snap by way of Jet Set Radio. Don't buy it without the Macro DLC.

Umurangi Generation is dripping with aesthetic, style, and heart. It celebrates street culture and doesn't shy away from making a statement.

You play as a photo journalist(?) who documents different angles of a very turbulent time. You're scored based on your photographs, but honestly, you can ignore the scoring aspect.

The base game feels significantly kneecapped by the slow moving speed - the Macro DLC fixes this by giving you roller blades, a can of spray paint, and more in-depth settings to tweak your photos. The DLC improves the game so much I can honestly say I wouldn't recommend the game without it.

I 100%'d this game in less than five hours with fairly heavy use of guides, for the sake of expediency and my own patience.

YMMV but I recommend it.
 
constantcompile
1,543 produits enregistrés
0
8 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
7.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 31 octobre 2021
3Dオブシェクト探しに高機能なフォトモードが付いたようなゲーム。
なぜ写真を撮るゲームと言わないかというと写真の芸術性はミッション達成に全く関係ないためだ。
たとえ完全に対象がぼけて見えなくても問題ない。
要求されたタイプのレンズを使いフレームにオブジェクトが入っていさえすればクリア判定になるのだ。
結果としてこのゲームは小さめのステージを走り回ってオブジェクトを探し回るのがメインになる。
恐らく自由に写真を撮るのはクリアして各種レンズなどの装備を集めてからになるだろう。

このため私のような写真を撮ることにあまり興味のない人間でも楽しめた。
オブジェクトを探している最中に目に入るポスターや落書きなどからだんだん主人公たちの置かれている状況が伝わってくるのが面白い。
細かい状況は会話で語られるのではなく全てプレイヤーが見えている世界から自発的にくみ取る作りになっているのだ。
このような作りなので私はこの世界のモブの一人として人類が滅亡しようとしている状況で写真を撮る事しかできない無力さややるせなさを味わえた。
ポストアポカリプスものは他にも沢山あるが現在進行形で滅亡していくゲームは数少ないのでもっと増えてほしいと思う。

結論としてはオープンワールドのフォトモードで時間をゴミにしてしまうような人に加え、このゲームの人類の黄昏な雰囲気に惹かれた人なら誰にでもお勧め。
オブシェクト探しの部分は普通に楽しいので写真を撮るのに興味が無くてもそれほど問題ない。
主人公が何もできずに人類滅亡していくのを見届けるお話が好みの人にもお勧め。


カツオノエボシが印象的な登場をするので気になって調べてみたのだが、ニュージーランドというかオーストラリアの南部あたりの浜辺ではよくこのクラゲが浜辺に打ち上げられるのだそうだ。
このクラゲは死んで浜辺に打ち上げられると乾いて青いペットボトルのようになるのだが、この状態でもうかつに触れると刺胞という微小な毒針が射出されて大怪我を負わされることになる。
この傷跡はひどい場合は一生消えないこともあるそうで、ゲーム中にもこの傷跡とみられる赤い斑点がある登場人物が確認できる。
オーストラリアだと毎年一万人以上が刺されているとか。
まさに邪悪な侵略生物兵器のような生き物だ。
開発者はニュージーランドの方だそうだがこのゲームからはカツオノエボシへの憎悪と恐怖を強く感じられた。
日本でも本州の太平洋湾岸で打ち上げられることがあるそうなので絶対に触らないようにしよう。
大量に漂着している場合などは水産関係のお役所に連絡すると対処してくれるらしいぞ。
 
penta0

2
Recommandé
14.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 23 février 2022
这可能是味道最正的赛博朋克游戏，特别是从那AKIRA式的原教旨日式赛博朋克的味道上来说。整个游戏只有短短几幕的长度，箱庭式的关卡仅仅从世界观中截取了几个近乎静止的空间片段，但从细节里对背景，角色还有剧情的刻画的感染力却一点也没有妥协，如精致的情景模型一般栩栩如生。游戏中刻意营造的low-poly/low-res/lo-fi的美术风格也是直击要害，堪称点睛之笔。

其实希望更多的游戏创作者能采用速写和白描的手法，或者至少能理解留白的重要性。当然，这种手法需要深层次的理解和思辨，其困难程度比全频段堆料之类的“捷径”高出不知多少。无法量化成方法论也意味着无法在工业化生产中批量复制。在更本质的的层面上，还有类似绘画vs摄影，有限动画vs真人电影的艺术形态高下之辩，不能强求。

当然，obligatory地还是要点名黑屁某赛博朋克钜作，赛博朋克的精髓并不是（不是的，对吧。）彩虹发色阴阳头或霓虹灯日文招牌gay吧或电子仿生小鸡鸡。

4.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 19 septembre 2021
A brief and buggy experience with half-finished mechanics and yet it's also one of the best games of its year.

Eight small-ish sandboxes with hidden objects to find and snap stylish (or not-so stylish) photos of. It's not the most riveting setup, but then, there's also a war going on, and victims and soldiers increasingly fill each area as the game progresses.

If you're trying out Umurangi Generation, chances are you'll lose yourself in its world.

Oh, and the soundtrack is worth picking up, too.

And the DLC -- which is even better.
 
tootstorm
2,802 produits enregistrés
0
10 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
6.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 18 avril 2022
In this game, explore a stylish, edgy world where you slowly realize that everything has gone wrong.

Your only goal is to take photos of certain things like "7 birds" or "a shotgun, a pistol, and a rifle". Fill the list, and you can move on to the next level. While hunting for the correct angles to grab these photos, you take in more and more of the messed-up world and gradually figure out what's really going on.

In one level, a discarded newspaper reports that the prime minister is on vacation while alien invaders are at the nation's doorstep. The wall next to it is plastered with army recruitment posters, advertisements, and propaganda informing you that yes, we're winning the war.

That's not to say that this is a downer of a game. For all the cynicism and despair evident in the world, there runs a theme of youthful rebellion and even hope and a call to action, because sometimes in the end all you get is one shot. Let your camera be your lens.

Simply put, a collectathon should not have lore this good. Make sure to get the DLC as well.
 
masuat
0
53 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
2
Non recommandé
1.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 4 juillet 2021
Bought the game after the interview with the developer on the Dads and Sons podcast. It's not bad, but it feels very raw. And I don't mean "raw" in an artistic sense... Or rather maybe not only in that sense.

It feels like a playable proof of concept, not a finished game. Proof of a neat context, but still. UX (settings menu for example is clunky), onboarding (tutorial is very limited and text-only) and the gameplay loop (no real incentive to take cool pictures instead of just rushing through the objectives) all feel like they could use some work. The internal logic of the world is also a bit unclear - like, from what I've seen, you live in a totalitarian dystopia but yet you can walk anywhere you want and photograph anything you want with the only penalty being getting smaller paycheck.

I don't regret paying for the game, supporting a cool developer who clearly cares and hopefully will make better games in the future, but I can't really recommend it as a product. Maybe wait for a discount or something if you want something quirky but feeling a bit amateurish.

On an upside, the art direction is very consistent, music is good, some of the locations are really pretty (some are also dull and lifeless though) and I like the story as a concept.
 
dziki

Non recommandé
1.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 6 juillet 2020
I like everything about the idea of Umurangi Generation, but I think they failed in the execution. I love the stylized PS1 graphics, but the game runs poorly despite how simple its visuals are. I love the idea of being incentivized to really explore a level and take pictures of the objectives, but exploring the world isn't fun when getting around feels so awkward, when the objectives are unclear, and when the bonus objectives you clear don't seem to even count towards anything. The soundtrack is great, but every time a song finishes, there's a massive stutter to load in the next song. It's clear the developers had a great vision, but just don't have enough experience making games. I'd love to play a polished version of this game.

Évaluation publiée le 29 octobre 2021
It's a nice walking simulator with a little photography game attached. The photography is fun, you get little challenges to find certain shots, and you can mess with the ISO, f/stop, aperture, and whatever else you'd want.

The game really shines with it's universe. It's a cool Maori cyberpunk kaiju vibe that's got a political message in the way most games are too timid to attempt.

It's not perfect but this is the kind of art video games needs more of.

Évaluation publiée le 8 septembre 2023
It may be pretentious, but ignore the time limit, get absorbed, and focus in on what speaks to you in the game. Umurangi Generation is the story you tell through your photographs. The game really enables the player to become a photographer at every level that matters, so develop your own style and make some kickass art. I wound up making a quick photo book based on my experience, and it was one of my most thoughtful experiences I've had in gaming. I think the meta narrative of my interpretation of the developer's world through that book is such a neat concept too. Highly recommend.

12 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
9.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 30 juin 2021
What little there is is not polished enough to be worth the price of admission. For the devs I have so many questions:

Why is movement so awful?

Moving around is one of two things you do in game and it feels like complete ass. It's excruciatingly slow, sometimes you clip through stuff that looks walkable, sometimes you clip through stuff upwards. Sometimes you can't jump even though it seems like you're standing on something. Sometimes you'll slide off stuff, other times you'll stick to it. Apparently if you buy the DLC there's some kind of sprint. Again. w h y ?

Why do so many objectives require you to stumble across a particular thing in a level?

This isn't a problem on the small levels but trying to find that one last thing you're missing on the larger levels feels like a chore

Why is the level's exit never in a consistent or predictable place?

Sometimes it's near where you started, other it's just somewhere arbitrary. This wouldn't be a problem if you could see it while playing the level, but it only shows up once all the primary objectives are complete.

Why are the secondary objectives so painful?

Looking for tiny black cylinders hidden in a large level ON A TIME LIMIT isn't fun. On the note of film canisters why do they never increase the amount of film you have beyond 24? This isn't just annoying, it's counter-intuitive to anyone that actually knows how a film camera works.

Why is all the UX so bad?

This is a Unity game. Unity has prefabs for all sorts of UI elements but rather than choosing my resolution through a dropdown I HAVE TO KEEP CLICKING IT UNTIL IT BECOMES THE ONE I WANT. THERE ISN'T EVEN A SEPARATE CHECKBOX FOR WINDOWED MODE. IT'S JUST THROWN IN WITH RESOLUTION. Why can't I use my scroll wheel for the level select? Why can't the game remember what language I speak? Why am I told what I unlocked for completing a level if I already finished the level and unlocked that item? Why am I booted back to the start screen if I want to choose a level after completing another? Why can I not restart a level instantly? Why do I have to press a key on my keyboard and not use my mouse to go through the start screen? Why can't I bind actions to my mouse? Why do I rebind keys my click+hold+release and not just click? I wouldn't waste my virtual breath on this if it were just a few things but it get so much so horribly, horribly wrong.

Why does the game look awful?

I don't mean stylistically. It's like there's some kind of post-processing effect that makes anything rendered further away than about 2 metres look like it's being rendered at a much lower resolution than it really is, and then upscaled. Or it might just be really aggressive lowering of texture resolution at distance. It's extremely similar to looking through a first gen VR headset. This goes away when looking through the viewfinder of your camera, which makes me think it's some kind of artistic decision about how we see pictures as being more real than reality. But I hate it. Just playing the game makes me feel like I need glasses.

Why?

In the era of post-launch support many of these issues should have been smoothed over months ago.
 
springheeled's giftshop

225 produits enregistrés

7 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile

Recommandé
5.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 14 aout 2022
I bought this game knowing nothing more about it other than you can take photographs and that I loved the art direction it has.

Umurangi Generation portrays a bleak dystopian sci-fi future through the lens of a young courier working for the Tauranga Express. You’re given a list of things to photograph each level but you’re free to take as many pictures as you like and as someone who has a casual interest in photography I really enjoy this part of the game!

There is a time limit set for each level to deliver your package however you can ignore this as it’s only for a bonus. I definitely don’t recommend rushing through things on your first playthrough.

The environmental storytelling in this game is expertly crafted and is worth experiencing for yourself firsthand. I’d also recommend buying this along with its Macro DLC as that provides extra levels that expand on the game’s themes.

A refreshingly angry and passionate game with heavy social commentary. It’s worth sticking around until the final shot.
 
Raloire

9 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
1
Recommandé
4.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 2 janvier 2021
Evangelion but from the point of view of a photographer and with the aesthetics and game design of a PS1 game. Jet set radio and pokemon snap had this as its child. i struggle to think of anything eles that's even similar.

You take photos, you have list of things to take pictures of, a list of bonus tasks to complete and a timer for said bonus tasks, that whilst does not stop progress i did think it took away from the experience first time round as i felt rushed trying to find the tasks in places i don't know and sometimes times wasn't fully sure what it was wanting. Now the timer dose fit its ps1 style aesthetic, but still dint enjoy that part.

Each level is relatively bite sized, yet dense enough in design and style. Really great soundtrack. Fairly short overall but some replay due to timers and various tasks for unlocks. Really cool story telling with its levels.

I would wonder what someone who hasn't seen (or enjoyed) EVA takes away from it thou, but as a fan of that and similar shows that have stuff straight lifted from for this, i thought it was really cool. The DLC feels like it looking in a different direction too look at story-wise, that i'm not fully sure is as strong as the base game but still enjoyed.

Really cool.

 
defult
2,369 produits enregistrés
0
4 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
3.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 14 octobre 2023
As a game by itself, this isn't anything crazy. Basic environmental exploration through the goal of taking pictures. The movement is kinda janky, I've clipped through a impressive amount of walls and floors just by brushing up against them, randomly being launched like 20 ft in the air eventually just became a movement method, the deliverables could use some greater elaboration at times, and I cry a little inside anytime I see I need to use the telegraph lens.
And yet, I think I completely adore this game.
The use of environmental storytelling is incredible. Despite the low-poly graphics, the environments are interesting and impactful and a pleasure to explore. The additional of all the different lens and the different edits you can add onto your pictures are cute details encouraging the player to have fun, take cool pictures, and fully take in the environment outside of just the obligatory items.
But of course, I have to mention the emotional impact of the story, as I'd argue that is the main selling point of this game. This game is raw with frustration and rage and fear and grief, and it makes it incredibly clear. Both the big and little moments still buzz around in my mind sometimes. So many times I'd stop right in my tracks to absorb a scene. In my opinion, the storytelling alone makes up for all the gameplay jank.
I'd also like to mention that the story line is so much better with the DLC, so if you're interested in fully experiencing the game, I highly recommend just getting the DLC and playing them back to back. The DLC also seemed to have less glitches, in my experience.
Also OST goes hard.

hat wobble
0
9 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
2.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 30 mai 2020
Video game photography has seen huge growth in recent times. You'd be hard pressed not to find a photo mode in most of your favorite AAA titles of the past few years, but those modes are complimentary side content at best. Despite their inclusion, there aren't a lot of games that allow you to actually be a photographer in the truest sense of the word.

Believe it or not, photography is much more than just taking a picture. The picture is the result of scouting out a great shot, getting uncomfortably close or uncomfortably high up, fiddling with an ultra-precise tool to get just the angle you want, and tweaking minutia in post. Photography isn't just a skill; it's a process.

It's certainly possible to take some great photos using in-game photo modes, but floating around as a ghostly camera just doesn't have the same challenges as being a corporeal photographer. Umurangi Generation fits that niche perfectly. It's a first person shooter, but you won't be shooting bullets; you'll be shooting landscapes, portraits, and close-ups.

Set in a post-apocalyptic New Zealand facing a Kaiju invasion and UN occupation, Umurangi Generation puts you in the shoes of a photo courier with an old-school camera. Umurangi Generation sports neon cyberpunk city streets, vast skylines, and dingy UN checkpoints coated in graffiti. This makes for a ton of good source material to have fun photographing.

The game will present you with objectives like "get a close up of the word Squid" or "get a wide shot of 2 coffee cups" and it's up to you to figure out how to put the shot together with various lenses and post-processing sliders. For lack of a better word, the "hit detection" for when you are doing picture objectives can be a bit shoddy. It works about 7 times out of 10, which is far too low for a game that tasks you with taking pictures.

On top of this, some of the objectives are outright sadistic. I spent 20 minutes looking for the letters "RTD" which ended up being on the side of a random car. One objective I got stuck on involved taking a longshot photograph of 5 american flags. It left me flabbergasted for a while, and I couldn't even take the picture when I found the angle because I had gone over the photo limit. The photo limit is a crucial misstep in my opinion, one that punishes players who just want to take cool photos (which is kinda the whole game).

The game's biggest flaw is that it has tons of untapped potential. Being a photographer can often be uncomfortable, awkward, and even dangerous. The environments are very static, and people never react to anything you do. I think a crucial part of photography is the interaction the photographer has with the subject; that potential is squandered here.

The player is also given money per photo based on color, content, and composition. This encourages the player to follow the fundamentals of photography, but this whole system seems contradictory to the game's ideals. In the tutorial, it is stated that photography is subjective, yet they've implemented an objective scoring system of sorts. It might be there to push players into learning the fundamentals. If that's the case, it's nowhere near consistent; my favorite photos were frequently worthless.

And that just might be the point.

It's hard not to see how Umurangi Generation holds a mirror (or rather a camera) up to our own world. Your favorite photos might not be worth anything to your payroll. Walls defiled by graffiti and propaganda posters also advertise post apocalyptic sci-fi movies and gaming bars. People dance to the beat of bizarre indie music not 50 feet away from the wreckage of a giant robot. While it's not subtle in its discussion of occupation, existentialism, and escapism, Umurangi Generation conveys its message through mostly wordless storytelling.

Is Umurangi Generation the most amazingly fantastic indie hit I've ever played? No, but it taps into something I didn't know I wanted: fully realized videogame photography in an interesting world. It makes for great photography practice, and even stores the photos on your PC.

Umurangi Generation is weird, flawed, and great. If you haven't given videogame photography a try, then you probably should. If that's something you already enjoy, Umurangi Generation is a bite-sized cyberpunk photo trip that's absolutely worth its price tag.
 
nawt
0
6 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
10.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 16 mai 2023
「Haere rā」
世界が刻一刻と終わりに近づいていく中で、
ファインダー越しに退廃していく風景をフィルムに収めていく。
ローポリ１人称視点の終末系撮影ゲーム。

「フォトバウンティー」と呼ばれる対象の撮影が目的であり、
「７羽の鳥」や「５つの星条旗」など、ステージごとに指定された
被写体をフィルムに収めることで物語が進行していく。

写真というテーマに重きを置いた作品であり、
物語において登場人物たちの会話やセリフなどは一切存在しない。
ただ目の前に広がる風景を切り取りながら、世界観を考察し、
世界の行く末を見届けていく。

なお、”青いペットボトル”は絶対に写真に含めてはいけない
被写体なので要注意。その理由は……。

▶ 良い点
・ISO感度やシャッタースピード、絞り値などカメラに凝っている
・撮影技法などカメラの仕組みに興味が湧く
・サイバー、パンク、ロック、ジェノサイドな世界観

▶ 悪い点
・被写体の指定など、ノルマ的な要素があり自由度が低い
・FPS酔いしやすい人は要注意
・世界観およびゲームシステムの説明が不足気味

▶ 注意点
実績「スピードラン」を解放できないバグがあります。
どうしても解決しない場合は、旧バージョンにダウングレード
してください。（詳しくはコミュニティハブのガイドを参照）
※DLCやクリア後の追加モードは解放条件に関係ありません。

▶ 総括総評
結論から言うとパズルに近い要素が多めです。
例えば、「５つの星条旗」を撮影するというタスクでは、
壁に飾ってある星条旗、お子様ランチの旗、お姉さんのパンツの
柄（星条旗）などを同時にフレームに収める必要があり、
どの角度から撮影すれば良いのだろう…と試行錯誤するのが大変でした。

被写体を指定しないとゲームが成立しないのかもしれませんが、
個人的には、特に目的もなくブラブラと気に入った風景を
撮影したかったので、ちょっとこれじゃない感が強かったです。
「ウォーリーをさがせ」のような探索ゲームである。
という例を引き合いに出した方のレビューが秀逸でした。

気になった点は、なぜ世界が”こうなってしまったのか”
という状況を把握するための情報量が少ないため、
EDを迎えても、釈然としないモヤモヤが残りました。
プレイヤーに想像の余地を残すタイプの作品といえば
聞こえは良いのですが、悪く言えば雰囲気ゲーです。

Lo-FiなBGMに鬼ポップで激キャッチーなサブカル系激推し
雰囲気が漂う尖った作品なので、好き嫌いが分かれそうですが、
やり込んでいくと撮影技法が充実し、撮影の自由度が増していく
スルメゲー的な側面もあるため、”写真を撮る”のではなく、
“カメラをいじる”ことが好きな人にはオススメできます。
仲間たちとの他愛もない日常を淡々と描きながらも、
退廃的で不穏な雰囲気を常に漂わせる作風は一見の価値有り。
 
kamᗩboko
