0
26 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
3 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation amusante
0
Non recommandé
9.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 23 mai 2020
Photography is good on the whole, but the gamification around it is frustrating at best and downright awful at worst. Main deliverables that are listed are a mix of interesting problem solving, say you need to frame a series of signs just right to spell out a word or series of numbers, and just a list of 'three chickens and a milk bottle'. Not perfect but tolerable most of the time, if stifling for being really creative in a lot of cases.

Then you get to bonuses. Pixel hunt tiny film canisters tossed carelessly around the level. Rack up a hundred dollars worth of points by just shooting film into the sky until enough money has been earnt. Run the level three times to figure out how to take the photos, where the film canisters all are, and then getting all that done inside 10 minutes. NEVER were these bonus objectives fun to do. I get the argument that you can skip them, but bonus objectives are meant to be a fun extra tough challenge not just outright annoying and a constant chore to complete. Putting extra unlocks behind them also makes it 'incomplete' to finish without doing these bonuses, pushing you to beat your face against it to really beat a level.

The world is very interesting, and the set-up is too. But then everything is just left to hang in the wind and atrophy. Who are you? You have mates, who are they? Why, through asking them to pose which is the only way you can interact with them, do they seem to ricochet widely between the huge swings the story and level progression take? I can understand you four, being average people, have no ideas of the bigger things in play. That all is mysterious too, but stands out far less than the fact you are friends with a penguin and that seems normal. Is the penguin magic? An alien? Just a penguin? Did you steal a penguin?

Only so much is shown through the levels themselves, the narrative wordlessly transitioning from place to place and progressing the main story of the world, and through newspapers and such decorating various levels. You cannot interact with anything at all. if not for the hands you can see holding the camera you could very well have just been a floating ghost camera taking photos without any change in the game at all.

With just a bit more work to make the world feel actually alive and not like a clockwork diorama, with the gameplay refined to be fun and meaningful, this could have been a real solid game. But lacking that, progression is an awful trial and the story does not give you enough to be worth the effort you need to put in. And since you need to go through all that to unlock everything and just have a cyberpunk free roam camera game? Not worth it.
 
Un développeur ou une développeuse a répondu à cette évaluation
Robodog_SA

Recommandé
5.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 31 janvier 2023
Killer soundtrack, tasty visuals, inspiring worldbuilding and straight-up impressive environmental storytelling.

However, the gameplay didn't click for me. On one hand it wants you to pay attention to every nook and cranny, absorb the environment, and understand it. On the other hand, it wants you to do it as fast as possible. Obviously, the solution is to pass through every level twice - the first time to do reconnaissance, and the second time to 360 noscope everything. I get it. But why!? I fail to see how this contributes to what the game is trying to say. It feels to me like the developer heard some feedback that the game was "too boring" and then decided to add this time limit to spice things up. In the end, I think it only serves to pollute what is at its core an already marvelous game.

All things considered... this is a good, although confused, game.
 
moonsweater

It's the kind of game that gets better the more time you invest into it. First you'll stumble through all the objectives, until you decide to revisit each area and start to absorb all of its' weird and unique beauty. If you have any interest in photography, this might just spark that bit of curiosity needed to try some other lenses or perspectives as well!

Magic
389 produits enregistrés
0
5 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
1
Recommandé
4.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 22 janvier 2023
Umurangi Generation is greater than the sum of its parts, and some of those parts are NOT great by any means.

The sounds aren't cohesive, the movement is frustrating, the controls unintuitive and messy. The Tony Hawks mission structure clashes with the multitude of photography mechanics, to a baffling degree - you are encouraged to gamer-goblin every objective in every map as fast as possible, so you unlock more interesting options for your creative photography endeavors. This would be fine, its often fun even, but forcing you to collect tiny collectibles in huge levels AND forcing you to do every single photo goal instead of letting you choose one or two to neglect is a huge oversight. You WILL get stuck searching for one tiny film box or that one motif, often hidden in graffitis that melt together with the blast of colors in every corner of every level.

I could go into detail on a lot more stuff ( events never happening after level 1, broken achievement, grading ), but you get the idea. There is hardly anything not flawed about this game.

But the overall experience is so damn interesting. The world is both depressing and exciting, the atmosphere is thick and oppressive while the vibe you get is strangely liberating. The game never alternates between pessimism and optimism, it radiates both simultaneously. The levels aren't all well designed, but they are all a delight to look at and explore. And once you actually get to ignore the missions and just relax to snap pics for the intrinsic value alone, Umurangi Generation really shines.

Special shout-out to the OST by Adolf Nomura / ThorHighHeels. 60% of the songs are phenomenal, 20% are weird and 20% are ear-grating; I think every player will put different songs into those percents, but it's hard to imagine the soundtrack could be lost on anyone.
 
Peringo
375 produits enregistrés
0
6 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation amusante
1
Recommandé
8.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 18 juillet 2021
很有特色的第一人稱攝影遊戲

玩法
本作大概有12個關卡，每個關卡是一個大小不等的區域地圖，玩家會被給予一些攝影課題，比如用一張照片拍到含有5隻鳥、用長焦鏡拍到含有某某文字的照片等等，時限內完成所有課題就能解鎖更多鏡頭和攝影裝備。

劇情
本作幾乎沒有文字上的劇情，只有一開始的教學會告誡玩家不要拍到某種物體，之後的劇情完全靠場景美術來敘述。主軸如同遊戲名稱(赤紅世代)，主角身處一個正在目睹人類毀滅的世代，他透過鏡頭記錄這段時間裡民眾的生活和政府的所作所為。如果是香港或台灣的玩家，可能會對本作的劇情有些共鳴也說不定，尤其是前者。

攝影
我剛好也是有在玩攝影的新手，可以說這款幾乎囊括所有新手會接觸的東西：長中短焦的鏡頭、魚眼廣角和微距鏡頭、閃光燈、ISO、快門、光圈，以及拍完照之後的修圖....在本作都有機會操作，只是要逐步解鎖就是了。

音樂
本作的一個大亮點，本體+DLC有130多首電子音樂可以聽，雖然不太清楚那樣的電音是哪一個派別，但都跟關卡的氛圍很搭
Vidéo YouTube™: Shoegaze Protagonist 
Vues : 5,191
Provided to YouTube by Ditto Music Shoegaze Protagonist · Adolf Nomura Umurangi Generation Official Soundtrack ℗ Adolf Nomura Released on: 2020-08-01 Auto-generated by YouTube.


結論
我會開始玩攝影是因為想要捕捉一些生活中值得紀念或是不尋常的時刻，本作的劇情正好是設定在一個混亂不堪的時機點，遊戲關卡中有許多見微知著的巧思來暗示NPC們的苦悶，搭配些許Cyberpunk風的場景，讓我快門按個不停啊!!

本作可以讓攝影玩家體驗不必在意別人眼光到處亂拍的快感，或許也能讓單純喜歡末日設定的玩家體驗攝影的樂趣，推薦給喜歡新奇遊戲的玩家。

p.s.建議與DLC一同入手，DLC有前日談的部分，非常超值。
 
Limsa Lominsa

Have you ever wondered what it would feel like to be a background character in Evangelion? Well this is basically that game. 0
Non recommandé
10.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 3 janvier 2021
I came to Umurangi Generation via the rave reviews in the gaming press... most of which gave the impression that it's a thoughtful (and politically charged) narrative, hidden behind a chill photography composition game.

What they didn't mention is the time limit on each level - which completely destroys any "chill" feels from the game, and prevents you from feeling like you can actually truly play with each setting - and the floaty, imprecise controls for traversal (which wouldn't be as much of a problem, if it wasn't for... yes, that time limit).

So, I can't recommend this game with these two massive caveats on its core gameplay.

Fotoğraf makinenizle çok sayıda fotoğraflar çekebileceğiniz bu oyunda; etrafa göz gezdirin, doğru açıları bulmaya çalışın ve deklanşöre basın. Évaluation publiée le 26 juin 2021
I'm on the fence for this one, but I'm leaning in the positive. It's got a nice aesthetic, and to see the story unfolding in the background as you're going about your job is a neat touch. However, some of the photo missions are more difficult to complete than expected, and the controls can be a bit unresponsive, not to mention that collision detection in this game will hinder much of your movement if you're really trying to explore the levels.

These issues hampered my enjoyment of the game, but I want to see more from the developers, especially if they improve in the future.

Évaluation publiée le 3 juillet 2020
This game is fantastic. Sure, you could treat it like Tony Hawk and get the specific pictures in a specific amount of time in the most efficient way... or you can explore the world built in the level's vignettes and encapsulate moods and emotions even the developer didn't know were present.

You take pictures of cool stuff, use the lens you want and edit it to your liking before sharing to Twitter. That's it.

I guess there's some excellent social commentary on the current quarantine and dope music too. If you like music.

Évaluation publiée le 15 octobre 2021
Umurangi Generation is the most innovative shooter I've played in years. Your photos don't matter. They're for you and who you show them to. The sky might be red, but you have the HSV controls.

With excellent and constantly surprising visuals, a killer OST with over a hundred tracks (including Macro, which IMO is an integral part of the experience), and unbridled creativity, this is a game everyone should own. Period.

Recommandé
8.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 28 mai 2020
It is a short and sweet game, oozing with a unique kinda style.
Your job is to complete certain shots in each stage, how you accomplish that is completely up to you. The further you progress the more lenses and filter options you unlock, giving you another good reason to go back to earlier stages and see what you can do now.
Also gives you another chance to discover more about the world and soak in more of the aesthetic while some great beats penetrate your eardrums.
It is a bite-sized experience that just gets better and better with every run.
 
Tarrende
291 produits enregistrés
0
4 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
1
Recommandé
11.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 5 février 2022
A photography focused game that tasks you with taking pictures of various things around the different locations in the city. There's plenty of other things to see in each location however and you're free to take as many pictures as your film will allow. You'll also get more ways to play around with the photography as you progress if you're into that sort of thing. The game has basically no dialogue or exposition, so looking around the different areas is how you'll find out about what's going on. You'll also get to appreciate the game's brand of somewhat dark humour. The simplistic artstyle is pretty endearing and you get to listen to a nice, chill soundtrack while you take your photoes. Overall I recommend it to anyone who wants to take it easy and take in the sights.
 
RedKnight
432 produits enregistrés
0
4 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
2.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 20 mai 2022
The game has potential but it's too picky when it comes to qualifiers. I spent more than an hour trying to photograph ten solar panels from God only knows how many vantage points. There were ten solar panels in the photograph on numerous occasions but none of them counted because I didn't have the EXACT angle the developers were looking for. I watched a walk-through and the host had a hard time too but finally got it. But in the photo, two of the solar panels were barely showing...it's like, how could that possibly count?? Lol. I will say the soundtrack is good and the controls seem to work fine. It's a good idea, overall, and I could see how people would like this. But I can tell already, I'm not going to have the patience required in order to play this. If you take a chance on this, be prepared to consult how-to guides, etc. It might be up your alley but it requires a lot of fiddling around.
 
seneca3191
0
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
1.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 23 mai 2020
This really is like Pokemon Snap meets Jet Set Radio in post-apocalyptic Aotearoa / New Zealand setting... very fresh.

I think my only complaint is the first person controller here, which doesn't seem to detect grounded states very well -- so sometimes it won't let you jump even though you feel like it should. You can secretly DOUBLE JUMP but the game doesn't tutorialize this... except in the input options menu? Last pro-tip: make sure you look at the tutorial screen for a minute or two, so you understand what the photo scoring system is about.

But other than those nitpicks, this is a great and expressive photo hunt game, in a very fresh setting, so well done Veselekov!!

Évaluation publiée le 23 novembre 2021
If you just want a game about Photography, then it provides a good baseline for it. If you also want your games to criticize the world that is our capitalist neoliberal hellscape through the lens of a photography game set in the near future, then this is that in spades.
 
GalacticPig
0
3 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
52.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 8 aout 2021
Symulator chodzenia, w którym wszystko co robisz - to zdjęcia. Nie ma dialogów, nie ma przerywników. Do czytania co najwyżej graffiti, plakaty czy nagłówki gazet.

Więc robimy te zdjęcia, a to co dzieje się w każdej lokacji i rozsypane po nich detale budują nam obraz tego co się dzieje. A dzieje się apokalipsa. Nie zdradzę jakiego rodzaju. Wszystko to rozgrywa się w Nowej Zelandii, w futurystycznej Taurandze i okolicach. Wszystko to jest silnie inspirowane cyberpunkiem i japońską popkulturą.

Umurangi ma opinie i nie waha się ich wykrzyczeć. I nie jest w tym subtelne. To lewicowe opinie. Zostaliście ostrzeżeni.
Zwłaszcza DLC, Macro, potrafi naprawdę mocno rezonować w obecnych czasach (piszę te słowa w 2021, po Black Lives Matter, po demonstracjach Strajku Kobiet).

Lokacje są otwarte i stosunkowo niewielkie, grafika mocno wystylizowana (kojarzy się trochę z Jet Set Radio). Sterowanie potrafi być nieco toporne, niestety. Interfejs też mógłby być lepszy. Progres wymaga robienia zdjęć określonych rzeczy, czasem można mieć wątpliwości czego gra oczekuje (zwykle można zadania wykonać na kilka sposobów). Odblokowanie wszystkiego (filtrów, obiektywów) wymaga robienia rzeczy na czas, nie jestem fanem. Nie jest to jednak potrzebne, by całość ukończyć.

Nie mogę powiedzieć, by wyrwało mnie z butów. Ale działa nieźle. I zostaje w pamięci. A to już coś, prawda?



 
Guregori

不能说好不好 只能说如果这是你能接受的风格 那于你而言这绝对是好游戏

Recommandé
9.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 20 mai 2020
Produit reçu gratuitement

首先感谢小姐姐送的key~ o(*￣▽￣*)ブ
总评：8分
画面：8分
音乐：8分
视角：7分
创意：9分
关卡设计：9分

非常有创意的一款摄影类游戏，游戏的建模不是很精细导致在找东西的时候感觉有点晕，视角切换不是很流畅。
场景的搭建很棒。一些街头细节还原的很好，还有不少彩蛋，（就是人脸有点抽象）。场景里有大量的【群友（鸽子精）】找准角度拍摄可以拿到高分~
音乐还不错就是有点重复，游戏的关卡设计真的有趣，然而我并没有成功在时限里完成送货嘤嘤嘤
价格方面还口以，推荐摄影爱好者入手，里面的一些镜头的调整我有点不太懂 OTZ 希望作者能给一个教程~

 
雪狐眸月
574 produits enregistrés
0
4 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
0.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 21 décembre 2022
手感不够顺溜
但足够酷
游戏做的比较自由——我是指创作上那种自由
场景也比较随性，天马行空——不是按照严格的合理性来的
角色很好看，时空感很特殊

平时就爱截图的人玩拍照游戏还是过瘾的

找单词的任务可难死我了——找“Mix”找得难受了，下一关还有这种题 ——啊

属于表面糙但是里面还是做了不少东西的
对个人作品有一定启发性

暂时还不知道这个游戏之前为啥能获大奖
可能就是因为这种随和？

另外会又让我琢磨任务列表这东西的事情
希望自由的游戏有时候往往还都会有，或者做的时候也会想 “要么还是安排一下吧？”

玩的角度来看，感觉也确实是有了具体的目标后，才容易有切实的进度感？
做的角度来说，可能也才有构建了具体的结构（建起了基本的循环）的感觉？

然而一旦遇到比较麻烦的条件，则又会极大的限制，甚至直接冲解掉本就细微的自由感觉啊
这时候可能需要探索与发现的周边结构来化解？

条件本身的设置程度和弹性必然也是这中间的艺术所在....
麻烦呢
 
Anto:-.

3 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
6.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 21 décembre 2020
The way this game gets the player into the story is really neat. You're given just enough guidance and information to start each level, but the bounties for the level force you to pay such close attention to the environment that you start to pick up on details you're not even required to take a picture of. It's simple, but highly effective.

I can't say I'd recommend this game to everyone... but if I thought everyone would get what makes this game so good, then I would.

Évaluation publiée le 19 décembre 2020
축!!! 22년 5월 30일 패치로 한국어추가됨!!!!!야호~!!!!!!!!!


사진찍는겜
각 스테이지별로 어떤 것을 찍으라는 목표와 보너스 목표가 있고
목표를 달성하면 새로운 렌즈나 부가기능(플래시 등)이 해금되는 방식임
심심하게 들리긴 하는데 트레일러 분위기 보고 분위기 좋은데 재밌겠다 싶으면 바로 사도 될듯
(네온이나 로파이 비트나 뭐 그런겜을 찾고 있었다면 잘 맞을거라 생각함)

사진만 찍으면 좀 심심했을텐데 제작자가 전달하고자 하는 메세지나 분위기도 흥미로웠음
본편은 메세지가 추상적이고 은유적이긴한데 모 괴수영화 생각이 많이 났고
dlc는 본편에 비해 직접적으로 제시하고 있는듯
걍 심심하게 사진만 찍고 끝은 아니고 공간이 메세지를 담고 있어서 재밌다는소리임
2020년 시국에 잘 맞는 겜인가 하는 인상도 받았다

단점이라면 번역이 없고 dlc 목표들은 좀 애매한 표현이 있어서 막힐때 웍스루 좀 참고하게 됨
어차피 목표가 전부인 겜은 아니니까.. 공략 좀 본다고 해서 재미가 반감되지는 않지만 누군가는 검색을 귀찮아할수도있으니..
다시 했던 스테이지 돌아가서 맵을 찬찬히 돌아보면서 해금했던 기능을 써 보는 것도 재미니까 그런거 좋아하면 해봐도 ㄱㅊ은듯
나는 워킹시뮬레이션 좋아하는사람이라 재밌게 했다

아 그리고 겜이 짧은것도 단점이라면 단점이겠다 ㅋㅋ
재밌는데 스테이지 더 있었음 좋겠다 아쉬움 ㅋㅋ
스테이지많이plz


요약하면
재밌다 브금도좋음
현실엔 없는 친구도 3명+1마리나 줌
고양이도 찍을 수 있음
요약끝


+본편 스텝롤 올라가는데 있는 노란색 문구를 어떤 의미로 적은건지 궁금한데
아시거나 머 의견이나 나름의 해석있으신분은 댓글주심ㄳ 남의의견궁금 ㄳㄳ
 
ANTLION
0
3 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
3.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 24 mai 2020
加入爱の榨汁屋&关注爱の鉴赏家，用爱品鉴世间作品，用心流淌真情实感。
用拍摄的方式，记录身边的美
前言：
《摄追赤红末世代》是一款以末日超现实为题材的，第一人称跑酷摄影闯关类游戏，由ORIGAME DIGITAL开发，并由ORIGAME DIGITAL&PLAYISM发行。本作的主角是一名位于新西兰陶朗加市的陶朗加运输公司的送货员，在末日世界里他将和伙伴们一起前往各种地点拍摄各类照片并完成不同的挑战任务，从而获取更多的报酬和更先进的设备。

新鲜有趣的教程模式：
由于本作是一款关于摄影类型的游戏，其中往往避免不了专业术语的频繁出现，因此详细的教程模式就显得格外重要。首先其开场白采用了新西兰土著毛利语的问候形式，给玩家带来了一种别样的新鲜感。

紧接着通过分歧选项的设定，让玩家充分地融入进教程中的同时，也改变了教程的引导策略，例如其中的一个问题是“大家玩过FPS吗”，其回答分别有“当然玩过”和“不太熟悉”这两种，当玩家选择不同的分歧选项后，教程模式就会对此采取不同的引导策略，来考虑是否需要对玩家进行该方面的深度说明。

期间教程模式会简单地普及一遍本作的基本操作和核心玩法，以及对照片的评分模式进行简单的说明。照片的评分标准有三种，分别是”3C”即颜色（Colour），内容（Content）和构图（Composition）。首先一张照片中的颜色并不是越丰富越好，相反单一的色调可能会获得更高的评分。其次并不是所有的东西都能够被拍摄，例如每个场景中的“蓝色瓶子”在拍摄后都会扣除一定报酬，因为它被称为“葡萄牙人的战争——带电的水母”。最后是照片的构图，即使用了什么样的镜头进行拍摄，以及在照片中出现了多少人物等等。同样在教程的结尾处也使用了毛利语，若玩家对操作方法还略有疑惑，可以随时重新游玩教程。

丰富的拍摄内容，多种镜头以及后期处理：
本作采取了关卡制，即只有成功拍摄关卡内所有的物品并递交后，才能解锁之后的关卡和各种先进的设备。每个地图的大小随着关卡的解锁而线性提升，场景内的可互动元素也逐渐增多，例如玩家可以靠近主角的朋友们，按下E键使他们摆出各种姿势，同时玩家还能发现许多地图中的隐藏胶卷，可以允许你使用完24张初始胶卷后还能拍摄更多的照片。

本作拍摄的内容相当的丰富，可以是某个词汇短语，可以是一座山，一只猫或一群鸟，也可以是某个涂鸦或某种图案，甚至还可以损友等。其中某些物品需要玩家使用不同的镜头进行拍摄，例如特写、长焦、广角以及鱼眼镜头等，只需滑动鼠标的滚轮键就能进行各种镜头之间的切换，可谓十分的方便。然而单单只会选择镜头往往是不够的，你还需寻找一个合适的角度才能拍下美轮美奂的照片。

因此本作的重头戏“跑酷”元素便闪亮登场，由于主角自带“双段跳”的技能，因此他可以在各种建筑物之上穿梭游走，寻找属于自己的完美拍摄角度。随着主角自由度的提升，玩家能拍摄更多无与伦比的照片的同时，甚至还能发现各种隐藏于地图中的彩蛋元素等，可谓是乐趣无穷。不过在地图中需要玩家拍摄的物品也同样随着自由度的提升，而变得更加难以寻找和发现，且本作没有提示模式的设定，因此玩家很容易会长时间地来回兜转而感到冒汗和头晕，建议本作在之后的更新能推出一定的提示模式。

玩家每拍完一张照片后，便能直接对其进行后期的处理，例如改变一定的曝光程度、色彩平衡、彩色以及饱和度等，从而打造出属于自己的不二之作。此外拍摄完的照片还会自动保存在游戏的根目录下，玩家可以十分方便地将其发布并分享到官方推特或Steam社区中。

在此做一个小总结：
闪亮的优点：
末日题材下的第一人称摄影+
新鲜有趣的教程模式+
独特的玩法和丰富的拍摄内容+
拥有高自由度&跑酷元素的设定+

不足或缺点：
没有提示模式的设定-
长时间游玩容易晕3D-

推荐分（7.5/10）
 
𝔙𝔦𝔢𝔰𝔱𝔟𝔢𝔩

A good, short but sweet game. The music is amazing and I listen to it all the time now just cause its such a good vibe. Paired with the unique visuals in game and its such a relaxing experience. Obviously if you are into photography this game is for you, as this is the main focus of the game and it does it well. But overall if you are looking for a nice calm, almost zen like experience to help unwind, this game is for you.

Recommandé
5.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 27 février 2022
If you're looking at your games library and making raspberry noises with your lips, please try this for something different. It's a photo-take-athon and the adjustments you can make to your photos are pretty cool, although I'm not into social media so I bet the options pale in comparison to image filters on whatever social media platform you're desperately trying to get noticed on. However, for ignorant sods like me, if you feel like you have a vague creative streak but haven't really had the time to go down that path, I recommend this to dip your toes into some crazy photo taking opportunities. Choose the lens, tilt the camera, choose some egregious or muted colour settings, the game saves them for you in a folder and then, like me, set them as your desktop background if you can navigate Windows 10 settings better than I...

Umurangi Generation has a very interesting setting, and the anti-UN sentiment, as a failing to a fictional world catastrophe, or as a statement from the game producers, is pretty cool. Oh yeah, NATO can suck deez cashew nuts too. That one's from me.
 
Ayam XII
0
3 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
4.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 2 novembre 2023
❤ Audience ❤
☐ Beginner
☑ Casual Gamer
☑ Normal Gamer
☑ Expert

Controls would be tough for an absolute beginner to games.


☼ Graphics ☼
☐ Bad
☐ Alright
☑ Good
☑ Beautiful
☐ Fantastic

Graphics are low poly, but it does use colors very creatively. How much you like the style is going to be based on your own preferences. The graphics/artstyle were good enough for me to feel immersed in the game.


♬ Music ♬
☐ Bad
☐ Alright
☐ Good
☑ Beautiful
☐ Fantastic

Haven't heard a soundtrack like this before. Trippy, relaxing, and creative. My favorite part of the game.


☠ Difficulty ☠
☐ Easy
☐ Average
☑ Easy to learn / Hard to master
☐ Hard
☐ Unfair

If you don't care about how your photos look, there really isn't any difficulty. The game gives you a lot of tools though to take interesting shots.


§ Bugs §
☐ Bugs destroy the game
☐ Lots of bugs
☐ Few Bugs
☑ You can use them for speedrun
☐ Nothing encountered

The occasional flying up in the air. I enjoyed it.


☯ Story ☯
☐ There is none
☐ Bad
☑ Alright
☐ Good
☐ Fantastic

A slow rolling, world building lore that you experience through each level. Nothing too exciting, but I think it provided a good enough backdrop for interesting levels.


⚔ Gameplay ⚔
☑ Frustrating
☐ Sleepy
☑ Relaxing
☑ Fun
☑ Challenging

All over the place here. A combination of pokemon snap and tony hawk pro skater 2, while not being as good as either individually.
Collecting all film canisters was a memorization game that I did not enjoy. It's like tony hawk in the sense that you have timed levels, where you are trying to figure out cryptic challenges for each level. I enjoyed completing the base challenges the most.


۞ Game time / Length ۞
☐ Really short (0 - 3 hours)
☑ Short (4 - 8 hours)
☐ Few hours (10 - 20 hours) [if you focus on the main story]
☐ Long (40-60 hours) [if you complete everything]
☐ Very Long (61-100 hours)
☐ Extremely Long (101+ hours)

The right length for this game.


$ Price / Quality $
☑ Full price
☑ Wait for Sale
☐ Don't buy
☐ Refund it if you can

$15 is worth it if you like the art style.

Évaluation publiée le 1 novembre 2022
As a hobbyist photographer, this game is a lot of fun. Taking photos in surreal environments is great. You learn about the world and the events unfolding around you as a passive observer, while still being very much part of the world. The levels can feel a bit static at times, but this gives you plenty of time to explore.
Fun game for anyone interested in Photography.
 
Lennymeister
0
7 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
14.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 21 mai 2020
Produit reçu gratuitement

Either a fresh, laidback, visual experience or an engaging, arcadey, bumpin game; Umurangi Generation is one of those games where the pleasure is found with your view on gaming in general.

To a common player, it may just look like a straightforward "Find objective, complete objective" game. Of which, let's not lie to ourselves, it is and that can be pretty dull for some people. But, I found myself playing each level twice: Once to intake my surroundings, keeping mental notes, understanding the worldbuilding and crackin' lil gags with the NPCs around the stage because I enjoyed putting myself in the character's (invisible) shoes. The second time, with the information I had gathered, to go with a more arcade "speed clear" approach since trying to map out an effective path to knock out every objective in under 10 minutes was a fun little challenge. Now, I didn't go HAM on it to try and get the best darn time there is but more like a little trial of "Okay let's see what I can do..."

I enjoyed the approach to every level and how it followed a narrative. A narrative that at first would probably make you go "?????" but then you remembered details you had seen in previous levels that then make you go "Ahhhh yeah yeah!!!". It ain't anything SUPER mindblowing that will raise you're* IQ by 200 but its still pretty cool.

The game was definitely longer than what I had in mind. To a point where I even thought "What to heck where is it going to take me next after the previous level? Isn't this enough???". Near the end of the game, I felt a bit engulfed by the objectives and started paying a bit less attention to the details in the stages (I blame the film capsule collectibles making me look at the floor). The game didn't overstay its welcome though. I was really into it from start to finish and even checked back some earlier levels to put some pieces of the puzzle together.

Overall, it's a fun, chill game to boot up and just get yourself lost in. Cure a migraine or two yeah? Its really enjoyable to jump around and try to get some cool vantage points for shots (AND break out of bounds because the collision is a bit buggy at times (I phased through a wall in almost every level)). I feel like some levels's cash bonus objective could be tweaked because I found myself "farming my friends" for quick cash pictures which broke a bit of the immersion.

I'd say its a nice grab for ~$10 but its aint too much of a rush to grab it NOW and play it. Find that special moment in your life where this game will be some sort of meditation for ye. The music is dope too.
 
Gaungade
554 produits enregistrés

40.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 1 novembre 2023
《摄追赤红末世代》是一款风格独特的摄影游戏。建模保持着方块的抽象形状，色调异于常态，表现力夸张。玩家需要在箱庭中四处探索，用手中的相机拍下客户指定的内容，顺便进行收集，完成额外要求。相机需要手动对焦、调整参数并更换镜头，每个场景第一次都需要10分钟以上的时间探索；表面上是摄影游戏，难点全在寻找目标上。

游戏关卡不少，但必须至少完成前一关的普通拍摄任务才能进入下一关，而这种寻物型游戏物品藏得好好的死活找不到，卡关是常态，只有额外目标的明信片拍摄地点有提示，只能等大佬做攻略指南才能过关的样子……主角的跟班工具人朋友们太幸福了，只要在一边玩就行，主角还要到处找胶卷补充相片……

有趣的是，主角居然会二段跳（人都傻了），还会各种滞空技巧（包括滞空抓拍），更能在半空中使用传送魔法回到标记地点，这就是末世下生存的快递员需要掌握的摄影技术吗！（误）

不过总的来说，本作还蛮休闲的，只要不在意时间，不去完成任务，就可以一直滞留在当前场景听歌，朋克音乐丰富且好听。不过记得先看游戏教程哦，不要被邪恶的蓝色小玩意儿害了~
 
BearBa
10,180 produits enregistrés
0
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
5.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 5 janvier 2022
Umurangi Generation definitivamente é um jogo diferente de muita coisa no mercado, é uma experiência que tem como mecânica principal, tirar fotos e vai ser por meio dessas fotos que você vai descobrir esse mundo imperfeito e distópico de Tauranga, com diversos problemas sociais e politicos tratados de maneira adulta, bem desenvolvida e séria sendo também, não intrusiva, garantindo um foco quase que total na liberdade artística do jogador e na sua própria forma de fazer arte

No quesito jogabilidade, Umurangi é um jogo simples, você pode andar, pular, se agachar, coletar rolos de câmera, tirar e editar fotos e exatamente na questão da fotografia onde esse jogo brilha, permitindo que você altere diversos aspectos da imagem como Matiz, ISO, Saturação, Desfoque e diversos outros que são obtidos por meio das missões secundárias do jogo (que acabam sendo primárias graças ao foco em fotografia do jogo) para melhorar sua experiências com a checklist das missões primárias que consistem apenas em fotografar coisas específicas no mapa, como um grafite, um simbolo ou uma palavra mas que acabam servindo mais como motivadores pra você explorar esse colorido e distópico mundo que vai acabar por te fazer ficar com vontade de tirar só mais aquela foto antes de terminar a sua entrega que vai acabar por virar uma jornada de 15 minutos pela lente perfeita pra combinar com o filtro que você quer usar

Admito que comprei Umurangi Generation mais pela parte de fotografia que sempre foi um hobby meu, mas o seu mundo, seu senso de descoberta e a liberdade pra fazer as fotos que você quer fazer do jeito que você quer, é uma experiência simplesmente incrível e foi o que me prendeu no seu mundo, minha única recomendação é que você faça uma jogada e pegue todas as lentes, filtros e modificações disponiveis para a sua câmera e ai sim aproveite toda a liberdade criativa que esse mundo beirando o seu fim e cheio de amigos (e pinguins) tem a oferecer, simplesmente uma experiência imperdível para qualquer pessoa seja ela Fã de Fotografia, de Distopias Cyberpunk ou apenas alguém procurando uma experiência diferente das oferecidas na cena indie ou dos videogames em geral. Esse jogo é uma verdadeira obra prima e vai marcar quem jogou durante MUITO tempo.

10/10
 
Xepinha

FenixCrown
0
3 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
18.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 24 mai 2021
I never really considered myself a photography person. The underlying complexity of making photos anything but functional sounded like an arcane art, and one that needed a significant commitment to make it look good.

Umurangi Generation made me feel good, perhaps even competent, at photography. The freedom to approach the stage from any angle, with a variety of tools, and then to apply various filter effects through multiple sliders is joyful to say the least. Starting from just upping the exposure on a photo that's good, but a bit dark, and moving on to balancing multiple effects to get something that you wouldn't think can look this good is extremely satisfying.

The game definitely is an experience that is best unspoiled - not as much because of the twists and turns, but because of how it relies entirely on environmental storytelling. The playable stages are all a part of a consistent narrative, told exclusively by the way you, as a player, perceive it. It is much less about what kind of a hidden, objective lore you can glean from it, and much more about personal affect. What will catch your eye? Which detail will you focus your lens on, trying to make sense of the lousy future you've found yourself in? That is entirely up to you. Well, mostly.

If you can grab Macro DLC, you definitely should. If you're not sure, just get the basic game, and it should convince you enough to get it. It more than did for me.
 
The Picrew of Dorian Gray

Évaluation publiée le 2 novembre 2023
Felt strangely similar to Lovely planet despite being a complete different genre. Maybe it's the floating-island like levels or the stylized graphics or the story told only by the environment.
One thing i would recommend when playing the game is to turn off the timer. The game feels way more relaxed that way.
Since the levels are pretty short anyway you can return later for completion. But I think the experience really benefits from having no pressure and exploring the levels on your own pace.

1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile

Recommandé
3.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 7 juin 2021
一通りクリアしたので。
35%offセールで購入。ポップなアートワーク、lo-fiとゆーかchillみたいなBGMのPV見て前から気にはなっていたんですが、たまたま下調べしている時に世界観に関わる記事を見かけて、やっぱり面白そうだしやるかーと我慢できずに購入。正直、事前情報は抜きでプレイした方が、ゲーム一連の流れに関わる『謎』の深まりを楽しめたかなーと後から思ったけど、まーその辺人それぞれだよね。

ゲームは、箱庭をうろうろしながらミッションで課せられた構図の写真を撮るだけ。特に会話イベントが入ったり、ストーリー説明等のムービーは流れたりしない。そもそもNPCに話しかけることはできないし、オブジェクトに関与することもない。ただ移動して、撮る。その辺を簡素と見るか、目的に集中できると見るか。

サイバーパンクな近未来に(微ネタバレのため伏字) 戦争 が差し挟まる各ステージ構成で、一枚の絵に収めたくなる印象的な光景は多い。世界観に関わる小ネタみたいなのもふんだんに撒かれていて、それを一人称視点でそのまま見るか、カメラのファインダー越しに見るか、で視野や意識のピントが大きく変わるので楽しい。ただステージ(マップ)自体は比較的、手狭。

序盤(ステージで言うと2面)のOtūmoetaiをプレイした直後は、これからどんどんステージ広がって一見では覚えられないマップも出てくるんだろうな～困っちゃうな～とか嬉しみ半分何となく思ってたんだけど、そんなことはなかった。まー無駄に広くても、ステージクリアのための被写体はある程度限られてるから、それはそれで困るけど…残念。

単純にゲームとして遊ぶならアクションパズルゲームになります。(カメラ操作は別にして)アクションは基本移動とジャンプだけなので、難しい操作は不要です。ルール上ステージ毎に10分の時間制限は設けられているけれど、制限を過ぎても特にペナルティはありません。与えられたミッションをこなしさえすれば、いつでもステージクリア可です。
ただ、この『10分』が絶妙で、初見プレイだと微妙にタイムオーバーするレベルの猶予なので、リトライ性は高いと思います。

個人的にはED入りの演出が一番のお気に入り。あれめっちゃ好き。
 
JGはらど
0
6 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
10.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 14 mai 2021
This game is amazing! Often fiction is about the big players. For example, Evangelion main cast are the "most important" people in their respective worlds. Or the PC in each Fallout game (or almost any RPG, for that matter), whose decisions change theirs respective universes geopolitical configuration in an scale which is almost unthinkable for an every day person. All those fictions, in a sense, subscribe to the (very colonialist and eurocentrical) "Great Man Theory" of history by giving their protagonist choices world changing consequences.
But what about the common people living in the shadows of these (metaphorical, but sometimes literal) gigants? What about people like you, or me?
Umurangi Generation is the answer to that question. We learn, without any dialogue, the experience of the opressed and ignored. The game shows us how would be the life fo the people outside hegemonical narratives in the face of a world changing event of which they are not the protagonist, but just some folks trying to keep alive in the face of adversity.

Also, the soundtrack is SO GOOD!!
 
lili_t
266 produits enregistrés
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
7.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 9 juillet 2023
Overall I give it a thumbs out but there are a few things that really hold this back from being great. One is the bounties. At first they were fine but later on it becomes frustrating to not only find them, some levels being super dark, but then taking a picture of them doesn't guarantee it counting which is frustrating. That plus lens requirements really make bounties a chore more than anything. And lastly the one gripe with this is the controls Even being used to them control the photographer is challenging. You get stuck on a lot of things and jump like a 1cm off the ground.

I am burning through these levels not becuase they are fun but because I want to get to the mode where you can freely take pictures. I'm not there yet mainly due to how frustrating bounties are, often relying on a guide to find the ones that I just either can't find or I find but for some reason it just wont count.

I do love the concept tho and look forward to unlocking the mode to just freely take pictures in a level without bounties. Hope a second one comes out expanding on this idea because I would love to see this pushed even further.

16 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation amusante
2
Non recommandé
0.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 25 décembre 2020
Produit remboursé

This game felt like it was half-done.

The game made my insides shiver with excitement as I'd first read its description and saw the abstract-"color-blocked" pixel-y environment it had- I really liked solving photography related puzzles and taking pictures in Life is Strange, so the idea of a game being based solely on photography sparked a very high interest in me. Unofrtunately it did not last long, after playing for about 50 minutes I decided to return this game and its DLC, here's why:

-Controls. The main reason why I returned the game basically. I almost choked on my hot chocolate when I crouched for the first time ever. Like they say- in Russia you don't drink Vodka, Vodka drinks you. Same goes for this situation, it's not you who crouches but the surrounding environment that does. It feels as if the ground just lifts up closer to you and goes further when you undo the "crouch". Jumps are no different-in short, navigating with such controls remindes you that you're just a gliding camera rather than a photographer trying to catch some cool frames. Pretty sad for a game where exploration has quite of an emphesis.

-I know the low res and non-aliased edges are part of the aesthetic, and it's usually a style I adore in games- but not when it's painful to look at! Bounties such as finding scattered film rolls were a pain in the #*^. This also made the "exploration" part feel like a chore, which should have been one of the most enjoyable things to do in this game.

-The tutorial. I could perfectly get the information given in tutorial via a controls tab in settings. It was not interactive, a lot of information was given at once without letting the player to digest and engage with.

-In the menu I experienced multiple visual glitches while switching between let's say settings and tutorial, it was as if an additional flashing frame was added in-between, I don't think this was done delibiretly if the devs did not intend to trigger a seizure in epileptic players... A miniscule problem I know, but this makes the game look "messy".

-Lack of a story made maps feel as lifeless shells stuffed with objects. I couldn't care any less about NPC's as they were no different than a bucket filled with paint.

-Tasks were non-creative, addition of clunky controls and eye-hurting graphics did not help it either.

Only thing I liked about the game was the map layouts, and that's pretty much it. I did not find soundtracks anything of revolutionary unlike many people in here. I do not recommend this game, you can spend your coin on much better games. 3/10.
 
Velvet
601 produits enregistrés
0
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
3
Recommandé
13.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 18 juillet 2020
Produit reçu gratuitement

Umurangi Generation is pretty much the ultimate "lo-fi beats to relax/study to" game. There's not really a whole lot to playing it. You just walk around taking pictures of things in environments that are totally static except for characters going through animation cycles. And yet its culmination of lo-fi graphics and music is still absorbing enough that I played through each level multiple times and got 100 percent completion.


It's one of those games with low-poly, low-resolution graphics designed to look like it was made in the late 90's (other examples like Paratopic or Sagebrush deliberately evoke the original PlayStation but Umurangi is more like the Dreamcast). But instead of being a horror game its vibe is somewhere between Jet Set Radio and Neon Genesis Evangelion -- colorful urban landscapes, anime-inspired characters, rap music, impending kaiju doom. It works so well that during my first run I kept playing just to see where each new level would take me. These levels aren't just attractive in a sort of retro, cozy way, they're also packed with small details, just begging you to photograph every inch of them. The chillhop music fits all this perfectly. I bought the soundtrack and still listen to it.

What really shocked me is how Umurangi strings its levels together to subtly tell its story. The first few levels look like typical urban and cyberpunk stuff with shades of militarism creeping in the background. Eventually it becomes clear the player and a handful of other characters who appear in all the levels are moving through a world beset by kaijus as giant robots try to fight them. You don't really see the fighting itself, but rather its impact on the regular human population, like those sparse scenes throughout Evangelion that show normal people trying to survive on streets and in shelters, escaping the battles. Laced throughout those landscapes are various bits of social and political commentary, mostly around the theme of government incompetence (developer Naphtali “Veselekov” Faulkner tells me this was a response to how the Australian government handled the recent bush fires and climate change in general), as well as indigenous symbolism owing to the developer's Maori heritage.

The actual "game", the photography, might simply be an excuse to give players something to "do" while just vibing in the late 90's anime atmosphere Umurangi so expertly sets up. Even if it is, the game pays close attention to the snapping of pictures with the player character's DSLR camera. It kind of operates like a gun in a first person shooter -- the click of the camera's shutter being akin to reloading a shotgun, selecting each style of lens (standard, wide-angle, etc.) as if they were weapons, finding additional reels strewn throughout each level to replenish your ammo.

All you really have to do is essentially a scavenger hunt -- photograph certain objects or concepts in each level to unlock the next one. Some of these turned out to be fairly challenging "puzzles", but what really drew me in were the extra objectives and the additional lenses you get for doing everything in each level under a time limit. Those extra lenses and other tools, which I won't spoil, significantly alter the game. The later ones are basically cheats.

Looking back a month-plus after finishing Umurangi, I'm shocked at how much it stands out in my mind from the rest of what's come out in 2020 so far -- AAA games included. It's one of the most aesthetically pleasing games I've played in recent memory, period.
 
RedSwirl
641 produits enregistrés
0
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
10.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 25 mai 2020
There are so few games that give you the strangely dirty feeling of having inhabited a place. It's oddly got nothing to do with fidelity, complexity, features, physics, RTX enabled godrays tickling the hairs in your player character's nostrils, none of that.

If I had to tie it to something tangible, it's about how well a game makes you feel that the space has existed before and after you got there. Was something going on here? Is there evidence of that? What else goes on when I'm not Doing The Game Stuff? This kind of design makes the game's world balloon in your mind as you fill in so many blanks left there by the developer.

Umurangi Generation is an entirely extra life I've lived in a marvelously ♥♥♥♥♥♥ future where my friends and I are just trying to make the best of what feels like the end of the world. Taking photos, unlocking extras, and moving through the story is so much fun, and if you enjoyed Pokemon Snap or actual real world photography at all, there's so much here for you.

Cyberpunk games like this do not come along often at all. Seize this moment and play this game.
 
scottux

Évaluation publiée le 4 juin 2020
Visually gorgeous, and the photography tools are really powerful and fun to play with. The spaces your navigate and document give you plenty to do. It's also wonderful that there is so much going on beneath the beautiful surface, in terms of it being a meditation on the feeling of being young and powerless while the world collapses around you. There are a few bugs and some jankiness here or there, and I'm not wild about the stress the timer mechanic gives me (you can just ignore it, esp. your first time through). But overall, I found it a really interesting experience.

3.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 20 mai 2020
Really interesting game so far. Really like the art style and music.

Sometimes, the objective descriptions are either vague, or the item you're looking for is hard to spot. Also, the game had some scaling issues with my 3440x1440 monitor. After experimenting with the options, I've found the 1920x1080 works fine enough. I had tried a higher resolution that was narrowed but still 1440 (don't remember the exact dimension), however this led to several issues where buttons I needed to press were off screen.

Despite these few issues, I'm looking forward to exploring more of the world the developer has created.

Maniae
0
5 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
1.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 31 juillet 2021
"Don't huff paint and kill fascists at the same time, kids!"

I was introduced to Umurangi Generation by the Youtube channel Super Bunnyhop, and I really, REALLY liked the concept! I've always thought that the first person shooter style of play could be used for something else, and target-based photography with scoring is an excellent idea, and so I got the game and sat down to play.

Precisely two hours later the end credits rolled for me, and I was a little underwhelmed.

So what is the game about? Truth be told, I don't reall know the answer to that. The game has absolutely no dialogue, and while it does some interesting worldbuilding with how it sets up its scenes and levels, there isn't much of a story arc to follow here. We find ourselves in a city preparing for chaos, an alien invasion of some kind. I feel inspirations have been drawn from Godzilla and Neon Genesis Evangelion. There seems to be a ban on photographing some critters that appear in the game, so maybe there is a secretive coverup plot?

Hard to say, though, as nothing is ever explained. Instead the player ends up getting tasked with photographing spray paint cans and cats and graffiti and other random objects in a way that gave me no idea what the role of our character really is, and then to 'make a delivery', which I guess is delivering the photos we took to a place, such as the back of a van. Why? Again: the game does not say.

What about the photography itself? Is it crisp and fun and challenging? Well, not really. I ended up completing several objectives by accident due to the wonky target detection, and some of the objectives are very poorly explained, which can cause some frustration. Take a photo of 4 things, when there are only 3 of those things in the scene? Hmmm...

The visuals leave a lot to be desired as well. While the game goes for an highly stylized art style, far removed from photo realism and well suited for a small team and limited budget, it felt a little too crude at times. The movement around the levels is janky, it's easy to clip around to places you're not supposed to be, and there is no risks, challenges or even fall damage to worry about. There is a time limit of sorts, but that only seems to relate to a bonus challenge, not the core game itself.

The only part of the game that stood out to me, really, was the music. While it doesn't seem to really relate to the scene or location in the game, many of the tracks were absolutely great and I found myself jamming to them quite happily.

Still, a good soundtrack can't really save a poor execution, and sadly I find myself unable to recommend this game. As much as I love the idea, I feel like the game doesn't do nearly enough with it, or construct an engaging narrative in which the player could feel involved. I can see the developers wanted the player to feel like just a passenger in the sidelines, witnessing something greater than themselves, beyond control, but the ride is too short and lacks an engaging destination.


Playtime: 2+ hours (A single playthrough)

Ratings (1-10)
Visual: 7
Audio: 9
Story: 7
Gameplay: 5
Overall: 6
 
WHAM
876 produits enregistrés

Recommandé
2.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 2 décembre 2020
Super cool and chill game that I definitely recommend if you just want to play something different, but still good. The game is short to get through the main story (it took me 2.7 hours), but I could definitely see replaying this to unlock more lenses or to just hang out in this world and take some cool pictures. It's nice having a first person shooter where you are shooting with a camera to take awesome photos. It's also really neat seeing how the story unfolds and how nothing ever feels forced. You get attached to characters without realizing it despite them never having any dialogue.

Recommandé
9.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 21 septembre 2020
Amazing soundtrack, great concept but the gameplay loop leaves something to be desired. Whereas in a game like Tony Hawk, completing *any* objective advances your completion, if you aren't 100%ing a level in under 10 minutes in Umurangi Generation, it's not worth turning in your photos.

Sure, you could, and advance to the next level--but you will miss out on new lenses, editing options, etc. which keep the game from getting old.

Aside from the unfortunate 100%-or-nothing aspect, it is absolutely worth picking up (and probably the soundtrrack too!)

Évaluation publiée le 3 juin 2021
This is a first-person detective game, but with cool photo mechanics worked in. If you mixed Obra Dinn with Pokemon snap you'd be in the ballpark. It's also got good vibes, chill beats, and avoids too much text or any narration while still having an interesting little story. Not very long (I've played through all the levels at least once already) but there's unlockable upgrades that will almost certainly require a replay of every mission. Good stuff, unique.
 
Gilben
1,468 produits enregistrés
0
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
8.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 4 juin 2022
This is one of the most unique videogames that have come out in recent years. A game whose core gameplay is about photography and tasks you have to do based on the tools your camera has. Many people compare this game to Pokemon Snap, but there's a significant difference to that game: Umurangi Generation, for one, isn't on rails and the levels have lots of verticality. Plus, as mentioned before, you can take pictures and use different filters, effects etc.
The other part of this game which is very well thought out, is the environmental storytelling. There are so many things going on as you proceed and the game encourages you to explore the curiosity the levels may cause you. It will make you have questions like why there are so many propaganda posters everywhere? Why there are so many cops and troops around? Who is that enemy we're fighting against? Are the authorities showing any competence during the crisis? You see, this is a dystopian game and I would argue that it's one of the best in this category. In fact, I would go as far as to say that, as a sci-fi dystopian game taking place in the real world, Umurangi Generation is the best game of that kind since Deus Ex. Don't let the Jet Set Radio inspired aesthetics fool you, the game is actually very bleak.
Yet even with all its bleakness going on, it serves as a sign of hope in modern gaming. Many people argue nowadays that games don't try enough to be unique or engaging, and that the developers are not as passionate as they used to be. Well, I use this gem right here as my disagreement to such statements. Especially since the developer behind this is still supporting his work 2 years after its release. Did I also mention that Umurangi Generation is DRM free? Yeah, you can buy it here on Steam, but Steam isn't required to get the game running.
With all that said. my final verdict is: This is the real Cyberpunk game of 2020/10
 
DimitrisYellingPlaya
208 produits enregistrés
0
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
9.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 23 mai 2020
The sounds, sights, and shots I’ve taken, coupled with my newfound desire to partake in photography… I think I’m comfortable saying UMURANGI is worth every penny. If you’re a fan of the aesthetics, and grew up on games like Jet Set and Tony Hawk, and hell even Pokemon Snap, this game is worth a look. If love taking beautiful screenshots in games, well it’s the perfect title for you. And if you’re interested in photography, it may even be good practice. Just make sure your PC can handle it. All in all, UMURANGI GENERATION the most unique game I’ve had the pleasure of playing in a long time, and I’ve still got plenty of pics left to take.

Boog
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
3.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 10 décembre 2023
Umurangi Generation is a game about taking photos during the apocalypse. and tells the story of a world entirely through asking you to take photos.

This game mechanic is a pretty genius move, as you are hyper-aware of your surroundings at all times and understand the story that is being told without any dialogue or exposition. Taking photos is a lot of fun and editing them afterwards and using different lenses gives you some pretty cool effects.

There is a lot of the fun to be had in the game is with the vibe, the general premise of the game, the music, and the world, which I can't spoil too much, but based on these factors I can really recommend playing it. The game took me 3 hours to complete so you don't really tire of the gameplay in that time, and the objectives for each level were generally fresh and interesting.

There is some general jank to the game, certain things are a bit buggy, but it doesn't take much away from the experience, as it fits the vibe and general punk-ness of the game almost better than a really polished game would. Which doesn't mean that it's always nice, but it's not that bothersome.
There are however a few things that actually annoyed me: one thing were the additional objectives during a mission, (such as finishing the level in a certain time, collecting items, etc.) I found none of these to be very enjoyable. I only really started having fun with the game when I started ignoring the timer and the collection aspect of the game. The other side-objectives were fine but I feel like I would have enjoyed the missions more without any extra objectives. Similarly, once you complete all the main objectives, you have to leave the level by finding a physical point in the level to exit from, which was exhausting, not that much fun and could have easily been solved by a "Finish Level" UI button. Finishing all objectives and side objectives during your first try at a mission is borderline impossible and replaying the level just to get it done in time wasn't really something I was interested in, but was something the game encouraged. Some of the levels were just slightly too big to be enjoyable to explore and my favorite levels usually were the really compact ones. Additionally, some lenses were a bit hard to use and the game sometimes explains objectives and basic controls in a way that isn't clearly understandable. Umurangi Generation generally feels like a good game with a great idea and cool mechanics, that could really have been improved by getting some playtesters to play it before release.

I genuinely wouldn't recommend this game to everyone. If you want a hardcore photography game, or a very polished gameplay experience, you might not have a lot of fun with this. I personally really liked the game, though. The game has a great sense of humor and style and some pretty memorable moments, and is really making you feel seen for worrying about the future of the planet in modern times.

Recommandé
23.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 24 octobre 2022
I love this game. I think it's the best game of 2020. I think it's an all timer.
Umurangi Generation is beautiful. It wields style. Its levels are generously decorated and palpably full of stories.
Umurangi Generation is the loudest, angriest game that never speaks a single word of dialogue. It yells about the world, how it treats people, how people treat it. It yells about how the repercussions of decisions made by those who don't care affect the lives of those who become forced to care.
Umurangi Generation made me want to be a photographer. I learned a few tricks through playing, which gave me the head start I needed to learn to proficiency with a real DSLR. The skills I learned translated back to the game. The pictures I take now are better than the pictures I took before. I want to get my own DSLR. Umurangi Generation taught me to love the medium of photography.

Évaluation publiée le 8 juin 2021
As a person who does photography, this game is fantastic. The art style is distinctive and gorgeous, taking photos feels wonderfully tactile and the amount of control you have is a lot of fun to play with, the world is wonderfully developed and (as is somewhat the point) I immediately got sucked in and wanted to know more. I love how the various characters' (on- and off- screen) interaction with the world is complicated and varied -- everything from propagandistic to punk -- but ultimately human when push comes to shove.
oh and it's really pretty
so that's a plus

Kairuku.
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
22.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 27 aout 2020
Produit reçu gratuitement

If we’re to watch the world burn, better we do it through the lens of Umurangi Generation, a window into an artistic and vibrant culture standing out against a dispiriting reality around it. It’s not some altogether hopeful and optimistic lens, but it’s a gripping one, no doubt. Umurangi Generation feels like nothing short of a miracle, a photography game which truly elevates itself through its worldbuilding, its atmosphere, and its triumph in capturing photography’s varied joys.
First, it must be said that this game positively oozes delectable vibes. From its low fi beats to its use of moody color and the general impression of each level as this singular, outstretched moment, the game’s aesthetic and presentation are incredibly chill, although the scenes certainly grow more dire over the course of the game. The art design is wonderful, with numerous styles which should be more disparate than they are. These range from sketchy wall graffiti, to the simple and charming models, to the various posters and billboards, many of which even employ real-life photos. These all blend shockingly seamlessly, and produce a world soaked in its own cultural and advertising landscapes.
Umurangi Generation’s worldbuilding is exceptional, as it conveys so much culture, counter-culture, and context simply through the scenes, environments, and progression of its areas. And while the player character is never explored in the game, the presence of your friends in every scene grounds you in that diegesis. At first the game seems content merely to tease a bigger picture informing the world of your photo-ops. But soon you’ll find yourself a witness to a momentous event for this world. It eventually becomes clear these photo shoots are not wholly discrete and arbitrary occasions, but a timeline of scenes throughout that greater event. These inject new context and tension into the situation. At first I was casually chilling with my friends on a rooftop photo op. But then I was thrust into an escalating crisis, one which proved positively absorbing. The ending at first seemed sudden and underwhelming. But it soon sunk its teeth into me and became a harrowing sendoff to my time with this world.
The game is unapologetically political, too, allowing a richer, more relatable landscape. Art and politics aren’t treated as disparate entities, for the game or for its world. Rather, they coexist and interact meaningfully. Graffiti and other art in the game are often thinly veiled – or even blatant – in their critique of the failures of government and authority in the wake of disaster. Newspaper headlines and movie posters will reflect this, and you get a solid sense of how things got this bad. These even provide a chance to gleam hints of the terrors imposed on this world, before they’re directly presented to you. And despite the sci-fi edge to Umurangi’s world, many of its problems are all-too-real and strikingly current.
At its core, Umurangi is a mostly straightforward photography game. To progress, you simply need to snap the photos described in your objectives list. Find your subjects, nail the angle, and employ the right lens if necessary. In practice, many shots are quite demanding, working as their own miniature puzzles, asking you to really the scene at its macro and micro levels to work that perfect angle. The fish-eye lens does admittedly break several objectives once you unlock it, as its sweeping reach can capture numerous targets at once, assuming they’re not coupled with specific lens requirements.
Photography is further baked into the game thematically. Each stage feels itself like a snapshot of this world, a moment caught in suspended animation for you to roam and purvey. Every area is a window into this world’s people, culture, context, and history, even its unfolding history happening right in front of you. But there’s never some sweeping score or choreographed cinematography to superficially dazzle you. Rather, discovery is wholly naturalistic and thus more humanistic. You get to develop the world through exploration, and by seeking to capture key scenes and details. You dictate your own experiential relationship with the environment, and the game challenges you to both recognize and produce meaning from the scene. There’s a true and unrivaled wonder to it all.
The controls are quite intuitive and simple, although the double jump can be a bit unwieldy at times. When you whip out that camera, though, everything works like a dream. The plethora of options before and after snapping the picture ensure there’s ample room for customization and creativity thanks to a surprising number of lenses, camera add-ons, and editing tools. I’m certainly excited to jump back in and see what I can produce. Fortunately, the game fully embraces its own social potential by directly connecting you with all your photos to share and save as you please. Umurangi Generation really feels like a platform for expression, both for the game’s own developer, but also for the players. It’s a brilliant realization of how real-life photography and other media presence can inform our understanding and perspective on a work or event. I also appreciate how the developer left all these extra little alcoves and pathways. Some require light platforming to access, but these are seldom required of the player to access for the main objectives. Rather, they’re simply additional spaces allowing new perspectives and unconventional angles for the creatively inclined.
Every core objective – save for one – is wisely rooted in the same focal action: taking a photo. This keeps the focus finely honed in on Umurangi’s gameplay and thematic conceit. Perhaps a bit contrary to this is the scavenger hunt for film canisters. These are scattered through each area, and occasionally, there will be one which proves quite tricky to track down. Reaching the payment amount, conversely, is rather simple to the point of being trivial. Most of the value of your shot seems to be determined by its content, in which you can simply snag a few fish-eye shots with plenty of things on-screen for a considerable payout. But these extra objectives are only needed if you want to seek out the additional modifications for your camera. While I understand the risk of overtuning a system assigning a monetary value to subjective imagery, the current system doesn’t encourage any creativity or experimentation, especially as it downplays the other two Cs the game champions, color and composition.
The game is conducive to both players looking for a lax photography simulator and those craving a more “gamey” experience. Those in the latter camp can pursue those optional objectives in a scramble to achieve them all within the ten-minute time frame. The time limit is far from strict, as once you memorize the photo and film canister locations, you can probably clear most stages in about half the allotted time, easily.
Umurangi Generation has a few ever-so-minor hitches which could perhaps be ironed out. But as with any truly masterful work of art, these faults pale in comparison to a package of otherwise outstanding achievement. As a photography game, Umurangi comes alive as a venue for inspired and motivated creativity and expression. As a narrative experience, it provides a shockingly heavy and political story, which manages to be more impactful in silence than most games could ever hope to manage with heaps of text or spoken dialogue. Those looking to get to the credits and get out might find it a bit fleeting. But I found myself enraptured from beginning to end. Umurangi Generation attracted me with its uniquely humanistic and grounded photography simulation, but I stayed for a world so alive, so expressive, so yearning, so heartbreaking, that I just had to be there alongside it for the end.
 
Uncanny_CC

Recommandé
14.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 26 mai 2020
A really fun and interesting game!

While the movement is a bit clunky, it's not so bad once you get the hang of it (double jump early into your first jump to get maximum height). The amount of evocative detail in each of the levels is fantastic and goes a long way in telling the game's story.

Umurangi Generation tells the story of its setting via the incidental details in each level. The story it tells is broad and thematic, but also deeply specific, clearly in conversation with a lot of cyberpunk and apocalyptic ideas.

To encourage close scrutiny of the spaces, the photography mechanic sets up a number of bounties, collections of items that need to be photographed together (sometimes with specific lenses, or specific proximity). I found these to be fun puzzles in their own right, but also vectors through which I noticed other interesting details about the levels.

Gradually introducing new lenses and effect sliders was a great way to gradually introduce photography concepts, though I wish I'd gotten more time to explore some of the later options.

All told, this game makes me more certain than ever that we need more games that use photography as the primary mechanic. It's such a natural way to guide exploration through densely detailed spaces.
 
The Castle Builder
733 produits enregistrés
0
3 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
5.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 11 janvier 2022
Umurangi Generation serves not only as a really cute photo-sim game, but also a really subtle political commentary on New Zealand/Australian Politics. As an Australian, it makes me feel heard in a way no other game has with its direct criticisms of our Prime Minister. It's art style is between Jet Set Radio and a Playstation 1 Game, which fits it's tone perfectly alongside the quirky lofi/breakbeat soundtrack, capped off with a really intriguing cyberpunk aesthetic that rejects some of its core tenants for Maori folklore, which is incredibly fresh and welcoming. The base game I found incredibly enjoyable, if brief, akin to something on Itch.io. The soundtrack is excellent, funny in some places. My only reservation is again the length, and how unless you've been paying attention, it's over-arching narrative comes at you incredibly fast, confusing to some degree. Despite, I wholeheartedly recommend it!! Mad props to the sole dev behind this. Tends to be one of those "you either love it or you don't" games, but I think it could be a lot of people's 'thing'.

The DLC is really where the potential of the game comes out. It's also short, slightly shorter than the main-game. However, it retains its subtle storytelling in a way that comes together a lot better, feeling a lot of Neon Genesis Evangelion, which the Dev has stated is an inspiration. Highly recommend the DLC.

Évaluation publiée le 5 aout 2023
Caso você goste de fotografia, Umurangi Generation é um dos melhores produtos disponíveis na steam, todo um sistema de câmeras e edição robusto, cenários variados e criativos que contam uma história com o passar do tempo, além de toda uma estética unica e digna de comparações com Evangelion, Akira, Initial D, entre outros exemplos magníficos da cultura oriental.

Caso você não goste de fotografia, Umurangi é só um caça palavras 3D com alguns problemas técnicos.

Évaluation publiée le 26 octobre 2021
As someone who enjoys photography irl, I had a great time with umurangi generation. It's a charming game with a great OST, especially in the DLC. Is it janky? Yes. Did that detract from the experience? Not at all.
I personally think you'll get the most out of it if you like exploring, and also just taking photos. The goals itself won't keep you entertained for long, but if you actually take your time to take some photos, I think you'll get a lot more out of this game. Also, all the unlockables are great later on and give you lots of gear to frame your shots.

6.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 5 février 2021
This game (even though I haven't played far into it) is amazing. When I was getting into it I was hoping for something akin to sludge life, a free roam open world tagger type of game with its story through conversations, but I was wrong and still love it. It's take on the idea of what I like to describe as a photography collectathon as you are given different things to take pictures of in different areas in each level with some bonus things on the side. The way how it is done is good but there is one thing I'd like to see if possible. Some type of hint system. Instead of like a pop up every minute make it through the people in the levels so you aren't stuck on a level for an hour trying to find a film reel, but it doesn't have to be like "look under the desk at this location," make it like "hey you looking for one of those weird cases, I think I saw one like under some desk a bit back," like not too obvious or heck even hide something in conversation like in KatiKati you go to the guys near Pengi and one dude says hey have you seen that butterfly graffiti in that back alley? It's pretty nice if you haven't seen it." Then again I guess the way how collectathons work is figuring out by looking everywhere, but it does get tedious now and again. Overall a 9.9/10 in my book. That's not even mentioning the music of the game by Adolf Nomura with all the songs vaguely sounding like songs you would hear in other game. The tone always hits in this good way from up beat to slow with the idea of something ominous for how the day and age is in the story. Truly some stuff I'll be listening for many reasons and scenarios.

A_Bottle_of_Gin

2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
8.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 31 décembre 2020
Umurangi Generation (+Macro DLC) Pełna Recenzja

Plusy:
+ Sam gatunek. Rzadko kiedy jest okazja przejść FPSa, który jest grą fotograficzną. Do głowy przychodzą mi może z trzy maks ale dopiero Umurangi tak mocno się na tym skupia, pun intended.

+ Opcje i gameplay. Nie tylko przed zrobieniem zdjęcia masz do wyboru tyle obiektywów, podświetleń, dodawaniem efektów itp. to jeszcze po zrobieniu zdjęcia masz od grona opcji, które mogą zmienić wygląd tego. Większość z tego jest ukryta za przechodzeniem poziomów i robieniem ich na 100% co czyni je dobrymi nagrodami o dziwo.

+ Już chce mi się wrócić do niej. Ponadto robiłem dużo zdjęć, których gra ode mnie wymagała więc kiedy np. zostało mi jeszcze trochę czasu przed speedrunnem poziomu to cykałem cokolwiek co było dla mnie interesujące... według mojego folderu zrobiłem 742 zdjęć.

+ Score system, który tak naprawdę, nie ma prawie żadnego znaczenia I DOBRZE. Sam w sobie jest dobry gdyż skupia się na trzech C – Composition, Color & Content. Ważne jest to, że nie musisz skupiać się na trzech na raz by mieć wartościowe zdjęcia ale możesz. Możesz zrobić wysoko ocenione zdjęcia z małą ilością kolorów I rzeczy ale z dobrą kompozycją co da Ci np. Tyle samo co zdjęcia z wszelakimi ludźmi na ulicy.

+ Ta fabuła. Podoba mi się, że poza samouczkiem wszystko tak naprawdę jest powiedziane przez scenerię.

+ O tyle zapamiętałem tylko z garstkę utworów, to sama ich ilość (ok. 80 2-minutowych kawałków) oraz to, że każdy poziom ma inny zestaw bardzo pomaga.

+ Dla artystycznych ludzi.

Minusy:

- Krótka bez DLC a z DLC może być za droga. Ponadto DLC dodaje znacznie lepsze zakończenie i nowe poziomy, które tak naprawdę są tymi najlepszymi z może jednym wyjątkiem. Więc jak kupujecie to polecam od razu z DLC.

Tylko jako niekoniecznie negatyw czy plus (bądź statyw) powiem, że widać, iż to jest modern gra. Są memy, jest śmianie się z popkultury internetu oraz przewidywanie przyszłość (Bar z 3D ORAZ 2D waifu), jest dużo rzeczy, które mogą być niesamowicie "dated" za parę lat, ale w przypadku tej gry uważam, że to działa bardzo dobrze akurat.

Tak poza tym to... nic mi nie przychodzi do głowy, serio. Jak miałem jakieś problemy (np. to, że 100% poziomu wymaga zrobienia bounty photos na czas 10 minut albo trochę trudny element platformowy w DLC) to po męczeniu się z nimi maks paru minut kompletnie o tym zapominałem i mam wrażenie, że nie wpłynęło to wcale na ocenę końcową.

Co najmniej 9/10
 
Popcioslav

5.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 16 juin 2020
A surprisingly pleasant and relaxed game in which you're tasked with taking photos during the apocalypse.

It's such a game (you could spend ten minutes in a single level or spend an hour plus if you really get into photoing stuff) that it eschews cinematic or literary storytelling and delivers everything you need to know (with a fair emotional punch) through the environments you explore.

It is so wonderfully evocative and it's hard to describe the sense of world as you wander around and let the story flow through you.
