Évaluation publiée le 20 juillet 2023
Melhor jogo indie que joguei recentemente. Parece só um de fotografia com uma OST que mistura LoFi e Synthwave pra passar o tempo. Porém você vai jogando e a lore da três mortal pra trás e o rumo muda pra uma direção que você não espera. É uma obra de arte e pra cada pessoa vai ser uma experiência diferente porque cada um vai poder focar naquilo que atrai mais a atenção, é só olhar a aba comunidade que vocês vão entender. Recomendo demais e a DLC também.
 
LeiHang
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation amusante
0
Recommandé
1.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 25 mai 2023
Great game 10/10. Someone said it was pro-communism but I don't think they understood the story. Story is really cool and you kind of have to take your time to figure it out in detail. If I'm wrong and it actually is some commie Pravda the game loses a point but really don't think that was the story being told.

Thought this was going to be more open world and was slightly annoyed at first at the timer and level based system but really glad it was like that in the end. Almost reminded me of tony hawk 2 as weird as that sounds theirs various little collectibles and secrets to find in each level as you try and perfect your score in a points based system. I really only wish there was more objectives, Feel like they should have put more emphasis on taking pictures of certain story elements that could be otherwise passed over..

Visuals have a very jet set radio quality to them, as does most of the game, that I find unique and charming. This game doesn't exactly have good graphics but it has such a unique style that it really doesn't matter.

Music Is pretty chill vibe type music. Sorry no strong opinions on most gaming music. Usually mute BGM and listen to news o... whatever point is its okay. Sound design fits the aesthetic.

(spoilers Story section)
Story is great, It's an end of the world scenario in which you can do nothing to prevent it other than take pictures and watch it happen. Kaijus are destroying the planet and they are messing us up. all this happens in the background the game doesnt outright tell you any of it. The story telling almost reminded me of an ARG in the confines of a single game. Pretty cool way to deliver the narrative.

There are some people say its promoting communism but I really dont think so, also not a fan of it either so i hope not. Think that stuff in game has to do more with new zealand being the only place left on earth not destroyed. U.N. and coalition forces had to declare strict martial law in order to make an attempt to keep order and galvanize the last of humanity to go fight the monsters destroying the planet. If anything I think all the graffiti kinda highlights the people who left it as losers who were to cowardly and lazy that let real men go do there fighting for them which was ultimately meaningless anyways as ultimately everyone dies. Yes it's one of those stories and I love it. Makes you really confront your existence.

Anyways if you like quirky and eclectic games with huge PS2 era vibes based on photography totally get this you probably wont be disappointed.

TripleHelix935
986 produits enregistrés
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
8.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 26 février 2023
Umurangi Generation is a vibe, and I absolutely love it!
Unfortunately, I can't say I'm the kind of person who would enjoy this game the most. It's a game about photography, and I'm really not good at it... and yet, as I said, I love this game a lot! It's still very enjoyable, even for photography inepts like me!

I think one of the things that make this game so fun for everyone, is the requirements you have to meet in the levels. Obviously, optional tasks such as "Finding all the Film Canisters in a level" or "Finishing the level under a certain period of time" will be fun to some. But I'm referring to the actual mandatory ones: take a picture of X and Y thing(s) with Z lens. It makes you look for said items, find the right position, use the needed lens, and maybe do some awkward repositioning. They make the mandatory objectives look great (most of the times at least...) and force you to get creative! And, in the process, something may catch your attention as well, and you may decide to take a pic of that too! That's how I enjoyed it the most at least...

Presentation-wise, Umurangi Generation is phenomenal! It has this low-poly, cell-shaded anime artstyle that is just... so good! It gives some nice Jet Set Radio vibes, but thanks to the much dimmer lighting and depressive atmosphere, it still stands out by itself. The soundtrack is mostly composed of some unique chill music, that I've found myself listening to quite a few times since I played it. Not something I listen to very often, but I love to have it in the background and hum to it every once in a while.

And the story... well I'm going to be completely honest, I'm really bad at catching any media's plot, even when it's spit on my face, so I may not have got it all. That being said... the story is really cool! It starts with you and your friend chilling, visiting different locations and such, but it quickly becomes obvious that things are really not okay: Prepared military camps, and memorials and candles to remember the deceased at first; and not much later, gunfights against gigantic incomprehensible beings and desperate people trying to evacuate the area. Welcome to the end of the world.

There really aren't many negatives I can point out. The movement is a little wonky, and the collisions can be pretty clunky (going upstairs is fun sometimes, some others it's frustrating). It's also a pretty short game, but like, so what? Just enjoy the scenes, take some cool photos, listen to those beats, and witness the end of the world...

Dedicated to the Umurangi Generation
The last generation who has to watch the world die.
 
Silver Bunny
401 produits enregistrés
0

The way the story of the situation lays out feels well done here. You're one of the people affected by the battles. You're being invaded in multiple ways. The controls were rather janky for me, which is a downside, but I really liked going through, getting pictures, and having to think of what bits of story to photograph.
Strong recommend.

zerofelicidade
107 produits enregistrés
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
7.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 19 janvier 2023
Umurangi Generation is one of the most interesting games I have ever played. I came across this game during my research on in-game photography. More specifically, I was looking at video games where photography is a major part of the gameplay. As a photographer, I can say that the parameters used to rate the photographs taken by the player are quite absurd. However, I was expecting this and it doesn't decrease the pleasure of being creative with all the functions that the game provides, and there are a lot of them! The visual style is based on a cyberpunk world and its presentation is inspired by old video games. I think the decision to go with the retro look is very attractive, as there is no actual try to illustrate a photorealistic world here, which makes the photography in this virtual space seem even more abstract and artistic. What fascinates me the most about Umurangi Generation is the world it portrays and the story it tells. It's absolutely brilliant that the story isn't told via cutscenes, scripts or text, but exclusively via the different levels and the objects and characters they contain. The story reveals itself to a good observer and a photographer is in the end nothing else.

It also runs very well on the Steam Deck.
 
Kersten

Évaluation publiée le 15 novembre 2022
The quintessential scifi disaster photography game. You thought you were solving fundamental visual puzzles, but you were actually investigating the failures of your society. One of the few dystopian stories to encourage you to savor the present.

Shoutouts to the soundtrack to being one of my most played music for the past year and getting me in the mood for DJ Tariq.
 
Ennui Enthusiast
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
5.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 8 novembre 2022
From a gameplay angle, it can be very janky at times. From a political angle, especially in the Macro DLC, it is very blunt. If you're someone who demands polish from your games and doesn't want to have "politics shoved down your throat" you're not gonna have a good time here. Luckily for me that wasn't the case.

The gameplay mechanics are actually a bit more interesting than your average photography game - sometimes you actually really have to think about how exactly to get the shot it's asking you to get, and that can be quite difficult at times - whether it's searching for the specific thing the bounty is asking you to get (for example, it might feature somewhere you don't expect, like on a poster or a computer screen), or lining up the shot itself with the lense it asks you to use. It's almost like a puzzle game in that respect.

Visually and thematically, what you get here is very much inspired by both Evangelion and very recent protest movements globally. The main game tells a story that is laregelly about the apocalypse. The DLC is much more interested in how our current world order is ran by powerful but simple-minded hedonists who do not care if their actions result in the death of their subordinates, ordinary citizens, or even the earth itself. If you do enjoy the main game from a thematic standpoint, I do very much recommend the DLC.
 
michaelcarlinkay
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
1.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 4 novembre 2022
I'm missing whatever others are seeing here. Gameplay-wise, getting around levels is a hassle, photograph objective criteria seem alternately way too permissive or way too restrictive, and the scoring system is both opaque and inconsequential. I read a lot of praise for the game's story (or setting, rather, since it's conveyed entirely passively through the environment) but the messaging feels pretty unsubtle. It also feels in conflict with the gameplay, since we're to understand that protag and his buddies live in a dystopian, colonized world... but nobody seems interested in preventing him from or reprimanding him for slacking off during his courier job and ducking into (for one example) a military tent to take extreme-close-up photos of the soldiers' faces, their weapons, and a map presumably showing troop movements and positions.
 
Tasslehoff_B
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
7.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 1 octobre 2022
Umurangi Generation é um jogo belo, sua única mecânica é tirar fotos, e nada mais alem disso, sem contar a exploração dos cenários que são muito ricos. Não possui nenhum tipo de diálogo, sua historia e construção de universo e toda contada pelo próprio local que você é inserido, entre no nível, faça os objetivos e passe para a próxima entrega. Falando assim faz o jogo parecer chata e repetitivo, mas não é, cada lugar que visitas é único e de certa forma vivo, alguns se repetem mas e numa perspectiva muito diferente e criativa, os fãs de Evangelion vão adorar as referencias. Agora o jogo não é perfeito, ele tem muitos problemas técnicos, alguns podem atrapalhar e outros são engraçados, eu cansei de ficar preso numa parede ou sair voando enquanto tentava pular de um lugar pro outro, alem de alguns itens ou o rosto dos personagens sumirem se eu me aproxima-se muito, e alguns descuidos que percebi em algumas animações que quase chegaram a estragar a imersão no jogo, mas procurar o melhor ângulo para sua próxima foto é muito mais recompensador. Não é um jogo para qualquer um, para quem quer um experiência diferente, um tanto casual, e apreciar a construção de um mundo, eu recomendo fortemente, mas para quem gosta de coisas mais frenéticas com muita ação, definitivamente não foi feito para você.

Recommandé
3.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 21 septembre 2022
This game is beautiful, atmospheric, innovative and manages to tell an interesting story without any narration. The camera mechanics are incredibly fun, and even though the parkour elements can be a bit tedious due to the dodgy collision detection (prepare yourself for regularly glitching through stairs or out of the map) and the ultra low mouse sensitivity, exploring the levels and taking your time to explore all the details feels great. I'd definitely recommend it if you want something to relax that is unlike any other game out there, and if you have a creative side.

A very phenomenal game it is.

Évaluation publiée le 12 septembre 2022
Short and sweet review for a short and sweet game. Loved the concept. Loved the art direction. Loved the unique storytelling approach. I beat it and unlocked everything in about 3 hours, but I still feel compelled to go back to mess around and take some more pictures. I honestly struggle to think of someone who wouldn't enjoy this at least a little. If you're looking for a chill game, this is for you. If you're looking for a fast paced speedrun type game this is (surprisingly) also for you. Highly recommended.

Abca

Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
5.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 1 aout 2022
Very vibe, very unexpected story when going in blind. Music is a vibe, visuals are a vibe, all your dear friends are a vibe. A very aesthetic game.
Sometimes the mechanics can feel clunky and I feel like thats mostly a result of the confusing objectives of each level, I went in without playing the tutorial so I'm not sure if that would have cleared it up at least in learning the mechanics and what your objectives are, I feel like making that mandatory would help but even then it doesn't bother the feeling of this game with it's quite short runtime so any frustration is not all that bothering.

All in all excellent game well worth picking up if aesthetic punk photography sounds fun to you

Edit: get the dlc
 
Sleppy
470 produits enregistrés
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
3.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 19 juillet 2022
Umurangi Generation, and its expansion Umurangi Generation Macro, are a testament to the statement, "Video games are art". Flawlessly, Origame Digital presents a mechanically satisfying and enjoyable experience while weaving in an emotionally impactful and relevant story. Simultaneously the artistic style, both visually and audibly, is unique and poignant...mystical and grounded. Umurangi Generation and its expansion are not only worth the time you spend with them, but the time you spend enraptured in their creative/photo mode as well. Do yourself a favor and give this is a go! Highly recommend, especially if you enjoy similar games such as Broken Reality and Assemble With Care.

ContinuousNoise
130 produits enregistrés
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
12.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 6 mai 2022
我其实也不知道该怎么谈论这样的作品、

1
玩法肯定不少见。不仅有不少同类作品，更多的还有在大作中作为一小部分内容或支线而被提供。
如果说有什么特别的，在摄影的专业性上作了一些深入？我不懂摄影，很难在这方面有什么评价。

但是有一点，游戏里说了好几次：“虽然某某功能可以帮助更好地摄影，但是也不强求，新手也能获得快乐。”
是的，我觉得玩得很愉快。

2
游戏肯定有将末世氛围好好表达了。
或者说，我不确定着是否应该用末世氛围来形容。
毕竟这和通常说到的，末世游戏、末世电影之类的差别太大了。

在通常说到的末世游戏中，我们在末世之中挣扎，成为英雄、或弱者、或牺牲者。我们总是个谁。

但是在这里，我好像谁也不是。
这里好像谁也没有。
没有什么特别的角色。虽然我是有那么几个朋友来着，后来还多了几个朋友。

在这个故事里，好像唯一被讲述的对象，只是这个赤红天空的末世而已。

我是个空洞的旁观者。毕竟我只是个照相的嘛。
但是说真的，就算是记录，我所拍下的照片对于记录这个世界什么的也不值一提。
甚至与我在这里不多的场景所见到、所听到、所感到的相比，这些照片也不值一提。
这些照片充其量…不过是明信片的水平？

就好像我们去到一个地方，有所感，但又明知这些感动将会流逝无法把捉；于是哪怕是留下一张明信片呢？
而这张明信片当然无法留下关于这个世界的万一。

在这片末世天空下，还有着纷繁复杂的世界存在在那里。
这个世界的故事、史诗、英雄、梦想、毁灭、爱情、……什么都没有被留下。
看看那远方的机甲的影子，我是照了这么张照片，可是这被讲述的世界和我的照片有一毛钱关系嘛？

3
啊，大概还是有关系的。
我也得承认，镜头下的那些，蝴蝶、蜡烛、文字，几个人，几段回忆，倒也是我所感到的生活或世界的一部分。

世界也总是我所经历的和体验的，向我逼涌而来的。

当我在这世界中短暂存在的几个小时里，拿着我的相机，去想要拍几张照片的时候，这个世界开始在我的心里投影下来。
这世界毁灭也好，在电子媒介中永生而复始也好，确实有在我心里被讲述了。

4
结局时，是的，整个世界已经木了。
趴在那的究竟是什么啊。

我什么也不能做。
那就，拍个照吧。

音乐也好，舞蹈也好，涂鸦也好；照相也好。电子游戏也好。
这是我们纪念、感知、理解这个世界，存在于这个世界的……额……的什么呢？的一点点确证吧。
 
水溅跃
204 produits enregistrés

Recommandé
34.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 30 avril 2022
this is the first time im ever reviewing a game on here but legitimately this game is so so so good. i just bought the dlc, so i have not seen that yet, but the way this game shows its story with no dialogue is just amazing. the bounties urge you to explore all of your surroundings thoroughly + all of the areas have a distinct feel and the messages within the game in regards to the occupation of aotearoa are very blatant and transparent. its really nice to see a game focus on the topics that this one does without sugarcoating anything. my only complaint honestly is just sometimes the platforming is a little janky, but it doesnt take away from the experience of this game too much. 100% recommend.

Moooniper
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
4.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 12 avril 2022
“I know, I know I've let you down
I've been a fool to myself
I thought that I could live for no one else
But now, through all the hurt and pain
It's time for me to respect
The ones you love mean more than anything
So, with sadness in my heart
Feel the best thing I could do
Is end it all and leave forever
What's done is done, it feels so bad
What once was happy now is sad
I'll never love again
My world is ending”
-What I ended up getting


I thought I would get a simple and relaxing photography game, instead I got Umurangi Generation a top notch environmental storytelling in a tight little package.

Gameplay
The game revolves around taking photos that meet a certain criteria, using different filters and processing methods to really give flair to your image, but you’ll soon come to realize that it isn’t a pastime of the main character, and through the lens of their camera you can really have a feel of the world around you.

Story
Why are there barricades around large bodies of water, why your employer penalize you from taking photos of █████ ████ “blue bottles”, are all questions you can answer yourself looking at posters, papers, people’s tattoos.

X-Factor
As I said, the most unique aspect of the game, other than the premise of being put in a little sandbox to take photos and edit them on the spot, is it’s very clever to communicate the feel and story of the world through cleverly constructed environments and details.

Downsides
The game can look and feel rough around the edges, but the worst aspect is that in every stage you’ll be tasked to take a photo of specific things, some of them hidden so much in the background or in places you normally wouldn’t look that it’s not uncommon to wander around for half an hour in an otherwise ten minute level.


It's not very long but it’s rather unique, with it’s own sense of style and with a different kind of approach to storytelling, that’s a recommended from me.

It's neat, doesn't outstay its welcome.
very interesting concept backed up with well produced visuals and strong soundtrack.
You play through a sequence of ISPY puzzles for hipsters with a funky beat playin over em, strung together by a subtle story told through visuals about the last generation of smelly kids gettin pissy about the world bein destroyed.
it's prolly tryin to say something, or just jerking off to evangelion, either way its fun.

worth the price of admission.

866 produits enregistrés

Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
12.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 11 février 2022
This game is the ultimate masterclass example of "Show don't tell", the game and soundtrack has a great story, world building, and atmosphere, without practically saying a single word the entire game.

Gameplay boils down to essentially a first person "I Spy" game where you have to take a photo containing the complete request like "Take a photo with a zoom lens that has 5 birds in it" This is a lot of fun as you scour the level not just for the items in question, but a good place to take the photo so you can get just the right angle.

The clever bit is that asking you to take time to look at everything to find the items forces you to look at things that aren't the item you're looking for, but identifying the environment around you gives you a ton of insight into the world, the people, and what's happening.

The game is super fun, and all the unlockable lenses and upgrades are fun to take back into previous levels to get more creative photos and find new secrets. It's worth picking up and experiencing it for yourself, at least the base game, though if you like the base game, I'd recommend the DLC as it adds new lens options for really interesting photos.

Recommandé
4.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 31 janvier 2022
This is a phenomenal game, and a testament to the capacity of video games to operate as directly political media. For the most part, the game is simply a heap of fun. The photography mechanics work great, the levels are vibrant, and the music slaps. Political commentary is peppered throughout out this on colonialism, the nature of international institutions like the UN, and the environmental crisis. As this is all achieved through environmental storytelling, none of it comes off as heavy-handed, and the player is left with a lot of room to think about things without being forced to. This gives the game's final moments some frankly *incredible* tension and political commentary, as the final levels of both the main game and the DLC are the only times it works in more direct political messaging. The impact of this combo is breathtaking.

I love Umurangi Generation. It has advanced the medium of video games as a whole.
 
blobbins
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
5.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 30 janvier 2022
Have you ever watched Neon Genesis Evangelion, or any other Kaiju-fighting show, and wondered what happens to the citizens of the cities that are destroyed by the collateral damage? When the giant mech shoots it's 1400 mm calibre rounds at the monster, the cartidges have got to land somewhere right? Wouldn't they destroy buildings and cars? Have you ever thought about what it would be like to actually live in a worn-torn cyberpunk city, like Tokyo-3? Do you really think that if an alien invasion ever happened, for real, or any other apocalypse for that matter, that our governments would handle the situation appropriately? If the sea turned to blood, how would you survive, let alone the economy? Umurangi Generation explores those questions, and more, through the medium of photography, exploration, and quiet contemplation.

You play as a young photographer, vibing with your friends and making art, in the last days of earth's existence. Because what else are you gunna do? What else *can* you do?

This game was made initially after the 2019 fires in Australia destroyed so much life, after the direct results of climate change were laid bare for all to see, and no-one seemed to care. Since then, we've seen a similarly tepid response to the Covid pandemic, and I think the DLC (Macro) explores those aspects of generational frustration more than the original game did.

If you're worried about there being 'lame social commentary', or if you think the game might be 'too preachy', then I'd say you can lay those fears to rest -- mostly. The game doesn't have any explicit message, it's objectives simply ask you to look at the environment, and to see the implicit damage for yourself. There's no dialogue even, just diagetic storytelling, through the art direction, clothing, graffiti, music, billboards, and stray newspapers.

Ultimately, this is a game about finding meaning in the end times. Something I'm struggling with a lot at the moment. If you are too, then this is an easy recommendation. The 'red sky generation' are the last people who'll ever live. I'm not sure if *we* are that generation, you and I, that is, but it sure feels like it sometimes...

I also think it's neat that the game saves every photo you take to your harddrive and opens that folder for you when you quit the game. It means that you can literally take something away from the game, as well as metaphorically. In some ways it's also an educational game about photography, and may be a gateway to making art by yourself.

It's art. In every sense of the word.

Oh, and the soundtrack kicks ass too!

Recommandé
2.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 4 janvier 2022
An interesting game that doesn't quite work for me. A game about photography feels like it should be slow-paced and allow you to explore at your leisure but all the tasks - find 10 of these, get this very specific photo, do it all within ten minutes - makes it feel rushed and stressful. The telephoto tasks are a particular headache as you run around each level trying to find one awkward spot where you can get the right items in frame. It's as if they felt they had to gamify what is essentially a walking simulator and the two approaches grate against each other badly.

I'd still say it's worth getting, but with the benefit of hindsight I would have enjoyed it far more if I'd just ignored all the secondary tasks and spent more time with each level, just poking about and entertaining myself first and foremost, and I'd suggest anyone buying it play it that way first too.
 
david.lees78
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
8.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 27 décembre 2021
Umurangi is the kind of game where you get out of it what you put in.
As an objective based game, it tends to be somewhat lackluster. How interesting someone finds this is entirely dependant on their interest in treating the world as a canvas. The main content of the 'story mode' is a list of levels with photo objectives. Capture a few birds in one shot, do a close up on a skateboard, that sort of thing. The joy is in capturing the details of the world through photography.
Stylistically, Umurangi shines with art direction, music, and environmental design that I can only describe as powerfully bold and authoritatively subversive. The whole game feels like a rejection to authority and abuses of power.
I feel the game is at its best when you immerse yourself in the atmosphere it creates, as Umurangi is not carried by the depth of gameplay, rather the mood and story that is conveyed by your own capturing of said atmosphere.
You keep the pictures you take too, which is really cool.
I can say with absolute certainty that this game will not appeal to those solely seeking extrinsic motivation. For those who want a game for style and atmosphere, Umurangi will more than provide if you are willing to look.

many thoughts, most of which have been better articulated by other people. but ig i will say that, being the perhaps Undue optimist that i am, i appreciate some of the little things which convey some kind of Meaning, or at least a gleeful embrace of its own nihilism, beyond the absolutely crushing content of the world around you. mostly i appreciate that your friend group stays together , they never say a single word but their presence, and taking the bonus group photo, is always a weird source of comfort. this very easily could have been a lonely story, but ig its not called Umurangi One Single Dude. we are all in this together

4.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 16 décembre 2021
Pretty cool game!

I really liked how the mechanics all made the biggest strength of it: the environmental narrative. They make you search for words like "xcf" or "cop" and use a very specific lens and make you scour about every face, every word, every thing with full intention of finding something. And that makes you start picking up some of the pieces for a nice and strong message that doesn't seem to get old. We truly are the generation seeing the end of the world. Loved it even if I didn't understand everything.

You do get to make a lot of cool looking photos. Try tilting the camera a lot! This game proves you can make a game entirely about photography and it would be fine.

I would like a more sophisticated movement system, and that the game woudn't be so upfront with a timer. If you see the timer, just don't care about it. Take your photos, find the stuff, make beautiful pieces.
 
XEXÉU, EX VOCALIST OF TIMBALADA
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
4.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 16 décembre 2021
At first glance Umurangi Generation is a chill photography game with artstyle similiar to Jet Set Radio, but once you look closely there is much more depth here. Its environmental story telling is top notch, providing social commentary through its setting of "♥♥♥♥♥♥ futute" that doesn't seem that far off from our own crappy reality. I highly recommend you watch Errant Signal and Super Bunnyhop essays about this game on youtube, they are amazing.
Gameplay wise its very simple. You are equipped with a camera and have to complete photo bounties in each mission by taking photos of specific objects, sometimes with extra requirements, such as using fish eye lense. There are eight levels, each being a small sandbox for you to express yourself creatively.
You start with your basic camera and unlock more specialized lenses, filters and settings for it as you progress through the game and complete extra challenges. I recommend you ingore the time limit and collectibles on your first playthrough and just immerse yourself in this world and try to piece together what's going on. There are many ways to accomplish each bounty and express yourself. Just go wild and experiment with perspective and your equipment!
Music and overall soundscape of Umurangi Generation is one of its strongest points. Its a very unique mix of electronic and hip hop music, which suits the setting perfectly. There are no voices in here, but this game's graffiti and propaganda posters speak volumes.
I have only a few small gripes with Umurangi Generation. Biggest of them being the controls. Movement feels stiff and unresponsive, I also gut stuck on geometry a few times. However, considering that you can't really fail in this game and it doesn't require fast movement its not a big deal. I also found it a bit annoying that you have to manually scroll through your entire selection of lenses and can't just pick it using for example a radial menu. Its a bit tedious, but again, no biggie.
I highly recommend Umurangi Generation if you like photography and enjoy slow paced, chill games with extra depth. For me it was such a nice change of pace from what I usually play. It succeds in almost everything it sets out to do and you owe it to yourself to give it a go. Big kudos to this game's creator Origame Digital!

konjus
685 produits enregistrés
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
10.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 8 décembre 2021
This is a difficult game to review, partly cause Steam does not offer an Undecided/Middle of the Road/Sideways Hand option, but also due to the nature of the game's narrative. These are just my feelings, so take it with a grain of salt where applicable.

Let's start with the gameplay. Someone originally pitched it to me as an avant-garde Pokemon Snap, albeit with more freedom, and I can certainly see the parallels. You roam around in artistic 3D environments taking pictures, unlocking new camera features as you go. While you can snap photos of whatever, there's a limited amount of film and objectives to complete in order to finish a given level. Unlike the Nintendo game, however, Umurangi has somewhat unorthodox methods for judging your photos. I still do not have a firm grasp on what constitutes a "great" scoring photo as the game's tutorial explicitly states such things are subjective. This sounds great on paper, but as an actual mechanic it could certainly stand to be better defined since score is tied to a stage's bonus objectives.

The stages themselves range from cramped, difficult to navigate mazes to open (in a limited way) areas that, nonetheless, still manage to be difficult to navigate for different reasons. You can jump twice, but the second is not terribly effective, and you can crouch. I assume the latter is just for taking variations on a given shot cause I never found it useful in the game itself. I did, on the other hand, get caught on the level geometry repeatedly throughout the game! Sometimes a jump would leave me on an undefined edge where I could slide along but not jump the last few pixels to the spot I was hoping to reach. Other times, I had to shake my character loose from a pipe or other obstruction I'd somehow gotten caught on.

I said you had limited film, and this is true, but it's also somewhat misleading! Every level has a number of tiny, frequently hard to see film canisters hidden throughout, and picking one up will refresh your photo count. Very handy in the few levels with an absurdly high bonus score objective, not that the game informs you of this. Collecting all the film in a level counts as one of the bonus conditions towards unlocking a second camera ability if you do them all in one go. Unfortunately, this means everything from the necessary photos to optional ones and picking up all the hidden film capsules, to boot. They're devilishly easy to overlook. Good luck finding them without a guide!

I'm not trying to be hard on the game, I just personally found it to be as aggravating as it was fun to play. That's ultimately part of my problem with there being a 10-minute time limit being present as part of the bonus conditions. On the surface, it appears to be a game about taking your time, soaking up the atmosphere, and doing your own thing. Yet at the same time it has photo limits, a timer, and a score count.

It also has a neat "recreate the postcard" bonus objective! It's a nice idea. It's also somewhat frustrating. I can take 10 nearly identical photos that don't count but apparently another one will count. Was I slightly to the side? Was my zoom a little different? I have no idea. It's possible to select the pause menu's postcard and get a larger view, but the sometimes dark look of the photo means it's not much help.

This is, unfortunately, another of the game's problems for me; the user interface isn't terribly helpful. The tutorial has a yellow text with no bordering that makes it very difficult to read. The menu options are black text on a white rectangle, like something out of MS Paint; it stands out as odd in an otherwise artistic looking game. There is also the fact that exiting a level takes you back to the title screen instead of the level selection screen. If you're struggling to do everything in 10 minutes, this will become very tedious.

I want to stress that the game is fun to play, it's just that there is plenty which could have done with some more polishing. Gameplay quirks or hang-ups that, while sometimes minor, nonetheless got in the way of my overall enjoyment. If you just wanna run around the environments, taking pictures, and making your way through the unspoken narrative, you will probably enjoy this game.

My other problem with Umurangi, however, has to do with the DLC. This is a lot more subjective than the rest of my review because the additional levels are a lot more aggressive from a narrative standpoint. I don't want to get into it for risk of spoiler, but I certainly found them to be less enjoyable, especially the last two levels. They are all fairly large compared to the main game's level design, and if I understand it right the developer was in an angrier frame of mind when they made them. It uh.. shows. They're visually impressive, as is most of the game, but there is a very distinct mood change from the regular portion of the game.

The last thing I'll comment on is the music. As I played the first few levels I kept thinking, "Gee, all it's missing is some Jet Set Radio-esque music!" because it was just sorta inoffensive, generic background music. Then I heard TARIQ talk during one level and immediately longed for that boring, lifeless music from the earlier stages. I think TARIQ is meant to be memes, or social commentary, I don't know. I just know I did not like TARIQ, Dolphins are neat, though, I appreciated the idea.

I'm bad at summarization, this is far longer than I'd like it to be, and it doesn't feature a handy bullet-point list like some folks use. If you read all of this, I thank you. These are just my thoughts on Umurangi, not a professional review. It's a very interesting game with a unique premise and gameplay we don't see often. I got it on sale; I don't know if I think it's worth the full price. I'd love to see another game that plays similar to it, though!
 
Hiroshi Mishima
1,727 produits enregistrés
0

LilClown
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
6.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 8 décembre 2021
Admittedly I don't believe this game is for everyone; if you lack of patience then this game isn't for you. It is more of a game that you go about finding spots to take pictures of, simple task yes? well to be frank it is simple but also not that simple. The game is very easy to understand that it plays out like 'Hide-N-Seek'; you gotta find place's to take pictures that are easy to find; while some more challenging to find (It does make the game more fun due to this).

If you get lost for a bit by being overwhelmed by the limited time you have; my suggestion on the first run of the game is to not worried about the timer-! There is no game over. You will not get punished even if you stayed in for a hour or so like I have. After your first run, you shouldn't be lost at all if you want to 100% run the game; even with a 10 minute run in each level that it really isn't that hard to get below the 10 minute mark to beat each level. Just do not do it in your first run since the new areas gets you more lost rather than just confused. Only problem I had about playing the game is finding Film Canisters that are spread across the game; but other than that I had no real issues trying to get each level done.

If you are into Interactive Visual Storytelling while playing a genre of video games that plays out more niche from other games. Then this game is for you. It is a beautiful game with a wonderful soundtrack! Is it worth every penny? Of course, every bit of it that it comes with multiple modes after beating it; with many other things you can do with your camera. It even has creative mode that allows you to do whatever you please. I won't speak to much on the story, because it is a visual experience; but I will say that it was a beautiful one.
 
PUMPG33K
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
8.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 6 décembre 2021
Umurangi Generation is a game I didn't have any expectations for when booting it up for the first time. Not high expectations, not low expectations, just a complete blank slate. I ended up being blown away by the experience, which is probably why I felt compelled enough to write a Steam review.

The core gameplay loop is satisfying; sure, you can boil it down to "just taking pictures", but given the variety of tools at your disposal even from the start (that expand as you complete sets of photo bounties) you start to consider the actual compositions of your shots. It never feels like a game where you're expected to know how to actually do photography -- I sure as hell don't -- but it rewards you for experimenting. Being able to save the photos you take into a folder after playing is a nice touch, too.

The entire vibe of this game is probably the strongest selling point, though. Despite there being a time limit to "do well" on your photo deliveries, if you ended up exceeding that time limit it doesn't automatically boot you from the stage. This allows you to actually examine your environment, pick up on the details of what's going on in this world, getting a sense of the injustices that the people you are alongside throughout the entire game are going through. All the while, a varied soundtrack that embraces so many varieties of influences (from microtonal jazz to rough analogue house and many more) matches and enhances the vibe. The stylish low-poly graphics add to this charm, and even help bring the experiences that much more down to earth during its shift in its final act.

Despite the fact that there's no dialogue in the game, you really get a strong sense of what's going on through its environmental storytelling. In fact, taking on the role of a photographer encourages this fact, having you consider your surroundings both from a gameplay perspective and from a human perspective.

TL;DR: Umurangi Generation is a great game, balancing appreciation of photography with a story about indigenous resistance against their oppressors. ♥♥♥♥ yeah. More games by indigenous developers need to be celebrated, this one included.
 
Proxy
768 produits enregistrés
0

The level of control you have and the almost endless amount of different types and levels of photos you can take is truly great, I love it so and i would recommend it 100%. Im gonna be taking lots of pictures and i wont ever stop here!

584 produits enregistrés

Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
5.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 2 décembre 2021
This won't be for everyone, but this was totally for me. It's kinda short, it's kinda buggy in places (but not in a game-breaking way), it's kinda rough around the edges, and all these things, and more, made it really compelling.

At a basic level it's what it says: a game about photography. Wander around 8 different levels and take photos, either trying to hit all the achievements or not. But there's also a story here, one that, for me anyway, was told in a perfect way. It's not spoon-fed, it leaves a lot of wiggle room for your own take on it, yet there's a pretty clear message as well.

The soundtrack really worked for me too.

Do I recommend it? Yup, no question. Will you, the reader, like it? I have no clue; but you might thank yourself for trying it.
 
davepdotorg

Non recommandé
1.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 1 décembre 2021
Giving this a thumbs down but will say there is a lot that i like about it. The general idea, the gameplay and the art are all really good. Unfortunately, the objectives are usually extremely nebulous, requiring shots that are extremely specific, even when there appears to be alternate ways of getting the same shot (see 15 Candles and Cat & Bird objective on the 4th level). It's a bummer that a game that ostensibly encourages experimentation can't recognize when the player experiments. The ten minute time limit on every level doesn't matter at all except for completionists, but still gives me anxiety seeing it tick away, feeling like I'm not fast enough or smart enough. Maybe the sequel will be better. If you want a better, much chiller photography adventure experience I recommend Toem, and Alba: A Wildlife Adventure.

300 produits enregistrés
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
6.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 21 novembre 2021
wonderful wonderful game where you take photographs with a relatively authentic photo-taking and editing experience. you enter a small, digestible stage and are tasked with taking a variety of shots with specific parameters like "Five seagulls" or "A Union Jack". there's a handful of common bonus objectives as well. the photo editing lets you use common sliders found in most photo editing applications. the different lenses also take different kinds of shots just like in real life.

the style and atmosphere is top notch. covid meant I couldn't go outside to shoot (and couldn't see people to shoot either) and this game is a wonderful alternative. the world and 'lore' is super cool too. it is a bit "environmental storytelling through graffiti" but it actually makes sense with the world's punk and dystopic setting.
 
suhfee
195 produits enregistrés
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
2.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 9 novembre 2021
Quick list of issues to note first:
- A bit buggy/jittery. Doesn't run all that well with a few FPS drops here and there.Nothing game breaking, but the camera can jump around a bit as it jumps from 1 FPS and back to normal.
- Double jumping and movement was not that reliable as I would have wanted it to be. A bit annoying traversing a few of the locations.

In general, it's just okay. It's a bit too "artistic" and tedious for me as a scavenger hunt/walking simulator. I wish I could rate this as neutral as I don't necessarily dislike/hate it having come in with no knowledge of the game.

There's definitely a story to be read and questioned over from exploring and completing each area, but I just don't know if the gameplay complemented the world enough and that there's just not enough to explore. There are more situations where you just need to find the right angle for this shot to include X or Y items to progress and that's just not captivating or interesting to do so. I know there are modes that are unlocked after "beating the game" or that it could just be ignored to make it more laid back, but I don't know if each area would keep me captivated long enough to begin with as they are very straightforward and limited events.

I enjoyed what was attempted and especially the music/art style, but I just can't recommend it fully.
 
LoneHer0
439 produits enregistrés
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
10.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 5 novembre 2021
Pretty much a summary of what went wrong with the world in 2021 all neatly packaged into a photography game. If you are wealthy and affluent enough to go into space like Jeff Bezos or Elon Musk, the door is open for you. If not, which you are in this game because you are doing a gig photography job. You're stuck on earth in a permanent state of disrepair, wasting away the time partying to forget the malaise, all while surrounded by giant bluebottles. The game doesn't explicitly tell you this, but you'll know when you see it.

This game doesn't need cutting edge graphics to be entertaining, but there are some imperfections that makes playing a bit irritating. Sometimes you end up getting catapulted into the sky if you walk up a surface, other times you can't even walk up a single step. Keep that in mind.

This game is really good!
The story, while minimal, hits a bit hard with the conclusion - and the photography choices the player can make throughout the game are great.

Évaluation publiée le 7 novembre 2021
As long as you go into this knowing it's about taking photos of a cool world and not much else, I would recommend it. Personally I found the bounty aspect of the game rather tedious, and the timer even more so. I feel these aspects were shoehorned in after someone on the team mentioned that taking just photos wasn't "game-like" enough, to the detriment of the game. That said, the world is cool and interesting, and taking photos of it is satisfying. Don't think it's worth full price, but a good pickup if on sale.

alcadel
374 produits enregistrés
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
7.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 24 septembre 2021
*𝐒𝐍𝐀𝐏* 𝐘𝐞𝐩, 𝐭𝐡𝐢𝐬 𝐨𝐧𝐞'𝐬 𝐠𝐨𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐢𝐧 𝐦𝐲 𝐜𝐫𝐢𝐧𝐠𝐞 𝐜𝐨𝐦𝐩𝐢𝐥𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧.
I know nothing of real photography. I barely know what's going on in the world. Umurangi Generation doesn't care: but the people within it do. This game and it's Macro expansion have a lot to say but you have to seek it out.

My favourite part about this is game is how the gameplay is so interwoven with it's narrative, everything you learn comes from your exploration, your willingness to interact with the world. You can simply brush past everything and just focus on completing objectives but you won't want to. You're given an insanely fun arsenal of camera equipment, even if you've never dabbled into photography before this game I think theres so much there to observe in it's vast environments that you'll end up wanting to be creative. It's easy to pickup but challenging to master, it's a deep art form but fortunately the game doesn't ever require you to have your photos actually 'look-good', since there's subjective argument but instead it simply needs what is asked to be present within any given frame.

Despite that you'll be encouraged to seek out fun angles, techniques and play around with the different post-processing options to the point that you'll forget about completing objectives. Then when you finally get to them, overtime they'll progressively get more 'out-of-the-box' requiring the practice that at that point you will have picked up naturally.

This game overall is short, it'll last you about 3 hours at most; but what it does with that time is so gripping that I'm desperate to recommend this to anyone who hasn't played it. That's not to say there isn't no replay value because if you're anything like me, after you've played this you'll wanna give the speedrun or creative modes a shot.
 
Rosalyn
1,406 produits enregistrés
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
11.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 24 septembre 2021
The movement is clunky and occasionally glitches out (things like having gravity affect you while still having 0 y movement, causing the moment you get to move downwards to make the character shoot down with far too much y velocity).

That's the only downside I can think of at the time of playing. It's a game that, at first, was made with concern over the world. The Macro DLC is downright angry. And it works. The cyberpunk aesthetic works for the vibe the game is going for, the "no photographing the blue bottles" tells all the story it needs to without having 100 hour long cutscenes. It works.

And I am ashamed at the society that it suggests we are.

Also you have a penguin friend. Yes please.
 
TokenOracle
427 produits enregistrés
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
7.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 23 septembre 2021
I picked this up because I like the idea of a photography game and I really like the art style. I was very surprised to have played this and found that it was telling quite a story through the photography. There are a bunch of levels to the game and each one you get to explore and take photos. You have a specific list of things to take pictures of, but you can run around and explore and do what you want. As you progress through the levels, you start to learn more about the world and learn why things are the way they are. I didn't expect to have such a deep story revealed through taking pictures like this, but I'm happy I was able to experience it. The levels are small, but very detailed leaving you plenty to photograph. You eventually unlock filtered to edit your photos and different lens types, like the fish eye lens. As a photographer myself, I find the photography mechanics to be fairly realistic. It's a game and some corners are cut, but having some control over depth of field, lens type, and photo editing was pleasant to experience in a game. My only complaint is that it's a bit short. I completed the story in about 6 hours. It does look like there is a dlc with a lot more content, so I hope to check that out eventually. Anyways, if you like creative and relaxing games, definitely give this a try and test out your photography skills.

Runs perfectly on Linux with Proton Experimental.

Évaluation publiée le 3 juillet 2021
What a great game, the art-style is very pleasant and minimalist, but accomplishes a lot. Picture taking is fun and being rewarded each level with a new way to experiment with photos is great.

While the game is about photography, it doesn't lazily throw you into a generic urban environment to take pictures in, small details of ongoing crises and the gloomy future, making it interesting to explore each level to learn small titbits about the fictional world that you are photographing.

Other than jumping being a bit iffy sometimes (which is such a small issue anyways) and objectives not wanting to be completed (can be a little annoying sometimes), this is a great game for people that enjoy taking pictures of things or are interested in the idea. Please buy the game and give it a try.

shadowdead12

Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
4.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 27 juin 2021
I didn't know what to expect before playing Umurangi Generation, but it suprised me with its sense of character, open level design, and storytelling through lore and structure. I loved the deep photo mechanics, with the ability to swap lenses and change various elements of the shot including bloom, exposure, and tint. But you don't NEED to like taking photos to enjoy this game, in fact I think you may have more fun if you don't. Objectives push you to find a checklist of items and you can scavenge the levels finding whatever you'd like, taking random pictures in between. The non-linearity contained within each level allows the player to see what they want from each level and learn about the world at their own pace. There is a story in this game, and although there is no dialogue, there is an astounding amount of emotion running through the game's levels, as well as its music and art style. Quite an interesting experience, and one I recommend strongly, especially to aspiring....or uninspired photographers.
 
pluggedintogaming

Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile

Recommandé
2.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 7 juin 2021
Umurangi Generation is a fantastic few hours. You will not be challenged with intense gameplay, or balancing lots of systems. You will be sent into a dying world with nothing more than your camera and your friends. You have objectives, but your photos are not graded on a quality scale. The game itself in its tutorial insists that it's unfair to grade art objectively. Your photos are your own expression, with each objective having usually one or two places you can complete it on a map.

It's not a long game, but the little time it holds you for is a great time. It's chill and beautiful, all backed up with a fantastic score by ThorHighHeels (who has a great YouTube channel if you like obscure Japanese video games btw).

This isn't a game for someone who wants a very active, demanding experience. It's a game whose value is what you find in it. If you've ever just wanted to get lost exploring a game world, snapping photos to remember it by, this might be the game for you.

And even if you're on the fence, if you catch it on a good sale, I think you should give it a try.
 
UncrownedJules

Recommandé
6.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 29 mai 2021
Absolutely one of my favorite games of 2020. Take the anti-establishment teenagers of Jet Set Radio and set them mid-apocalypse documenting Kaiju attacks, environmental and economic collapse, and a UN occupation and do it in the style of Pokemon Snap. Bleak, heartbreaking, colorful, irreverent, wonderfully cynical. This game perfectly captured the absurdity of the world around me as I played it during the peak of the pandemic and civil unrest of the summer of 2020. Add in an incredible soundtrack and some of the best environmental storytelling I've ever seen and it's an easy recommend from me.

crazy guy
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
13.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 22 mai 2021
It is a Film! Zoom Back Camera!

Seeing the end of the world from another continent, and I'm proud of that Jodorowksy reference leave me alone

UMURANGI Generation is THE photo mode that you actually want to play with. Okay, maybe I'm overselling it, hear me out.

It's a good on-its-way-to-be-great photography game with a few mechanical flaws. I kept asking myself what does this game wanted to be. If it's meant to simulate the adventurous photographer experience, then it has done its job pretty well.

I'm just gonna list down the flaws real quick:
- the movement system can be a bit stiff sometimes
- the camera would detect faraway targets that're outside of the visible frame
- the targets of the objectives can be a bit finicky for the frame to detect
- the depth of field effect radius probably needs more refinement
- that's it I guess

From this point on, my comment on the game will be heavily subjective with mild spoilers.
I kinda love this game. I got all the achievements and I kept on playing because the game is just that fun of a space to run around, especially after I unlocked all the late game upgrades.

The hunt for the film canisters, let's say that's my least favorite part. I mean I get it, they're meant to highlight certain parts of the maps that I would've not look at otherwise, but *insert Rich Evans' 'oh my god' here*

What keeps me coming back are the aesthetics for sure, the Jet Set Radio charm (including its jankiness) is definitely here. The game's vibes, man. Enhanced by beautiful colors, fun soundtracks, and all this cultural bonfire surrounded by these quite bleak worrying subject matters.

The environmental storytelling showcased the idea of helplessness for being a mere citizen, witnessing large conflicts and catastrophes that no one has control over. As a citizen of a Commonwealth country, I think I can kinda sympathize with the Maori presented here. All these wars and geopolitical talking points are just too much for one person to bear, and for this game's case all the player can do is take nice pictures and say
"I was there when it happened."
Yeah it's a bit depressing, but that's that. I'm too stupid to talk more about this.

The photo shooting mechanic is great. All the clickety-clack sound effects are just as satisfying as an M1 Garand ping. Climbing around these levels reminded me of my own college photographic experience, my mates and I went to places that we shouldn't. We tinkered with the ISO, aperture, shutter speed just to make dumb pictures that nobody will see. This game gets it.

Recommendation-wise, if you're a photography fan, get it whenever you can.
If you're looking for a game to chill and just wander around, this game would be a nice detour.
Niche as hell. You have been warned.

Sequel wishlist:

- extensive camera angle manipulation
- hotkeys for the lens
- include any form of optical illusions or gestalt imagery
- functional halfpipes?
- more camera types? (a TLR camera maybe? no? okay...)

That MGS 2 reference, dude
 
Kensonaga
0

Ceschi
947 produits enregistrés
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
6.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 19 mai 2021
A fantasic game that encourages artistic self expression and exploration.

You slip into the role of a photographer, who is tasked with photographing specific objects or words, like "1 Cat & 2 Birds" or "The word Squid". Some objectives are even a bit open to interpretation. After taking a photo the game will quickly rate it and give you some money which basically represents your score. You will do this in a variety of cool looking cyberpunk levels with a PS1 aesthetic. Each level is like a little open world and the objectives can be tackled in any order and in multiple ways.
The challenge mostly comes from certain restraints, like having to use a specific lense that is only effective at certain distances or has trouble capturing multiple objects. Another challenge you can impose on yourself are the optional objectives, which are however always the same in every level.
You will also have a wide variety of tools avaible, with which you can play with however you like. As mentioned before, you will unlock different lenses like a telescopic lense, which allows for photos with a lot of depth of field and makes it easier to capture far away objects, but has a narrow field of vision. On the other extreme is the fish eye lense, which makes it easy to capture multiple objects at close range and warps the picture in stylish ways, but has no depth of field and is useless when the object is far away. Besides the lenses you can also unlock some filters, with which you can edit your photo immediately after shooting it but has no effect on the rating.
The game isn't just a neat street-photography simulator however, it actually has a plot which carries through each level. There aren't cutscenes or any dialogue, instead it's all visual storytelling. Lets just say that all of the levels have some stuff going on in them, placards you can read and recurring motives, that imply what's going on in the world outside the small levels.
 
Gumbone

pellegreene
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
14.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 4 mars 2021
I love photo modes in games. I'll drain hours taking pictures and tweaking settings to get something that's remotely passable as "artistic".

I especially like it when a photo mode gives me full motion control of the camera, allowing me to shoot photos from whatever position I want to get the perfect angle. Unbound from the player character, I can frame any scene in such a way that tells a self-contained story.

Bonus points if a photo mode can make me instantly change poses and facial expressions, and even hide characters altogether. Throw in the ability to change the time of day to adjust the in-world lighting, impose cinematic black borders, and slap on logos of the studio and the game itself, and you've got the transformative power to make your own little narratives out of these digital worlds.

Umurangi Generation is a game that's ostensibly for those who like photo modes in video games yet denies the decontextualization that such modes enable.

You cannot photograph that dance party in the VR-cade block, bursting with youthful energy, without the massive UN "EMERGENCY LOCKDOWN PROTECTIVE BARRICADE" looming in the background.

You cannot photograph the subway crowded with face-masked citizens corralled by automatic rifle-toting soldiers without the neon billboards advertising escapism via end-of-the-world movies and military enlistment propaganda.

You cannot photograph beautiful candle arrangements without memorials to loved ones who died in a catastrophic, reality-shaking event.

You cannot photograph your cool friends without seeing cyber-streetpunk fashion mixed with Maori stylings and New Zealand iconography.

You cannot photograph the word "COPS" without the following words "ARE DIRTY" or "COME HERE TO KILL US".

You have to painstakingly position your character within the world, never once being able to detach yourself from your body, and manually shuffle through the different lenses and their varying levels of zoom and depth of field to get your job of delivering particular pictures done for dollars you don't get to spend.

And you cannot stop that timer from ticking, constantly reminding you of all the pressures it represents like blowing deadlines and opportunities, well past the point of no return.

So why not take the moment to listen to the best soundtrack of 2020 and be present in the time and space Umurangi Generation demands you to inhabit, examine, and reflect on, as we ourselves live through the slow-motion apocalypse of neoliberal decay?
 
joseph
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
1.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 3 mars 2021
i absolutely love everything about this game except for the heinous level design and poopy diaper controls. agree with all the praise, it's unique and a lot to love but damn...it just feels like total garbage to wander around. in a game about wandering around, i feel like that kind of matters.

dope soundtrack though, i want to love this game but the jank won't let me (and this is from someone who can get down with pretty high levels of jank).

3.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 25 janvier 2021
Amazingly atmospheric world set up with so little fanfare. No dialogue, no action, and still somehow one of my favorite video game experiences of the last 5 years. Incredible soundtrack by ThorHighHeels sets a mood I've been happy to be stuck in ever since I finished this game. All of that aside, just a really fun time to take pictures in these cool environments and sus out what led to this '♥♥♥♥♥♥ future'.
 
PunchFaceChamp
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
26.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 22 janvier 2021
Oh my god this game is amazing. The world the game is set in just sucks you in, it just feels so alive with all these little stories going on in the background, people hanging out with friends, protests, memorials, and the actual story is absolutely insane, but really cool. What's more is that none of it is directly told to you, its all in the background, left for you to figure out. And the gameplay? It's absolutely superb, allowing you a ton of control without it being too complex for beginners. The game is absolutely gorgeous too, giving off a more chill JSR vibe, which makes it a joy to photograph. The music gives off that same chill JSR vibe, heavy use of samples and it's an absolute jam, man. Also, hot tip: get the DLC. It features some really good upgrades like the ability to sprint and get really close to the ground (which really helps you get some really good shots) and some fantastic levels to boot. In summary: get this game, and the DLC.
 
addderalll
209 produits enregistrés
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
17.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 22 janvier 2021
Tells a story all by using the world around you. The world is falling apart and all you can do is watch and take photos.

You go around the map and take photos. To complete a level you have to find all the bounties. To get an extra unlockable you do the same but you have to find film, reach a money quota, take a photo of all your friends, yes the penguin too, recreate a post card, and drop off the package in 10 minutes.

This game is very experimental and I love it.

Lets Teamwork! <3
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
3.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 17 janvier 2021
If this game did not have a timer running on every stage, it might have been my game of the year. As it is, the experience was slightly ruined by what is an optional goal to complete the objectives within a time limit. Even though I knew it was optional, I still had a hard time ignoring the timer and found myself rushing through the levels instead of soaking in the atmosphere and the story. And that is too bad, because the atmosphere and the story in Umurangi Generation is absolutely amazing. I love the way that this game tells its story through what are essentially 3D tableaus. This is environmental story telling done right and it utilizes the medium of video games in a beautiful way. It also has an amazing soundtrack and an incredible ending.
 
Roarer
581 produits enregistrés
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
35.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 16 janvier 2021
i heard about this game at the very tail end of 2020, and immediately got attached to it, being a fan of punk and photography already individually.
i played the entire game start to credits yesterday, and the dlc this morning, and, im happy to say that not only did i enjoy it, but its probably one of my favourite games full stop!
unfortunately, some of the levels made me sort of anxious, after i realised you could run out of film, and the timer always being visible on screen (while also not showing up on the level complete sreen and still coutning on fadeout!), in addition to getting overwhelmed by all the bounties.
i think maybe it would've be more enjoyable had you been able to sort of find bounties as you progress in the level, in order to make it less daunting, since i genuinely felt like i was put into option paralysis at the beginning of some of the levels.something that would also help is have a hotkey to display the bounties on screen all at once, quality of life stuff like that
film is less significant since, i understand it is a part of the game design, but it would be nice if at some point the game just gave you unlimitted film at least (haven't 100% it yet, so maybe it is and i dont know!). though, at the same time i kinda wish there were in game hints to help guide the player since some things are really tough and, more importantly, frusterating to find
i also kinda wish there were sliders for things like iso and apeture, as is i never want to play with the options because of how long it takes to cycle options and experiment, in addition to the develop menu being more complete, like, being able to back out without consuming film, letting sliders youre click holding be adjusted when the menu is invisible, making the menu a lot more user friendly on controlelrs, stuff like that
on controllers !! would love if you could use both a controller and mouse/keyboard at the same time, since it would really help for speedrunners who have preferences for different actions, and make the game much more accesbile to people with unique physical situtations, like myself, who cant hold a key down comfortably for long periods but nudging a stick feels fine.

anyways, the game!! thigns i liked
i loved the games completely silent and almost entirely static storytelling, it pulls it off incredibly well and i dont think ive ever felt so attached to a group of silent protagonists like this before
the aesthetic and setting is awesome. theres a train level, i like that :).
a ton of options for taking pictures and i always want to go back and find new shots and execute ideas, especially not being able to go out and take my pictures under lockdown.


i want to, try and provide as many issues i had so the game has the oppurintity to be the best it can, so i gonna add things as i go,
- stairs are really obnoxious to take photos with since they are really buggy
- no way to begin hovering prior to a triple jump, and no way to drop from a hover and begin hovering again, which makes readjusting shots on the hover boots really painful
- no way to lock your ground speed makes it so its really easy to slide of small terrain and forces you to continually jerk back up
- roller blades leave a trail even when u enter camera view, and, on the flip side, it disapears which makes taking pictures of the trails really stressful or maybe impossible

Évaluation publiée le 15 janvier 2021
Absolute banger of a game. Lots of fun exploring the often oppressive urban cyberpunk environments just making art. Yet to touch the DLC but in the base game alone you're given a wealth of creative options for taking pictures. Outside of that creative aspect the objectives in each level are fun to go for too, it's tons of fun trying to run through a level as fast as possible and try to complete all the objectives in under 10 minutes. Best cyberpunk game of 2020.

d00m95
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
30.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 11 janvier 2021
Absolutely fantastic game. Bounced off it the first time I tried to play because the time limits in each level spooked me, but I'm SO glad I came back and tried again. Now I can't stop playing it. It should be noted that the time limits are only an extra layer of challenge, and you don't need to follow them to progress (though if you beat them it does unlock certain equipment upgrades).

Looks great, the soundtrack is banging (also very funny at times), and the story is one that keeps revealing more layers the longer you play. It's sad and angry and beautiful and life-affirming and terrifying and one of the best games I've played in a long while. A game for our f**ked up times.

les beans
218 produits enregistrés
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
3.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 7 janvier 2021
I haven't finished the game yet but the level of detail and creativity here is astounding. Don't be fooled by a slightly simple aesthetic, there is a ton of polish, charm, and intention put into almost every corner. The presentation also consistently draws you in to this world, leaving you feeling like you can play "just one more level". Even if somehow the last couple levels I have left completely drop the ball (I doubt it) this will be well worth the purchase and I don't think I'd change my tone about this review.

Highly recommend, especially if you're interested in making games or games criticism

Évaluation publiée le 2 janvier 2021
This game is absolutely amazing to play. I highly recommend trying it out, and look through the environmental storytelling. Get this game.
 
IceColeBrew
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
1.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 1 janvier 2021
Produit remboursé

I don't suffer from motion sickness but this game somehow made me motion sick. You feel like a slow moving tennis ball on a stick with wheels duct taped on the bottom rather than a character. So I had to refund.

My ideal movement for a game like this would be something like Titanfall, quickly zipping from location to location to take shots with my camera. This isn't what I was looking for.

Also, not a huge fan of the Playstation 1 style graphics. I don't feel motivated to take photos of any of the NPCs as they just stand idling staring into the distance. It's not dynamic, unpredictable or fun to capture static models.
 
Vintage Comfy

Évaluation publiée le 1 janvier 2021
The amount of care and detail put into this game's levels and worldbuilding is incredible! I strongly recommend this to anyone looking for a short game that understands what it means to be cyberpunk and fills its environments to the brim with personality. Controls are a little slow but, given this is a game you want to take your time with and soak in, it's probably for the best.

Évaluation publiée le 29 décembre 2020
Umurangi Generation is a chill game with a memorable style, environment, and soundscape. The immerse and detailed photography simulation creates engaging gameplay. Each level's unique settings and soundtrack have me wanting to return to them just to re-experience their vibe. Thor High Heels music for the game is something I could have playing in the background on repeat. It sets an unforgettable mood. (Also, I highly recommend checking out his YouTube channel). Everyone clealry put their all into this game and it shows. It is a brief but exciting experience.
 
PotatoSaladGuy
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
12.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 25 décembre 2020
At its surface, Umurangi Generation is a vibrant and charming game about taking pictures with an upgrade-able camera while you listen to an absolute bop of a soundtrack. Each level gives you a list of things you need to take pictures of while utilizing different lenses, with bonus objectives that net you more equipment and photo editing tools. Each picture is essentially a puzzle, in that you have to find where the listed photo subject is and how you have to photograph it, allowing for a great deal of artistic liberty all the while. The gameplay itself is relaxing and engaging, with plenty of replay value. But where this game truly shines is its narrative.

This game is a fantastic example of environmental storytelling at its finest. It lets the looming narrative seep slowly into each level, leaving it up to you to pay attention and piece things together. There's graffiti on the walls, characters interacting in certain ways, lighting/ambiance, posters, advertisements, etc. that all paint a bigger picture. Combined with an amazing soundtrack and satisfying sound design, it creates extremely effective moments that still occupy my head long after finishing the game. And this game pulls no punches, especially in the Macro DLC. Though exaggerated by kaiju and Evangelion-inspired mechs, the underlying themes are all very real. Governments failing to respond appropriately to national crises, authority figures abusing power for dominance over the people they're supposed to protect, and much more broadly, younger generations paying the price for the actions of the people that came before them. Words can't do justice to describe just how effective this game is at delivering its points, it simply begs to be experienced, seen and heard.

Umurangi Generation feels like hanging out with friends, and you don't want the good times to stop. You don't want to stop enjoying the colorful graffiti on the walls, the dancing cyberpunks, or the amazing music. But the whole time, you're painfully aware that it won't last. Amidst all the bright, lively locales is an ever-nearing threat. And you can't tell if the real threat is the kaiju invading your hometown, or the militaristic police force that's always been there.
 
LargeIcedPumpkin

I seriously didn't know what to expect going into the game, but it ended up being an amazing time. You can play around and try to make really good looking, creative photos or you can rush around trying to get all of the required photos as quickly as possible and both play styles feel really rewarding.

One of my favorite parts of the game though is the worldbuilding. Just by playing in the game for a few hours you get a vivid feeling of what it's like to live in this ♥♥♥♥♥♥ future. Genuinely an amazing time, I highly recommend it.

Évaluation publiée le 15 décembre 2020
Umurangi Generation is likely going to be my favourite game from this year. I don't think I've been "into" a game faster than the first 90 seconds I spent inside this one. The music is amazing, each environment is brimming with creative ways to capture it, and the overall narrative that plays out is worth seeing through your own lens.

I also love photography/mechanics. The ways you can quickly edit photos is really satisfying. After being in a bit of a slump creatively, I feel renewed to try some different lenses and ideas IRL because of Umarangi Generation, and that's pretty cool.

6.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 11 décembre 2020
Okay, third try here, Steam ♥♥♥♥♥♥' sucks. My playtime for this fantastic game is really 10 hours, the time you see here plus 3.4 hours through GOG Galaxy 'cause ♥♥♥♥ Steam. Steam's a corp hack and so is CDPR, so probably gonna switch to Playnite.

Anyway, this game ♥♥♥♥♥♥' rocks, get it. Best photography game I've ever had the pleasure of playing, and it is probably one of the first serious photo games I've seen or played. It's not photo mode the game, you're on the ground crouchin' with the people takin' shots of their boomboxes and neon-painted clothes. You're a punk tryin' to make ends meet, slippin' by UN barricades to photograph whatever the current assignments are.

The primary & bonus objectives encourage you to be thorough, fast, and have a sharp eye, but since the bonus objectives are optional, ya can also ignore'em and play chill. Nevertheless, if you're the type after more of a challenge, the bonus objectives are there to give you an incentive to replay and try to improve. Although, really, the atmosphere & tunes alone should be enough to keep ya comin' back, which by the way, grab the soundtracks, grab the DLC, and enjoy some harder hittin' scenes to shoot in the Macro DLC.

Base game's phenomenal and punk af, and Macro doubles down while giving you even more toys to play with. Easily one of my top games of 2020, and I highly encourage you to check it out if the aesthetics catch your eye or you're into virtual photography. This game ♥♥♥♥♥♥' rocks.
