5.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 1 décembre 2020
In high school, I had to take classes in photography. I hated it. For years after, I occasionally took photos, but had classified photography as something that was "not for me". I heard about Umurangi Generation from a review on youtube, and decided to check it out, as maybe I had passed judgement on an entire medium of art unfairly. It turns out I had done that. Through interesting levels with great worldbuilding and incrementally giving the players new toys to play with, this game made me see that much more can be done with a camera than what I was shown in class. I love this game, and it is absolutely my game of the year for 2020.
 
BeowulfDragon
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
5.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 1 décembre 2020
Light spoilers follow:

I wasn't sure what to expect when I bought this game, but I was really surprised. Umarangi Generation is a really minimal game that tells a huge story simply by making you an observer of the people and environments within a war-torn sci-fi world. You play as a point-and-shoot street photographer / photojournalist, of sorts, tasked with taking photos of an assortment of subjects, gradually unlocking new lenses and photo-editing tools as you go along. There's very little dialogue outside of the tutorial and you're free to explore and compose your shots as you wish (the game is more or less agnostic about the artistic quality of your photos). There are big nods to sci-fi touchstones like Jet Set Radio and Evangelion along with an excellent electronic soundtrack.

But while the photography scavenger hunt mechanics and lo-fi cyberpunk aesthetics are what initially drew me in, but the real hook for me was getting to explore the world and unlocking the next level to see another puzzle piece of the story. It's a world that's at times both gritty and colorful and the developers really seem to focus in on all the tonal juxtapositions of life in wartime as well as how young adults (and penguins) find ways to thrive in the midst of violence and authoritarianism. It's a game that invites big questions. I found myself thinking a lot about how a big, unwieldy experience like war is both clarified and obscured through the lens of a camera.

Really a one-of-a-kind experience. Highly recommend.

Absolutely love it.

Only the "bonus unlock" mechanic doesn't really fit in my opinion and seems to be mostly here for video game reasons. Would have much more enjoyed getting the extra stuff as a result of finding hidden stuff, instead of rushing through it with a guide.
 
Dr. Strangethumb
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
4.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 28 novembre 2020
I'd heard Umurangi Generation really highly recommended for its environmental storytelling and soundtrack and style, but I wasn't sure if I'd enjoy the actual gameplay of taking photographs. In real life when I try to take photos in real life I often impatient trying to figure out how to capture something as interesting as the view I can see through my eyes with the limited perspective of my phone camera.

Taking interesting photos is easier in a designed space like this: levels are very dense with interesting details and people and contrasts, and you can often clamber up high to get a new perspective on things - I've found it fun trying to piece together interesting shots, and the game introduces new filters and tools slowly enough that even more fairly-photo-illiterate self can keep up and feel like each new option adds things.

The thematic/scifi/setting stuff going on is great as lots of people have said, but it does also do a great job of making "take cool photos!" fun and accessible IMO.
 
determinedhobbit

I've been doing photography in real life for just over a year now and just upgraded to a full frame camera. Umurangi Generation is a fantastic introduction to photography at your own pace and with a beautiful style. Plus the new DLC continues with the very timely for 2020 themes.
 
Doctor Game
2,657 produits enregistrés
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
11.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 27 novembre 2020
Umurangi Generation is just what I needed. While it's movement may be janky and it's optimization poor, the Dreamcast-esque visuals, thumping soundtrack and wonderfully in-depth photography system makes up for it. Almost every level is a banger with complimentary design and wonderful variety in visuals. The only major flaws I've found is that some targets are way to specific, often "hampering my style" and making some levels infuriating when they'd otherwise be consistently fun. If you love the idea of a sandbox photography game with a visually unique world to explore, give Umurangi a chance!

Just Offscreen
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
6.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 26 novembre 2020
I picked this up last night and meant to just play it for a bit before bed, but Umurangi Generation is so engrossing I had to see the story all the way through before I could put it down. It's an awesome ride that will keep surprising you all the way to the end. Its soundtrack and visual style will immerse you in a world with a rich history with many layers to peel back as you work through your scavenger hunt list in each area on the road trip.

The photography system is robust and accessible, making it a fun toy for amateurs to play with and a very powerful tool suite for people with more of an interest in photography. While setting up your shots, figuring out where to get the right angle or something, and noodling with your photos, you're left with a lot of time to think about what's going on in this world and what you haven't seen yet, which makes sure every time you get the answers to those questions it packs a punch like a freight train.

It's an awesome story told in a unique way in a complete, compact package with plenty of bonus challenges and extra unlockables to keep you going if you want more.

1,730 produits enregistrés

Recommandé
5.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 22 novembre 2020
The "vibe" of this game is fantastic - the lofi/vaporwave aesthetic is executed beautifully here through the visuals and the soundtrack.

However, what truly makes Umurangi Generation shine is the visual storytelling and the themes it touches upon, very much inspired by real world events (2020 in general tbh).
Soak in the world, take some photos, and hang out with your virtual friends.

Also get the DLC, it's a fantastic expansion to the base game
 
PapaPolski
1,235 produits enregistrés
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
19.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 20 novembre 2020
This game does everything it can to make an enjoyable experience out of taking photographs in a "♥♥♥♥♥♥ Future." Everything from lenses to color settings, to trying to find a good angle to get the perfect shot is so amazing. I only have a few complaints about this game and the only one that is worth bringing up is that the base game only has 2 stances for taking photos (crouching and standing up, as well as laying down added as an unlockable in the DLC). But this isn't that big of an issue because even with this shortcoming the game more than makes up for it with all of the other unlockables and things it allows you to do with your pictures, and if you want to do editing to your pictures that the game doesn't have, all you have to do is go to the games gallery folder where it outputs your pictures. This is a game where artistry meets fun and it really got me interested in photography. There is a laundry list of objectives in each level that challenge you to meet them, but if you're anything like me that's not what will keep drawing you back in, what will keep drawing you back in is the freedom this game gives you to just take pictures and have fun doing it.

If I had to describe my feelings about this game in one sentence it would be this: I want MORE!

6.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 7 novembre 2020
Aggressively good game with an incredible soundtrack and great themes. It is a game that understands the current moment so perfectly well that it is, in my opinion, should be considered a top priority when studying art and counter culture released in 2020.

It manages to portray the bleakness of a dark future with surprising hope, as one day there will be a last generation.

I could honestly write so many pieces about this game, but much more eloquent people than me already have.

With the MACRO DLC it takes those core themes and runs with it even harder.

This game is truly worth your time and will end up being a classic of the medium.

Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
13.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 7 septembre 2020
A wonderful, moody and atmospheric game in an older, PS1 style.
The game is a first person "shooter", in the more old fashioned sense. You explore through several densely packed areas armed with a camera and a bounty list of what needs to be photographed. The adventure starts off very point and click, but as you progress, and the story opens up, more options for your camera are unlocked as well. From different lenses, to colour, contrast, and lighting options, you can revisit old stages and see them in ways you couldn't before.

This beautiful apocalyptic photography sim is easy to get lost in, and I hope that you do.
 
SirRossington
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
71.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 23 juillet 2020
I've put a ridiculous amount of time into this inspired photography sandbox.

Umurangi Generation's low-poly cyberpunk dystopia is a joy to explore with ThorHighHeels' incredible soundtrack. The game goes beyond 'wow cool future' cyberpunk, with a world that takes today's problems to their natural sci-fi conclusions and expresses those ideas through amazing environmental storytelling.

It's also a wonderful game to relax in, revisiting levels and taking even more photos in ways you hadn't before.

A HUGE recommend, whether you're a photography pro or if the only photography you've done is on your 3DS' front facing camera.

Kitsu289
429 produits enregistrés

Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
9.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 21 aout 2020
Take photos during the end of the world.

Umurangi Generation is a dedicated photography game with a hint of speed-running. You can either snap photos just to score points or really dig into the different camera lens unlocks and filters.

It's set in a future New Zealand with an emphasis on Maori culture, disillusionment, graffiti, and a great big dash of Neon Genesis Evangelion.

There's a larger world and story at play that you can pick up from the environment, but as a photographer you're just a witness to these final set-pieces of future.

Max nut
540 produits enregistrés
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
5.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 7 aout 2020
I suck at writing reviews but I just can't put this one off.

Umurangi Generation is one of those games that will stick with me for a long time.
The soundtrack and world building are stupendous. The photography aspect is well and good, and its why I initially purchased the game. But once I started really getting into it I noticed I was way more enamored just exploring the environments and reading all the signs/advertisements to piece together this world i'm in. There is no dialogue, yet I grew attached to my buddies throughout the game.

I'm not sure what this visual style is called (i would really love to know if it has a name) but i get strong Quadrilateral Cowboy vibes from it. The models remind me of the early 00's/Playstation 1 era games. It fits so well though, i'd like to see this style used more often.

This game is worth full price all day to most people. And I feel like if you are immediately digging the game just by the pictures on the store page you wouldn't have any regrets making the purchase. If you are on the fence, there's a demo that does a perfect job at giving you an idea of what the game is. At least try that!

Oh, and ignore the countdown timer. I didn't pay it any mind during my entire playthrough. Please don't rush the experience just for the time bonus. It's not worth it. Relax and explore.

I really hope Origame Digital does well with this title so they can make more experiences like this. They are right up there on my stalking list next to Sukeban Games for the foreseeable future.

tanakataro
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
4.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 21 juillet 2020
Spoiler Free Review: This game is for people who are into art of all kinds, who prefer to use art to express themselves more, and maybe people who feel anxious in the current pandemic. I strongly recommend you go into the experience totally blind, like I did. There's tons of awesome environmental storytelling that's enjoyed best with fresh eyes.

I can't describe how much this game has meant to me, especially now in mid 2020. The cyberpunk art style is cool and might callback early y2k aesthetic, but its really product of -this- time and I hope more game enthusiasts will take a look at it when they reflect on this year. The low poly graphics and unsteady controls gave me motion sickness. I had to take a lot of breaks, but I played it all the way to the end. I would argue that it's the best photography game ever made. There's so many games that try to tell me what to think with their gameplay, but Umurangi Generation was the first I've played that honestly asked me what I thought. I loved it and I hope it finds more people who will love it, too.
 
ChicMonster
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
8.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 19 juillet 2020
A first person photography game that uses Māori symbolism and Jet Set Radio as influences to show how the generation with no future deals with the end. Take pictures of your friends, the environment, and people at the end of the world caused by environmental issues and a kaiju attack from the sea. Each of the levels range from you and your friends in towns full of memorials and film and recruitment posters, street dance parties before the world's end, bloody combat zones, train rides of survivors, etc. Unlock new lenses, camera options, editing options by finishing levels and completing objectives. Gives you a lot of options to take pictures how you want once you unlock everything and are no longer trying to finish under time constraints.

Jumping can be awkward with double jumps not always working or falling through things you would think you could stand on. Unlocking the hover boots pretty much removes the issue in addition to opening up some nice photo opportunities.

Screenshots: https://twitter.com/Legolas_Katarn/status/1284713563769024515

8.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 7 juillet 2020
I really really want to do this game justice, but I feel like no words will - this is a game you need to xperience, because talking about it or even just wathcing someone else paly is just not it. It is good. And if you are even thinking you might like - you will. If you're not sure - it is the best digital stroll you can take, with your head in the clouds.

This game did so many things for me. It is a relaxing experience for the fans of looking around in the game, exploring the details and enjoying environmental storytelling. And boy, does this game have a story! A "show don't tell" done right. The music by Thor Highheels is just the best pick for such a ride andit all builds up to a very very pleasant time spent. The brilliant part - it is a digital equivalent of a lazy stroll through Hongkong-like environment. If you want it to be. Or it can be a point-scoring rush if you want it to be and a very enjoyable at that.

Basically - a very good game. I want more of this and more from these guys.

While it is a short game, the mechanics are solid. There's a growing catalog of effects and lens to make use of as you play, giving you a reason to go back and play other levels again to get a better pay at the end of level which is your score in this game. Spire.dmg
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
1
Recommandé
7.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 29 juin 2020
Umurangi Generation is one those unique games that stands tallest, even amidst industry giants - at once perfectly accessible, heartfelt and engaging, this is a title that should be on everyone's list of games to try.

It is refreshing to have a game that asks you to care and observe your surroundings, taking in the sights, framing the shot, and absorbing the story - with this title having released within the context of Covid-19, rampant inequality, despotic and apathetic governments, and the ever looming climate crisis, Umurangi Generation feels like an emotional outlet.
The game does a superb job of handing over total creative expression to the player, drip-feeding tools and techniques as they progress - one level might see you getting to grips with a standard kit lens, before handing you another lens or editing function in the next. It feels perfectly paced and in harmony with the confidence and ability of the player.

Although one might be able to beat the game within a few hours, it feels as if it could be endlessly replayable, especially with the new tools the player unlocks throughout - as the credits rolled, I felt ready to jump back in, to capture new sights and imagery, and to let more story details wash over me.

In these times, I feel this game should be an essential pick - creative expression within a safe space, a sense of camaraderie, and a critique of those who have collectively failed us. This game serves not only as an outlet for its creators, but potentially for all of us.
 
COMRADE KIWI
1,601 produits enregistrés
0

0

10.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 28 juin 2020
In 2020 Umurangi Generation is an extremely important game. It shows that you have to look at the world to truly understand it, form your own idea of it, document it. The visuals are unique and allows the player to build their own vision of the world. The music is amazing, it adds so much depth to the locations you explore and the themes that surround them. Umurangi Generation is an incredible game.

2 hrs in its been great Its got a bounty system to get you through each level which works really well for helping you find fun shots and also get use to navigating each map you're dropped into. There's bonus ♥♥♥♥ to do which will net you more camera parts per level but the ten minute time limit can stress me out lol so what i usually do is take my time on the first run and take note of all the things i gotta do (which is really easy because the game has a file which it saves your pics to) and then on a second attempt ill crank out the requirements and have fun. Zec
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
1.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 24 juin 2020
TLDR: Went in expecting a sandbox game, came out the other end a war photojournalist.

Have you ever wanted to combine a skating-game-like freeform scoring system with professional photography in a run-down country torn apart by controversy and crisis? You want some Evangelion references with that?

I laughed, at first, when I saw the plugsuit-wearing UN pilot, bloodied, sitting on a bench next to a peacekeeper standing guard with a rifle. I wondered if they knew the peacekeepers I had photographed earlier, sitting around and bumming smokes off each other, writing graffiti on the roof of a skyscraper as they waited for the rain to pass.

Then the attack happened, and I saw my friends clutching rifles, desperately holding out against an impossible enemy while the soldiers tied their bandages and writhed in pain. I took pictures. I recorded every moment I could--pictures of the blood-soaked survivors gathered 'round over some American Style Fast Food, under an advertisement that advised them to "Unleash your inner child!".

I saw civilians who wanted the UN to go home. I saw desperate loners dancing in the street next to a "VR GAMER PARTY VAN". I saw memorials to the dead and messages from the dying.

Ten out of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ ten, this is a game I never knew I wanted.
 
dbrz
604 produits enregistrés
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
3.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 15 juin 2020
This is an excellently crafted succinct exploration game.
I'm not normally motivated to leave reviews but I just love this so much.
The environmental storytelling is awesome (in the truest sense of the word) and the interaction through the mechanics of photography gives you the perfect method for delving deeper into the world of futuristic Tauranga.
Can't say I've ever played something like this before.
A dystopian future which incorporates Te Ao Māori is pretty special.
If you like a unique experience that leaves you thinking, I can't recommend this game enough.
Ka pai, Veselekov. You've really knocked it out of the park with this one.

10.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 25 juin 2020
Gorgeous and compelling photography sim set in near-future New Zealand. The controls and platforming can feel slightly clunky at first, but the extra effort makes it feel so much better when you finally nail a great shot you've been trying to get.

A wonderful, subtle story that unfolds in the background and a killer soundtrack elevate a good game to a sublime one. Plenty of lenses and picture adjustments to unlock along the way as well. I'd be shocked if this doesn't end up being one of my favourite games of the year.

Évaluation publiée le 20 juin 2020
A striking, compelling slice of worldbuilding told through a camera lens. This is a game that does an astonishing job of painting a picture and drawing you into that picture, simply through its captivating (and entertaining!) environments. Small issues - the seemingly unnecessary timer, the lack of direction when it comes to the stage "exit" - are easily overlooked given the quality of the overall experience. Come for the vibrant colors, stay for the catchy tunes.

Fantastic rough gem. Bathe in the real life pleasures of finishing a roll of film, looking at your shots, and realizing you only took one that's worthwhile. I have some minor complaints about the polish, but I understand the limitations of a small team. I'd love for the developer to revisit the systems here with a larger budget.

Quick wishlist patch:
Make the sliders permanent between shots so I don't have to reapply them for each frame.

4.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 6 juin 2020
This is not a game for everyone, so I can’t tell you to go buy it right now. There’s a lot here that a lot of people won’t like, from the lack of a clearly presented story, the lack of any real challenge or obstacles to overcome, the fact that it’s pretty short at 7 levels and 3 to 4 hours of gameplay, or you might be one of those people that view this game as “pretentious” for daring to exist. If you liked what you heard and saw, then go for it. If not, then I probably wouldn’t suggest giving it a try because I doubt the game itself will change your mind.

I loved every second with this game though, and the fact that screen tearing was the only thing I could think to say ill about it speaks volumes to how wonderful I think this game is. I have no idea what Faulkner does next, but I eagerly await whatever it is.

Check out my full video review here:
Vidéo YouTube™:

Recommandé
4.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 2 juin 2020
Umurangi Generation is excellent - a really cool game definitely worth playing through.

It's a great example of how a story can be told through gameplay without needless exposition. By exploring locations and completing objectives the story reveals itself, with more detail to be picked up the harder you look around.

The gameplay itself is really well done, it's a mix of exploration / puzzle solving to take the photos to complete the bounties, and being able to edit each shot and unlocking more options as your progress makes the photography really fun.

Highly recommended game, really enjoyable and original.

Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
19.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 31 mai 2020
I'm not a photographer at all, but this game has me considering taking it up...

The levels seem lovingly crafted not only to tell a story, but to provide endless visual opportunities to explore and capture the world. Once you take a picture, you can edit with a bunch of different settings, starting off nice and simple for a novice like me with just a few settings. But even this was surprisingly enjoyable and addicting. More exciting things are unlocked and you get more of a grasp of how all these might interact to really bring out a unique picture.

As others have mentioned, there is a timer on each level strictly for an optional objective, as explained in-game. It helps you unlock more things, but it’s something you should just ignore and come back to. I had a much more enjoyable experience of new levels by just taking my time to explore and come across the main objectives, and to scout out and snap anything that captures my eye in the meantime. Later I can come back to levels to try and do it quickly, which I’ve now done for a few levels to get more settings/gear.

And of course, if I was ever having trouble finding that last elusive objective, it was never really bothersome or boring due to the fantastic music throughout the game, while still enjoying taking in the environment.
 
ibcamwhobu
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
4.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 27 mai 2020
Umurangi Generation is a fun, if short, game about photography in a neon dystopia. The gameplay is very simple, but the flexibility it offers combined with the open-ended mission objectives gives the game high replay value.

Overall, I like Umurangi Generation a lot. The art style, level design, and music are drenched in aesthetic, and the environmental story telling is rich and realized. The game is a little short (only lasting 8 levels), but I don't mind a game being a little on the short side as long as it's deep in its gameplay. In each level, you're given a set of 7 "bounties" which ask you to take pictures of certain things, sometimes with specifications on distance or lens type. It's not quite as open-ended as a game like Pokemon Snap; honestly, it feels a little bit more like a Tony Hawk game in terms of level structure. Additionally, you have 5 bonus objectives which are the same in every level: recreate a postcard, take a group photo of your friends, set a high score, find all the hidden film canisters, and complete the level in less than 10 minutes.

My main critiques come from the lack of incentives to perform these bonus objectives. The game lacks achievements, upgrades, or secret levels to reward you for your hard work. In a way, I appreciate this simplicity, but I want some sort of feedback for my performance. The game doesn't even save your highest score, which I figure is the bare minimum for a game with an arcade-style loop.

If you're looking for a lengthy, complex campaign, then this game isn't it. However, if you're looking for a fun, bite-sized experience, with great music and visuals, Umurangi Generation is a sure hit.
 
MoonMuse Brandon

Recommandé
3.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 25 mai 2020
What i would describe as a "chill" game, it is all about being there and taking in the atmosphere, the objective of taking pictures just being there as a reason to soak it all in. Although the game is relaxing, it isn't without challenge. It does require some problem solving to figure out how you're going to get some things in the same shot with a specific lens. The game has a narrative, but it isn't forced down your throat. It takes place in the various environments of the game where you carry out your objectives.

I thoroughly enjoyed the experience, the music and visuals were a perfect blend, the game is oozing style. The gameplay itself is simple, yet brings a real sense of catharsis when you get that perfect shot. It also comes with pretty limitless creative expression.

I can only really fault the game on the length, i needed more. Something to do after unlocking all the levels beyond just doing the bonus objectives too. What they have is pretty perfect, i just wanted more.
 
SS
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
10.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 25 mai 2020
The movement takes a little getting used to, so until you get used to jump strafing you'll feel like you're not moving as quickly as you want. But that's a good thing because it makes you take in the environment. The whole point of this game, at its core, is environmental story telling. The challenge hints can be frustrating at times, but in the quest to answer just what they want you'll end up soaking in the extra details. Ignore the timer your first time through a level and you'll have a great time. Great replay value since as you unlock more lenses and processing options you can get new perspectives on earlier levels. I wasn't sure what this game was going to be going into it, but by the end I felt like they really pulled off what their goal. Minor tweaks (clearer hints on a couple of challenges) and maybe just a slightly increased base movement speed would make this game perfect. Or maybe it would ruin it. Maybe the point is to go slow.
 
Extreme Walrus Juice
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
3.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 25 mai 2020
Umurangi Generation oozes personality.

The game revolves around taking photographs using a quick to pick-up FPS control scheme. The tutorial is quirky and does a great job of getting you started, and the objectives are laid out clearly for you when you jump in. You unlock lenses and other features by completing objectives and progressing through the game. It doesn't force traditional photography rules like 'power of thirds' or anything like that so it's not too intimidating to get into. However, you could absolutely implement these rules into a casual playthrough and get a lot of extra fun out of it.

Obviously, if your game revolves around photography you have to make sure the visuals are good, and this game delivers. No, you're not getting a super realistic high poly simulation with ray tracing, advanced hair physics and a 4D see it, smell it, breath it kind of experience. What you are getting is an incredibly stylish cel-shaded world and levels that compliment that technique - from urban city rooftops with red sunset skylines, to neon-lit edgy inner city night-time scenes. The developers have put their own humour into the art in the environments and it teases themes about troubles in the real world. Combining this with the 90's house / synthwave soundtrack gives the game a very underground 'f*** the system' kind of vibe.

I don't have much bad to say about the game. Collision jumping onto things / hitting sloped objects can be a bit awkward but it's so minor that it's barely worth mentioning. You can stack jumps in quick succession before launching to get unintended height (think Doom Eternal speedruns) but I actually like this quirk, it doesn't affect normal gameplay whatsoever.

For the aesthetic of the game, the replay value and the personality this game has, I would absolutely recommend this.
 
Matt
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
19.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 24 mai 2020
The Photo Mode Incarnate

Video:
Vidéo YouTube™: Umurangi Generation: The Photo Mode Incarnate 
Vues : 75
This was a game I was very much looking forward to. Enough to create this Review. Turns out it's a creative sandbox first and a game second.


Text:

The Photo Mode, a fun little distraction for the People who are stuck in a situation where they want to make good Pictures but lack the equipment or their surroundings are kind off…boring. It has been around for a while, enjoying growing popularity. My interest in it can be traced back to Alan Wake with it’s no HUD Option, which I highly recommend trying out. Now we’re getting titles exploring the Photography Part a bit more, dropping you in a Place with a Camera and tasking you to get certain pictures. This is also where Umurangi Generation falls into only stringing those Photo Ops together with a Narrative and an impressive Set of Options to make those Pictures look exactly like how you want them to. That alone is pretty impressive but is it enough to make this a compelling buy for 15 Bucks/12,50 Eurobucks?

The Setup / Story:
Umurangi Generation takes place in the Walled-of City of Tauranga, New Zealand, sometime after 2047. You’re an unnamed Courier, working for the Tauranga Express. Throughout the Game you will be send to various locations to complete Deliveries and take Pictures while you’re at it, as the Events, surrounding a Kaiju Situation, unfold around you. The Game takes the Route of only telling you the Story with the environment and Newspapers scattered around, meaning you actively have to look for the Story. While good for the most part and very fitting for a game about exploring Photography, I would have liked to get a Newspaper Print after a completed delivery, where you could see how the People get along with that whole Kaiju thing hanging over them and get a better picture of the world.

The Visuals:
The Visuals evoke a Neo-Noir Style. With Simplistic faces, jagged Models and an intentionally lower texture quality. It is a more unique Art-Style which has a very appealing quality to it. Sadly, the game isn’t optimized very well. In the more populated Areas, the framerate tends to go down very often, which can get one out of the experience. There is also a Problem with environmental Variety. If you prefer Landscapes besides the Concrete then sadly, you’re out of Luck as there are next to no Landscape Levels, you’re gonna have to live with Walls, Walls, Walls. This is something that DLC has to solve later on.

The Gameplay:
As it is a Game about Photography you’re only Equipped with a Camera and are tasked with taking certain Pictures that include things like “2 Boomboxes” or “a Skull and a Knife”. How you want to take those pictures is up to you. Many of those tasks can be completed any way you see fit while some require a certain distance or a specific Lens when taking the Picture. On Top of that there are Bonus Objectives, like “Recreate this Postcard”, “Take a picture with all your Friends in it” or “Finish the Level within a 10 Minute Window”. Completing all these nets you new Equipment, like Lenses or Camera Upgrades to give your Pictures a new touch and make it easier for you to complete Objectives, so it’s recommended to go ahead and finish everything first before moving on which, with a constant 10 Minutes Limit for Delivery, kind-of becomes a Mad Dash, where you will have to throw away your Artistic Sense to reach all those Bonus Objectives in time. If you just want to run through everything you will also be done with all 9 Levels in about 2 Hours and be bored afterwards, so bringing in a Creative Potential is required for long term enjoyment as that ties to the game’s main selling point and it’s best feature. When you take a Picture, you can customize it with various filters that you unlock during the game, which open up the possibilities for your Pictures more and more. Soon your Pictures can turn from regular looking to out there experiences and that is when the fun begins.

The Soundtrack:
The Soundtrack itself is pretty damn good. The Composer, Youtuber ThorHighHeels under the Alias Adolf Nomura, made a very good Soundtrack that fits very well into the Style of the Game. The Main Issue lies with the Implementation of it. A couple of Songs have already been in other Albums of the Composer and sometimes don’t seem to fit well with the Scenario of the Level, giving it rather more of a Playlist-Feeling than adding to the Atmosphere. A longer custom-made Track with a Separate Option on subsequent visits would have helped out with giving that first Playthrough more of an oomph.

Verdict:
Umurangi Generation is a game with heart and a solid game about Photography that I, as a Photo Mode Enthusiast, really enjoyed. It has some issues in terms of Variety and you should also be ready for the jank that comes with One-Man Development, which can get one out of the Flow but if you enjoy taking pictures and want to explore it with a set of Creative tools, Umurangi Generation is a recommendation at full Price. If you’re new to Photography or are still undecided you should try out the Demo first and see for yourself. But I want to say one thing: I am glad that a Game like Umurangi Generation exists. Not because it made me anymore interested in Photography than before, I still don’t have the Equipment and my Environment is still boring, but because of how it captured this feeling of being a Photographer. You don’t see that all too often.
 
Screenfunfan

Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
6.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 23 mai 2020
I love it when games leave it up to the players to decide how much they want to engage with the underlying themes and the mechanics.

On a basic level, you can just stroll through lively environments, complete bounties by shooting photos of some birds here or some plants and boomboxes there with varying lenses and listen to mellow alternative, jazzy hip hop and trip hop tunes.

The next level is looking for those rare shots, squeezing in one more bird by slightly tilting the camera to fulfil the objective from an unusual vantage point or perspective, and colorgrading them to your liking and aesthetic vision afterwards.

And the third and final level is engaging with the incredible story and concept told through visual cues, ephemera and underlying concepts, delving into the conflict at the heart of the game and drawing your own conclusions.

And that's where Umurangi Generation is the most rewarding for me. Someone else might have a total different take on what makes the game fun and engagig. And that's the beauty of it all.
 
zandterbird
